subdebate.1.para: Bill presented by Mr McGauran, and read a first time.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGAURAN
talker.role: Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the bill be now read a second time.

The Radiocommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1999 seeks to make various, unrelated minor amendments which have been requested by the Australian Communications Authority (ACA) and its predecessors, in consultation with the telecommunications industry and consumers. These amendments are largely unrelated to each other, but all of them will aid the provision of telecommunications services. Now I turn to the details contained in the bill.

(a) The current act allows the ACA to regulate communications only with designated satellites. The modern telecommunications space industry will utilise a range of space objects. Companies which intend to invest in the launch and operation of space objects need to be assured that radiocommunications signals to and from their space objects are not interfered with. This bill will allow the ACA to regulate communications with space objects.

(b) The bill will allow the Australian Broadcasting Authority and the Australian Communications Authority to make written agreements allowing the ACA to issue radiocommunications licences in the broadcasting services bands.

(c) The current Radiocommunications Act 1992, subsection 60(5), allows the minister to limit the amount of spectrum specified persons may acquire. To limit is not generally understood as zero. This bill will allow the minister the flexibility of limiting to zero, the amount of spectrum that a specified person could acquire and thus possibly better aid the introduction of new players to the telecommunications industry, and consequently greater competition.

(d) The act, at subsection 100(4A), currently requires the ACA, when deciding on whether or not to issue apparatus licences, to have regard to frequency assignment certificates which state that the apparatus in question will not cause `unacceptable' interference. This is an unrealistic requirement. The bill will replace the term `unacceptable' with a more workable statement to the effect that the correct frequency coordination procedures, as determined by the ACA, have been followed.

(e) Subsection 266A(1) of the act provides that the ACA may determine conditions that apply to the issuing of a frequency assignment certificate under the act. It is doubtful, however, that this gives the ACA the power to ensure that accredited persons maintain professional indemnity insurance for a reasonable period after they issue frequency assignment certificates. To protect persons in the telecommunications industry this bill will correct this deficiency.

(f) In connection with section 315 of the act, the bill will simplify and reduce the penalties payable in lieu of prosecution for offences committed under the act. The current penalties are complex and excessive. Simplifying and reducing penalties is likely to lead to them being more readily applied and the industry being better regulated.

(g) Under current legislative arrangements for licence renewal a licensee may renew a licence up to six months before the licence expires. Failure to renew by the expiration of the licence means that the licensee must apply for a new licence. However, between the expiration of the licence and the issue of a new licence, licensees generally continue to operate but pay nothing to the ACA during this period. The bill will ensure that, if a licence is renewed, it will commence from the time of expiry, ensuring that licences are not used without appropriate fees being paid.

(h) Currently, the Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Act 1983, the Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Act 1983, and the Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Act 1983 provide that licence tax instalments are due on the anniversary of the date of issue of a licence, not the date the licence commenced. It is inappropriate that a tax on a licence used for a particular period not relate to the particular period concerned. The bill will correct this deficiency in relation to the Radiocommunications Taxes Collection Act 1983. The Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Amendment Bill 1999 and the Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Amendment Bill 1999 will correct this deficiency in the Radiocommunications (Receiver Licence Tax) Act 1983 and the Radiocommunications (Transmitter Licence Tax) Act 1983 respectively.

(i) In the event that the ACA and Australian Broadcasting Authority (ABA) are unable to concur in revoking an agreement regarding communications services, which are licensed by the ACA, operating in the broadcasting bands, an impasse results. This amendment will provide a mechanism for cancelling agreements for communications services to operate in broadcasting bands that will give certainty to the marketplace by providing specific criteria under which an agreement may be revoked.

(j) Section 23 of the act currently states that the act does not apply to foreign satellites, vessels or aircraft. Section 195 of the act, however, purports to regulate transmissions from foreign vessels and aircraft. This is a problem that arose from the way the act was originally drafted. The proposed amendment will remove the problem and make it clear that the ACA may regulate transmissions from foreign vessels and aircraft in Australian territory.

(k) Some devices used in telecommunications are neither transmitters nor receivers but reflectors. The act only covers transmitters and receivers. Reflectors are a low cost way of extending the coverage of transmitters and receivers. They are widely used but companies which do use them cannot seek the protection of the act in relation to interference that may occur with reflectors they use. The proposed amendment will extend the coverage of the act to reflectors.

(l) Under section 187A, if the ACA wishes to pursue manufacturers or importers for failing to retain appropriate records concerning a device covered by mandatory ACA standards appropriate records, it must go to the expense of prosecuting them because that is the only penalty allowed by the legislation. This is expensive, time consuming and draconian. The proposed amendment will allow such persons to be fined, specifically $220 for individuals and $1,100 for companies.

(m) The ACA enforces compliance with product standards by auditing the compliance documentation assembled by manufacturers or importers. Paragraph 279(1)(e) of the act, however, requires that only `quality assurance program records' need to be produced. Other relevant records are kept by manufacturers and importers but the ACA has no right to see them. The proposed amendment will give the ACA the power to require for inspection all records relevant to products' standards. This will ensure that Australian consumers of telecommunications devices can be assured that devices that they purchase are fit for the purpose they intend.

(n) Under the act the ACA may create accreditation bodies, but the act does not allow these bodies to charge for all the services they provide under the act. The policy aim regarding accreditation bodies is that private individuals or companies would form such bodies, under the auspices of the ACA, and provide services to the radiocommunications industry. Current charging arrangements make accreditation bodies economically unviable. The proposed amendment will allow accredited bodies to charge for the services they provide under the act. This should see more accreditation bodies established and more services provided to industry.

(o) Certain radiocommunications devices may be lawfully operated only by `qualified' persons. The ACA has the power, under section 263 of the act, to devolve the examination and assessment process persons must undergo in order to become `qualified'. The ACA does not, however, have the power to devolve the issuing of certificates of proficiency to persons who have become `qualified'. Thus the ACA will retain a considerable administrative burden for no apparent reason. The proposed amendment will allow the ACA to devolve the issuing of certificates along with the examination and assessment processes.

(p) There is no existing measure to ensure that Australia is able to assert a taxing right over income derived from the use of spectrum licences in cases where such licences are held by non-residents. This is a potential tax loophole which the proposed amendment will close before it can be used.

I thank the House for its forbearance in this technical recitation of the major aspects of the Radiocommunications Legislation Amendment Bill 1999. However, I am sure the House will agree that these are issues which, although highly technical at first glance, are extremely important to both the flourishing of a competitive industry and to the protection and guidance of consumers. I therefore commend the bill to the House and present the explanatory memorandum to the bill. The explanatory memorandum that I am presenting in regard to the Radiocommunications Legislation Amendment Bill also covers the next two bills which I will introduce on behalf of the government.
Debate (on motion by Mr Stephen Smith) adjourned.

debateinfo.title: A NEW TAX SYSTEM (TRADE PRACTICES AMENDMENT) BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 10 December, on motion by Mr Entsch:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The debate on this bill, A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998, is an important one, but there is a more important debate that this House should be having, that is, the secret strategy of the Howard government to turn this economy into a low wage, low skills economy.

speech.para: Released last night was this secret document of Peter Reith—pennings from the penthouse. He couldn't write a book, but he could write a rambling letter. He couldn't get it published, so he published it himself. But what is the content of this secret agenda? It is a hidden agenda to turn Australia into a low wage, low skills economy based on confrontation. That is not what this nation wants.

This nation has to advance itself in forward thinking ways, not in the class division of the past, not in turning worker against employer, forcing us to the low wage end of the scale. We can only be a competitive, growth nation, able to hold our head up high, if what we are prepared to do is embrace policies that advance skills and innovation, that open up the economy and make us more productive. They are the sorts of policies we want and we will get those policies only from the Labor Party.

What is very interesting about this hidden document is that where the minister actually proposes some sensible suggestions they are all really Labor suggestions. The trouble is, as a government they are not prepared to commit resources to them, whether it is the tax credits or the extra money for labour market programs, the skilling of the nation or the introduction of mechanisms to get people from welfare into work—all Labor initiatives, all worthy of consideration but too hard for the government. Peter Reith comes to the conclusion that these are worthy of consideration but, because we are not going to commit the resources, what do we do? We will cut workers' wages; that is the solution. We will find every mechanism possible by which we can cut workers' wages. We will reduce this economy to a low wage, low skill economy.

What we need in this place is not just a bit of forward thinking but also a sense of bipartisanship. There is a debate about tax reform beyond the GST, but we are not getting it from the government. It seems to us that there are many areas—particularly if you look at this document—around which we could sensibly development reform, but not if we head down the path that this secret document concludes we should. So there is an important challenge to the government here today, important because what has come before the parliament are some musings of a minister, some considerations that, when he takes account of Labor policies, he thinks are not bad ideas `but we cannot implement them because we cannot acknowledge ownership, and anyway we are not prepared to commit the resources.' What we really need is a government which is prepared to embrace the initiatives which the Labor Party has been proposing and do something to get unemployment down in this nation.

The bill before the House in many ways exemplifies the government's approach to tax reform. It is basically all about smoke and mirrors. It is about assertions without substance and promises without follow-up. None of the promises made before the election about all the advantages of this great tax package have been borne out in the inquiry which was insisted on by Labor senators. On each of the counts where we set the markers—on fairness and the impact of the GST upon the economy—the government's assertions have been found wanting. We have found that the compensation package is inadequate because the inflation impact of a GST has been hugely underestimated. We therefore know that people will be much worse off than the government has been asserting.

Similarly, despite the assertions that this tax is good for the economy, in all the evidence before the Senate inquiry there was no evidence from the government to back it up, but evidence produced by witnesses proves quite to the contrary: there will be job losses, there could actually be a cutback in GDP, there will be no benefit for the economy and there was no evidence, again as the Treasurer asserts, that the revenue base is broken. The difficulty with this package—which they took to the election—is that the more you put it under scrutiny, the more it falls apart.

This is the bill which the government said was going to be the means by which they ensured that the benefits of abolishing 10 taxes would be fully passed on to consumers. What they have done is introduce a new 10 per cent tax on almost everything and they have abolished a number of other taxes: the wholesale sales tax, diesel fuel in part and a number of other taxes. We have asserted—and this has been borne out in evidence to the Senate inquiry—that we will not see the full benefit of those 10 abolished taxes being passed on. Yet the government's assumption in its tax package is that there will be 100 per cent pass-on. And in the election campaign they said that they would ensure that there would be strengthened monitoring powers and penalties to the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission to ensure this 100 per cent pass-on. That, supposedly, is the purpose of this bill. But like all the assertions made, it falls short of what was promised.

This bill is intended to prohibit the charging of unreasonably high prices for the supply of goods, having regard to the new tax system, and to empower the ACCC to monitor prices over three years from 1 July this year. In essence, it is about preventing price exploitation, exploitation that would hurt consumers and cause the inflationary impact of the tax package to rise. It is important to understand this. The government said that the inflationary impact of a GST would be 1.9 per cent. Already in the Senate inquiry Treasury has admitted it will be 3.1 per cent.
Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —It is, Joe. Have a look at the evidence. The public needs to know that because you hid it from them. It will be 3.1 per cent, not 1.9 per cent.

speech.para: Have a look at Treasury's own evidence. It is staggering if you do not know that. It is staggering for a minister of the government, promoting this bold new tax plan, to not even know what his own department is saying the impact of inflation will be. It will not be 1.9 but 3.1 per cent. That assumes 100 per cent pass-on as a result of the other taxes being abolished. No-one believes 100 per cent will be passed on. Why? Because, at the moment, in many cases you cannot identify what the tax components are.
Mr Billson interjecting—

talk.start.para: —There is an acknowledgment over there from the backbench that you do not know. If you do not know, how can you say they are being passed on? How can consumers be aware of what should be passed on? That is the very point. It will not just be 3.1 per cent that we are talking about by the time the Senate inquiry is finished; the inflation impact will end up being between four and five per cent—not 1.9 but something three times higher than that. Your compensation package will erode before people's eyes because you have underestimated the inflation effect.

speech.para: Not only have you underestimated the inflation effect and not only will that have implications for compensation—because older people, people on pensions and people on fixed incomes will not be compensated enough—but you will erode the low inflation environ that the policies of the Labor government underpinned. We have just enjoyed almost three years of inflation below two per cent. This one measure alone is going to add another four to five per cent on top of that. Why would you do it? Is it because we have low interest rates in the economy at the moment and because we have beaten inflation?

Why would you want to introduce a piece of policy madness that in one swoop will drive up the inflation rate another four to five per cent? What will be the implications for interest rates? What will be the implications for people's purchasing power? What does it mean in terms of the compensation packages that are on offer? They will be slashed. If those compensation packages are offered on the basis of 1.9 per cent inflation, when the true impact is four or five per cent, the compensation package is going to be woefully inadequate. Where are you going to find the difference?

We heard the Treasurer saying that tax cuts will be passed on in full. If he is going to give the full amount of compensation based on the inflation rate, he is going to have to dip further into the surplus. What does that mean in terms of fiscal responsibility? What does that mean in relation to where the markets rate this economy in terms of fiscal responsibility? This is an ill thought out package. As I said, the government's assertion—and this is what this bill is about: trying to back up the assertion that there will be a full pass-on of the benefits of the other taxes cut—is just not borne out by any of the evidence that the Senate inquiry has heard.

The ACCC will be able to formulate guidelines about when prices may be regarded as unreasonably high. It will be able to issue notices specifying the maximum price, it will be able to impose fines of up to $10 million against corporations and half a million for individuals in relation to price exploitation, and it will have to provide a written report quarterly to the government. Labor considers that, given the important role the ACCC needs to play—though it has not been given sufficient resources to do it—in attempting to restrain the inflationary impact of this GST, if it gets up, the reporting requirements should be more stringent. We will be proposing an amendment to that effect in the consideration in detail stage.

The bill is supposed to be about protecting consumers, making sure that every last cent of every last saving that was delivered as part of the Treasurer's tax package is actually passed on to the consumer—at least that is what they led us to believe. The Treasurer said, on 24 September 1998, in relation to the new 10 per cent tax on almost everything:

It's important when we abolish [existing] taxes that prices come down for consumers and we're going to have the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission ensuring that the reduction in prices from the 10 taxes being abolished is passed on.

But does the action match the rhetoric? To put it simply—so that even Minister Hockey, who did not seem to know about the inflation impact, can understand it—the bill is limited in scope and period of application. The ACCC simply does not have enough resources to do its job.
I will be foreshadowing several amendments to the bill, but at this stage I move the following second reading amendment:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words:
"the House, while noting that price monitoring will be necessary to avoid confusion and exploitation during the implementation of the government's New Tax System:
(1) condemns the Government for seeking to introduce a GST which is an unfair, job destroying new tax;
(2) condemns the Government for its failure to provide adequate resources to the ACCC for its new role and for the limited scope and time period of application of the monitoring; and

(3) condemns the Government for misleading the Australian people prior to the 1998 federal election with its assumption that the inflationary effect of the New Tax System will be only 1.9%, given that this is based on a 100% pass-through of savings which the limited pass-through monitoring mechanism contained in this Bill is unlikely to ensure".

I will go into some of those issues in detail. The government has allocated $27 million over three years for the ACCC to carry out its role under this bill. The ACCC has indicated publicly that it will employee a maximum of 40 extra staff—

talk.start.para: —Only 40 extra staff for a new 10 per cent tax on everything people buy. And what has the government done? It sourced 40 new people to ensure 100 per cent impact of the pass-through.

speech.para: Does anyone seriously believe that 40 people are going to be able to do that? This government does. And, if this government thinks that, it either shows it is naive and stupid or it knows that the promise it made of full pass-through simply will not be delivered, so it has hidden again from the Australian public the full inflation effect of this GST. If it has hidden the full inflation effect, what else has it hidden? The inflation effect is bad enough, because if inflation goes up the economy suffers: people suffer, purchasing power suffers. Yet this government would have you believe otherwise. It is important to understand, just to get some idea of the magnitude, that, if every one of the 40 extra staff the ACCC is taking on for its role works a 40-hour week and for the full three-year monitoring period, each of the 1.4 million businesses that the Treasurer wants to make as his GST tax collectors will be visited by the ACCC for an average of just over ten minutes over the whole three years. That is 4.1 seconds a week. Do we really think we are going to do some monitoring with 4.1 seconds a week? That is 4.1 seconds a week to ensure that we get 100 per cent pass-on. Give us a break. The public are not mugs. They know that you are not serious. This bill demonstrates that you are not committed to ensuring the full pass-on of the drop in the other taxes.

How can Australians possibly believe the Treasurer's assurances that the savings will be passed on? I hope the minister can give us an enlightened answer to this. Certainly the witnesses before the Senate inquiry into this do not believe him. Professor Ann Harding said:
Speaking as an ordinary person, it seems a little unlikely.

Something of an understatement! The National Farmers Federation said that the full savings would not be passed on. We hear the National Farmers Federation quoted in this place, including by the minister at the table, the Deputy Leader of the National Party, often enough when it suits. The federation do not believe the pass-on is there. Mr Higginson of the Road Transport Forum said that people `will try to hold on to some of the savings'. What are the industry and academic views? What about the ACCC itself? This is where it starts to get really interesting. Last week before the Senate inquiry, Mr Hank Spier, the general manager of the ACCC, said:
There's no way we can police every business.
Where are the resources, Minister? How are you going to deliver on your promise? He said there was no way the ACCC could police every business.

talk.start.para: —There is the $10 million sanction.
—Ah, he says there is the $10 million sanction, the fine. How can you impose a fine unless you investigate, you fool?
—There are 10 million policemen.
—We have got 10 million policemen now. Is this the job creation policy of the government, 10 million GST police, Minister? That is an interesting revelation.
—The consumers.
—The consumers are now going to be GST police. How can they be if they do not know what the tax component parts are? How can they be? What a joke. In what realm of reality do these people operate?
—The North Shore.

—The North Shore. I am sure there are a lot of people there monitoring the prices at the Gucci store, the Armani store and the caviar store. They would be monitoring those prices; I am sure they would. They would have a real idea of it, but it would not matter to a lot of them. What you are really talking about is ordinary people who cannot unravel the price of the existing taxes, who would not have a clue as to what the existing tax component was, who would not be able to be one of your 10 million police because they would not know what they had to police. Yet you said during the election campaign that you were going to commit resources to ensure that this happened. So what we have got is 40 people incapable of carrying out the government's promise.

speech.para: The Treasury inflation estimates I have touched on before, but I think it is important to reiterate this point. The inability to monitor prices by the ACCC in every business across Australia and the sheer complexity of calculating the effect of the removal of existing embedded wholesale sales tax will result in a less than 100 per cent pass-through to consumers of any savings generated through the removal of that tax. This will force up the inflationary effect on the new tax system, again calling into question the adequacy of the Treasurer's compensation measures. He has been touting the coalition's tax cuts around the chamber and beyond in recent weeks, but when we look at them they are not as rosy as he wants to make out. A single income family on $40,000 a year would, on Treasury's assumption, receive $29.90 as a result of the coalition's tax package. That is a figure based on 1.9 per cent inflation. But if the inflationary impact is higher, and let us just do it on the four per cent figure, the benefit is halved to $16.80 a week. That is the effect of the inflation impact. And, if you are not monitoring, inflation is going to go higher.

We know that Labor's tax credit is an idea that has now been picked up by the Leader of the House. The pennings from the penthouse have identified the tax credit as an initiative worthy of consideration. I will tell you why it is worthy of consideration: compared with the tax that you have offered, $29.90, which will be halved under the four per cent mechanism, Labor's tax credit to that same family offered $66.90 a week, and without a GST.

talk.start.para: —Rubbery figures.

—Rubbery figures, the minister says. I will tell you where the rubbery figures are, brother—they are in your tax package, which is being unravelled by the hour in the Senate. Rubbery figures indeed. These were figures costed by the very witness that has been before the Senate. Peter Reith knows the benefits of Labor's tax credit but he has not got the courage to force it through the cabinet.
—So he leaks it.

—He likes to have it leaked. He likes to self-publish his document to try and pretend he is a thinking man, a man of ideas, a man with an agenda. But whose agenda is it? It's our's—our agenda. The only decent idea coming from that side of the parliament comes from us.

speech.para: Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —He is a plagiarist.

speech.para: Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —If you read his document—I'll tell you he is plagiarising.

speech.para: Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Because in his own letter he says:

speech.para: The proposal—
this is in his letter about tax credits; this is good—
in the letter has similarities with the earned income tax credits suggested by the ALP.
So he has plagiarised it, Minister.

talk.start.para: —It's his job application.

—No, I think the shadow minister behind me is correct. This is more than a letter; this is a job application for the vacancy when the Prime Minister decides to step down—getting out of that nice, comfortable leather chair if it ever suits him—or when there is a decided move against him. This is one Peter positioning against the other Peter. These are the two Peters. These are the pieces from Peter: a tax piece and—what have we got?—a wage cut piece. Peter Costello, who wants to put a 10 per cent tax on everyone—that is his policy for the nation—and Peter Reith, who wants to cut people's wages; that is his policy for the nation. What a pack of dullards!

speech.para: When you look through this letter, the only decent proposals that you ever come across are those that have been advocated by the Labor Party—but the government will not commit the resources to them and they have not got the courage to implement them. The truth of it is: if people want genuine reform, give the authors of the initiatives the opportunity to implement them. We will commit the resources. We believe in these things. We believe in a tax system that gets people from welfare to work. We believe in a tax system that reduces the high effective marginal tax rates. That is why we have proposed the tax credit—we believe in a tax system that drives the direction for job creation.

You are not getting any of that here; you have only a cobbled together piece of junk from the minister for employment and industrial relations trying to outdo the other pre tender to the throne—the two pretending Petes. You have got them trying to outdo each other for policy ideas; one is to tax the public, the other is to cut their wages. This is not a direction in which this nation needs to go. The other point I want to go to in terms of this bill is that the policing does not extend across the full implementation period.
Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Let us go to it. The GST input tax credits for motor vehicles will be phased in over two years from 1 July, Minister. Right? Clause 12 of the bill provides for, in certain circumstances, GST-free supply up to or beyond 1 July 2005. Hence the full effect of the implementation of the new tax system will not be in place until the ACCC ceases its monitoring activities. This is a brilliant piece of monitoring!

speech.para: As we have seen with the debacle over the government's treatment of prepaid funerals, which the member for Lilley and the member for Newcastle have outlined, elements of the GST system are starting up already. You are getting the GST charged for funerals before you are dead—paid in advance—and the tax is not even in. What a great system! Where is the ACCC monitoring that?
Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Why don't we pass the package? We won't pass the package because we do not believe in it, and it is unfair. This is an example of where it is unfair: the tax reform hotline is telling people that funeral directors should put their prices up for prepaid funerals entered into after 2 December in anticipation of the GST applying. They cannot wait for this tax—it is not even legislated and they are slugging you before you're dead. Talk about a death tax paid in advance! Then, after people are told, `Go and find out what the amount is,' they say, `See an accountant.' I thought this was supposed to be a simple system, Minister.

speech.para: What about the inadequacy of the powers? Another glaring inadequacy in this bill is that it does not give express power in relation to other changes to be implemented. The only express power goes to the relationship of the wholesale sales tax abolition. Where is the reference to the diesel fuel credit scheme, Minister?

talk.start.para: —It's covered.

—It's covered, is it? I would like to hear that in your response. Where is the reference to bank taxes and stamp duties? In relation to the state charges, we have not yet seen the legislation implementing the abolition of these charges. It is therefore difficult to see yet if the ACCC's powers will be extended.

speech.para: This is part of the problem: you will not reveal the full details of your package. There is still more hidden. But the explanatory memorandum indicates that these changes can be included by way of regulation. So now we are going to have the parliament not overseeing the monitoring power; it will be left to the bureaucracy, left to be hidden again, left to be buried away. So we have to take this government on trust—trust in relation to a tax they said they would never ever introduce. They now want you to believe there will never, ever be increases as a result of the taxes that they have abolished.
We heard the Deputy Prime Minister promise to resign if he did not deliver on the $3½ billion cut in fuel taxes. He said on the 7.30 Report on 9 September:
As part of [the] Coalition package, we will empower the ACCC to see that [fuel savings will] flow right across Australia.

Where is the empowerment? It is not in the bill, Minister. This is a Deputy Prime Minister who has deceived the Australian public in terms of the rural constituency over what he says is the single most important dimension of their tax package—cuts to diesel fuel. He has deceived them. He told them that he was going to give the ACCC powers and yet the bill that comes before the House does not contain those powers. The ACCC has not got that power. The minister should show where it has. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Is the amendment seconded?
—I second the amendment and reserve my right to speak.

—I always enjoy following and even listening to the contribution from the Deputy Leader of the Opposition. He seems to think that this place must be a branch meeting of the ALP, where he can substitute reasoned argument and thoughtful, sober comment on public issues with vitriol, verbal diarrhoea, gum flapping and name-calling. Fortunately, most people in this place are not persuaded by that sort of behaviour, and the member for Hotham does himself no credit at all by carrying on in that way so consistently and so predictably.

speech.para: The significant thing about what he had to say is that there was nothing in it. It was a rerun of the election campaign arguments that the Australian people heard, digested and realised were more of the ALP's overblown rhetoric about tax, because the ALP has form on tax. We had the l-a-w that went in the b-i-n. We have a side of politics that could not stick with its commitment to hold taxes. We had the infamous Dawkins budget in the glory days, which the member for Hotham seems to want to go back to.

Remember those glory days when the Dawkins budget was being talked about? I met a proprietor of a home maintenance business in a group of about 150 people at a meeting I attended during the election campaign. I am not quite sure what his objective was in being there, but he shared with me his frustration during the Dawkins budget era as a wholesaler in the confectionery industry. He told me that, in the course of about three days, as he was trying to liaise with the suppliers and retailers of the confectionery products he was selling, he had no idea what was going on with the tax changes. He would get a phone call from the manufacturer who would say, `The taxes are going up. Labor is going to whip up this slippery, hidden wholesale sales tax on confectionery products. We don't know quite what they are going to do, but stay tuned.' He was saying, `What do I tell my customers?' They said, `We don't know what to tell your customers because we don't know what the Labor Party is going to do.'

He reported to the public meeting that I attended that he then got another phone call saying, `They are having a bit of a rethink about it. There are problems with the definition of confectionery and other supposedly more staple food items. It's a bit clouded. They are worried about the politics of it. Hold the phone, we'll be back to you again.' Then another phone call came. `It's back on the agenda as one of a raft of wholesale sales tax increases that will apply to an enormous range of products that are purchased by the Australian community.'

It was back on the agenda and up it went again. That is the very same tax that the member for Hotham must have been talking about when he was referring, in his speech on his amendment, to the hidden taxes, the confusion, the exploitation. That must have been the tax system he was referring to, because that is the tax system we want to overturn for that very simple reason that it is hidden, it is confusing, it can be manipulated by those in government—as evidenced by the ALP continually and by the continual flip-flap during the Dawkins budget era. That is why we want to change it. People do not know what it applies to, they do not know the rate of it, and they certainly do not have a feel for what component of the price they are paying for goods is tax. That is why we want to make those changes.

He was talking about the Australian people not being mugs. I wholeheartedly endorse that. He was suggesting, though, that Australians, in not being mugs, would somehow have difficulty with this plan the government has put forward. The Australian people are not mugs; that is why they threw Labor out in 1996. The Australian people are not mugs; that is why they have supported the Howard government on this reformation of our tax system. And, above all, Australians are not mugs because if they think they are getting ripped off they act.

What is the thesis of the Crean argument? What is the slippery Simon picture on tax reform? He has three key points. The first is that consumers are mugs because they are not able to discern between suppliers of goods and services—you need a bureaucracy in Canberra or somewhere ticking off every price that is put on a product or service. Why is he saying that consumers are mugs? The people I know, the electors of Dunkley, will, if they feel they are being asked to pay too much for a good or service, go somewhere else and check out the price. Simple Simon believes that this economy is just one little individual surrounded by all these hostile influences with no capacity to make choices about the things they do in their own lives. That is his thesis: that the Australian people are mugs. The member for Hotham believes Australians are mugs because they do not know how to engage in the sensible use of the funds they have available to them. That is his first thesis.

His second thesis is that we run in some sort of controlled economy, that we have to report back to Canberra with every price because if we do not do that people will be taken advantage of. There is a great thing about the Australian community—if you are not happy with something that is going on, you shop with your feet, you hop up and you go somewhere else. If you feel someone is taking you for a ride you go and check with another supplier or provider of the service or another retailer and you check it out. That is called negotiation. I do that in my family. We are a single income family. I have done that right throughout my life because we want to make sure we are getting value for money.

What is the Crean thesis? That people are not interested in value for money? That they will just, in some helpless way, wander up to these nasty people who are the backbone of our economy and be taken advantage of? That is the second part of the Crean thesis.

I like the third part of the Crean thesis best of all. He is saying that the economy is fine. He is saying that the economy is humming along and going so well, why would you want to change it? What a great endorsement of the Howard government's program that the member for Hotham, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the supposed pre-eminent economic spokesperson of those opposite—excluding those who are writing their books—believes the economy is fine.

We think the economy is much improved on what it was in the Labor years, but we want to keep working on the economy, we want to keep making sure that there are more job opportunities out there and that there are increases in real wages. So when the member for Hotham says that the economy is fine, I think that is an endorsement of what the government has done and it gives us confidence in the other measures the government is proposing to bring about even further improvement in the economy. The member for Hotham, the Deputy Leader of the Opposition, the pre-eminent economic spokesperson of the opposition says the economy is fine. I think it is much improved on what it was but I would like to see it a lot better.

What is significant about the contribution of the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is that he did not land a punch on the bill that is before the House. He could not find a problem with it, even though he has had difficulty coming to grips with the contents of it. For his benefit I will refer to some comments by Simon Blake from Clayton Utz which appeared in the Australian Mobile Telecommunications Association newsletter. He said:

Price exploitation as it's defined for the purposes of this bill in section 75AV as occurring if the `price for supply of goods or services is unreasonably high having regard alone to the New Tax System changes'.

He was trying to say that they were not including all the issues in the tax system. I would encourage him to apprise himself of the contents of the bill. I imagine he has been working on that preselection speech, or whatever it was he delivered in this House, and has not had the opportunity to apprise himself of the contents.

What is significant about today is that A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 is before the House and it is the delivery of another element of the coalition's tax reform plan, endorsed by the Australian community. It is probably one of the reasons why tax reform was a positive influence on the outcome of the last election. The government has delivered—on time, in full, on budget and within the context of a responsible fiscal agenda—all the tax commitments that it went to the Australian people with. They have been delivered. What a vivid contrast to the tax reform era of the ALP.

The problem we are working with is that for 13 years under Labor tax reform meant new taxes, more taxes and a bigger hand of the government in your pocket. We are trying to work through the static that has been created by those opposite and put forward a tax plan that leaves more money in people's pockets. We know that is a difficult task, but we are studiously taking up that challenge. It is further evidence that the Howard government is getting on with the job, despite the obstructionist approach of the Labor opposition and the minor parties.
In the policy document, `Tax reform: not a new tax, a new tax system,' the Howard government laid out its comprehensive tax reform proposal. On pages 15 and 16, it said:

A transitional price oversight regime will be established under special legislation which will give the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) special powers to ensure that price changes by business are consistent with changes in tax rates.
Page 22 of the tax reform plan document went on to explain that the legislation would provide the ACCC with powers to formally monitor retail prices and:
. . . to take action including imposing penalties up to $10 million against businesses that adjust prices in a way that is inconsistent with changes in tax rates.

The abolition of a range of state and federal taxes is a key part of the government's tax reform agenda and is why the cost of living impact has been confidently estimated to be just 1.9 per cent. The member for Hotham was talking about some other form of analysis, but in the sober, clear light of a new day I think he would accept the fact that the economic modelling done by the government on the price impact is quite extensive. A well-founded argument underpins that assessment of a 1.9 per cent price impact and not the rhetoric or overblown statements which Mr Crean wants to substitute for sound argument.

With many of the taxes which are to be abolished, hidden or buried in the final retail price of goods and services, the government has acted to address community concern about possible price exploitation and excessive profiteering. Treasurer Costello and the Howard government have delivered continu ing low rates of inflation at an average of one per cent per annum under the coalition, compared with a 5.2 per cent annual inflation rate under the former Labor government.

Six cuts in official interest rates since the coalition was swept into office in 1996 and a growth rate of five per cent point to a strongly performing economy—or a miracle economy, if you accept the assessment of Fortune magazine. Workers are benefiting from the 400,000 new jobs created since the Howard government was elected in March 1996 and real wages growth at five times the rate Labor could deliver in its 13 years. The member for Hotham thinks the coalition government is somehow hostile to working people, but the coalition government—Prime Minister Howard, Treasurer Costello and the whole Liberal-National Party team—has delivered the goods for wage and salary earners in this country.

These are prosperous but competitive times for our much admired Australians who apply their expertise, wit and skill to create the wealth and employment that benefits all of our community. But the very same conditions that have supported sustained growth, improved standards of living and new and secure employment opportunities are testing times for business proprietors and decision makers. There are no loose and sloppy profits about, simply there for the taking. Business success needs to be worked for.

I am reminded of a conversation with a local business person who, like me, was buying some of the magnificent barbecued chicken available from the Playne Street chicken shop in Frankston. He was lamenting the passing of the time when high inflation made for easier times for him as a business person. His worry was that now he had to trade his way out of any business mistake he might make and could not simply sit back and let inflation deliver him a counterfeit business growth figure at the end of the year in his profit and loss sheets. He told me how, in the past, he had simply put up his prices a little faster than inflation to hide any bad call he might have made within his business.

His customers did little about this as they were conditioned to inflationary price increases being a natural and unfortunate conse quence of economic growth under the Labor government. The key to profitability was simply to stay ahead of wealth-eroding inflation—and so was born the prices spiral that damage so many businesses in the Dunkley community during those 13 dark years of Labor. The coalition has broken that growth-inflation nexus by sound economic policy. This is behind us. We might not have dampened the taste for sloppy profits in all people operating businesses in this new environment. While the strengthened competitive pressures that are in our new robust, motoring-along and internationally admired economy will deliver the benefits of the abolition of many state and federal taxes, there is a chance that nostalgic tendencies may stand in the way of reduced retail prices.

Market forces and the risk of cavalier profiteers losing market share will contribute to ensuring that consumers enjoy the benefits of the abolition and reduction of state and federal taxes. This has been proven to be the case in other jurisdictions where an outdated tax system has been reformed or extensively renovated. I note that nothing in what the member for Hotham had to say pointed to evidence that what the government was doing would not work. Nothing he pointed to suggested that in other countries where similar tax changes have been made there was runaway profiteering and helplessness within the consumer community—or, as the member for Hotham would rather represent them, the Australian mugs, but I do not believe they are mugs as he seems to think they are. There is no evidence of that happening in other countries where tax changes have been made.

In the recent industry newsletter that I mentioned earlier from the Australian Mobile Telecommunications Association, Simon Blake from Clayton Utz overviews this bill under the headline `Government provides ACCC with GST teeth'. Mr Blake makes the point:
Given the intense competition between various players in the telecommunications industry, it would not appear likely that price exploitation would be a factor.
Nevertheless, Clayton Utz goes on to advise that businesses should be aware of the provisions of the bill we are debating today and:
. . . ensure that in setting price structures in the post GST regime, that all prices are justifiable on normal commercial bases.

This is the very clear message circulating around one of the key sectors of our economy and business community. This is a message that is going through all sectors of our economy—that competition will play an important part in the implementation of these reforms.

This is good news for consumers when we consider this advice alongside the estimated $1.3 billion or 4.9 per cent in savings anticipated in the costs in the communications services industry as a result of indirect taxation. That is just one sector—4.9 per cent savings. In that comprehensive plan that the government has released you will see table after table of areas of our economy where savings are expected. I would encourage consumers to have a look at those tables, and that will give you a sense of what sort of savings and what sort of negotiating stance you should take when you are going to buy goods and services.

My research suggests that there is little evidence of specific examples of consumer exploitation or excessive profiteering in international experiences similar to the coalition's tax reform plan. While in the national interest there is a moral obligation on all of us to play a part in the successful introduction of the new tax system, we need to be mindful of our own culture, which sees beating the tax system as sport for many.

Australian business exhibits an aggressive attitude to taxation issues by international standards, so it is not surprising that material released as guides to business are indicating that there may be `appreciable GST opportunities' due to the scale and newness of the tax. CCH Australia Ltd's Handy GST guide does, thankfully, add to such an assessment that the bill before the House `give(s) the business community some encouragement' not to profit-take through the exploitation of consumers during the transitional period. Moreover, businesses themselves need to be aware of cost reductions available to them. In the transition period, it will not help businesses to secure input cost savings if they are not mindful of, and prepared for, the savings that will arise from the abolition and reduction of other taxes.

Businesses need to be alert to these cost reductions, and the relationship between those reductions and prices, if they are to stay competitive with more astute players within their industries and markets and, above all, to stay competitive in the eyes of discerning consumers. Planning is important. The CCH Handy GST guide adds that the provisions of the bill:
. . . will come into effect on 1 July 1999 and thus business will need to take this into account in developing price strategies to cope with the impact of the GST.

We need some insurance against the odd example of someone chasing a quick and easy buck under the cover of changes in our taxation system not only for the sake of supporting the successful implementation of the new taxation system, but also because the potential negative impact on the positive macro-economic conditions that the Howard government has created are too important to lose. They have been achieved through hard work, not through wishing, not through lecturing, not through posturing, as the member for Hotham went on about. They have been achieved through hard work, and they are too important to lose.

The tax abolition or reduction that is an integral part of the tax reform plan needs to be allowed to act to reduce prices. This is part of the consumer dividend of the tax changes and will ensure that maximum benefits are derived from increased disposable income borne out of the income tax reductions that are another part of this comprehensive plan.

International experience suggests that transitional integrity plays a significant role in the bedding down of tax reform. The astute and clinical implementation of the New Zealand tax reform is credited with contributing to the general public acceptance of these changes. In contrast, the cumbersome and unresponsive implementation of similar changes in Canada is credited with generating some lingering hostility to their tax reform. So there are some broader issues here about underwriting and supporting the excellent macro-economic conditions that the Howard government has created for business and employment growth within this community, in addition to getting the tax system bedded down properly.

The A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 will play a role in ensuring that the Australian community enjoys the full value of tax reform benefits. The bill will also support the general positive economic environment that is delivering growth, more employment and business opportunities. The bill will also act to underwrite the integrity of the transition from the old tax system to the new. It is a great proposal and I encourage the House to support it. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I was entertained to hear the member for Dunkley refer in his closing remarks to `lingering hostility' to the GST in Canada. It is certainly my recollection that it was a conservative government in Canada that introduced the GST and that the electorate responded to this by reducing that government from, I think, 160 seats or thereabouts—certainly a majority of their parliament—to just two seats; talk about an election drubbing!

speech.para: Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The answer to the interjection is that we have an obligation to look after the Australian people which transcends consideration of our own electoral wellbeing. On behalf of the Australian people who voted for us, over 50 per cent of the Australian people who voted against the GST, we have an obligation to do everything we possibly can to make sure that this country is not saddled with a GST. Indeed, it is the government which displays contempt for the Australian people by still pressing ahead with this legislation, knowing that at the last election over 50 per cent voted against a GST.

speech.para: Since the election we have seen many revelations about the way in which the GST will operate, and I intend to go through just a few of those. But first we need to expose just what a mickey mouse arrangement this government is proposing to put in place to monitor prices and to try to prevent the GST being exploited. The first of those that I want to talk about relates to fuel prices. The Deputy Prime Minister on The 7:30 Report on 9 September last year promised:
. . . as part of [the] Coalition package, we will empower the ACCC to see that [fuel savings will] flow right across Australia.

I invite members opposite, and I invite the Australian electorate, to have a look at this legislation and see where is the provision in this legislation that will empower the ACCC to monitor the Diesel Fuel Credit Scheme. Where is the power for the ACCC to have a look at fuel prices? If that power is not in the legislation, how is the ACCC to ensure that fuel savings will be passed on?

We asked this question of the Deputy Prime Minister yesterday, and he had no adequate response whatsoever. Even worse, in the Senate estimates hearings last week, Mr Hank Spier, General Manager of the ACCC, said that it was his understanding that the Diesel Fuel Credit Scheme was not specifically defined in the legislation as coming within the ACCC's powers. With no specific role for the ACCC prescribed in the bill concerning the Diesel Fuel Credit Scheme, there is simply no guarantee that any savings from this scheme will be passed on to consumers. So we cannot look forward to those lower fuel prices that the Deputy Prime Minister assured us would happen prior to the election. We see a government which is not fair dinkum about this area.

The other evidence from the Senate select committee I want to refer to at the outset concerns the issue of itemising the GST separately on retail receipts. We have had the Treasurer describing the sales tax as a secret tax and saying, `Now we are going to move to a GST as a transparent tax.' But when we ask him, `Is it to be itemised separately on retail receipts so that customers can see just what the GST is?' the answer is no.
In evidence on 21 January this year before the Senate Select Committee on A New Tax System, Mr Greg Smith, a senior Treasury official, conceded:
Consumers by definition cannot give you the answer of the tax implicit in the price. I will not expect any consumer, high or low income, to know the answer to that.

So there it is. How are consumers to understand just what is the GST component of any given price? The bill before the House is a bill which the Labor Party will support. We are absolutely opposed to the imposition of a 10 per cent GST on nearly everything, but we will support this bill because we do not want to see Australian consumers suffer as a result of the implementation of the GST. It is a bill which has wide-ranging and far-reaching powers, some of which are close to those which were rejected by the Australian public in the 1948 referendum on price and rent controls. In some respects, it is interesting that the Right of politics is advancing these ideas. If a bill like this had been introduced by the Left of politics, I am sure it would have been characterised as some kind of Marxist plot. It does point out double standards in the area of price monitoring.

When we talk about bank fees and charges or when we talk about petrol prices, the government always says, `We have faith in the markets; you should let the markets determine these things,' and, `Informed consumers will ensure the lowest possible prices.' This bill shows that members opposite in government do not actually believe that. It shows, when they are concerned about the GST issue, what they want to do is then give the ACCC the power to monitor prices, to impose fines and to issue injunctions and so on. It shows that they have no faith in market forces when it comes down to it.

This bill gives the ACCC control over any price that is affected by the implementation of the GST—that 10 per cent tax on nearly everything. It gives the ACCC powers to prevent price exploitation and to prosecute organisations or individuals engaging in price exploitation. It allows the ACCC to prevent price rises due to the GST, and gives it the ability to set a maximum price for any item or service that may be affected by the GST. It allows the ACCC to monitor these prices.

But, while we support this bill on that basis, there are serious problems with it. The first is that it accompanies and is part of that job destroying, regressive tax package which will result in consumers being slugged with a GST on nearly everything. Secondly, when we look at the detail of the bill, we find a government which is not serious about actually monitoring prices and about actually ensuring that profiteering does not arise as a result of the GST.

I say this because, firstly, the government has only committed $27 million over a period of three years for the ACCC to monitor those prices. That is a grand total of $9 million a year to monitor the imposition of this tax. We need to contrast this with the money the government spent advertising the GST in flagrant breach of the caretaker guidelines. The government spent some $19 million in two months advertising the GST. So we have $27 million over a period of three years for policing and $19 million over two months for advertising. What a lamentable set of priorities.

Indeed, the bill will allow for only some 40 staff in the ACCC to monitor prices. That means that, over the three years of policing every business affected by the GST, there will be a grand total of 10.7 minutes devoted to checking. I think all Australians will realise just how ineffectual such an arrangement will be. That paucity of funds devoted to the monitoring of the effects of the 10 per cent tax looks even more absurd when you consider the government's pre-election promise that the total maximum rise in CPI due to the implementation of the GST will 1.9 per cent.

As we have seen through the Senate, that estimate assumes a 100 per cent pass-through of savings; so it is absolutely critical, for this government's figuring to work out, that every business which has any kind of reduction in its costs as a result of sales taxes or other taxes being dropped passes that through to consumers. It is not our belief that that will happen.

Indeed, the 1.9 per cent is not an estimate of the impact on inflation when the GST is introduced in the year 2000-01, if the government gets its way; the Treasury has admitted to the Senate that that figure will be 3.1 per cent. We believe that estimate is far too low because it does not take into account the billions of dollars in compliance costs which will be faced by businesses and inevitably passed on to consumers. It does not take into account the transitional provisions which deny tax relief for motor vehicles. It does not take into account that the abolition of indirect taxes will not be fully passed on to consumers and certainly will not be fully passed on in year one.

Access Economics has also said that there will be an inflation impact estimated to be around 0.5 per cent when the income tax cuts are introduced but which the Treasury has not factored into its inflation estimate. So, in reality, the first year inflation impact of the GST will be in the order of five per cent or higher, not 1.9 per cent. The GST will add to ongoing inflation by introducing a price and wage spiral. What is the evidence about this 100 per cent pass-through which the government is depending on in its inflation estimates and in its estimates of the adequacy of the compensation package? Professor Harding from the ANU said:
Speaking as a professional economist, I do not know because I have not studied it. Just speaking as an ordinary person, it seems a little unlikely.
I think she is right on the money there. Robert Douglas from the NFF said:
If a GST is introduced, it will be practically impossible to determine how much subsequent commodity price changes will be due to the GST and how much due to other factors.
Associate Professor Neil Warren from the University of New South Wales, concerning this assumption of 100 per cent pass-through, said:
As an immediate assumption, it is a brave assumption.

That is absolutely right: all the evidence coming through to the Senate committee suggests it is a very brave assumption indeed. I did indicate earlier that I thought this legislation exposed some of the government's double standards and poor priorities. I want to come back to this theme: it is something that Labor has been pursuing for some time on behalf of consumers—in particular, the issue of bank fees and charges and the issue of petrol pricing.

In May 1997 our then shadow Treasurer, Gareth Evans, asked the Prime Minister whether or not the government would `direct the commission to formally monitor all retail bank fees and charges to ensure that bank customers get a genuinely fair deal'. The Prime Minister described this sort of question as technical nitpicking. In my electorate, people have a very different view of this. We have been greeted with a spate of bank branch closures, in particular by the Commonwealth Bank. When it closed its Strathmore branch I got a letter from Mrs Patricia Walsh, who in particular expressed concern about the use by the bank of the phrase `due to declining customer usage' which, as she pointed out, only added insult to injury. She said:

Perhaps a more accurate version would be "Due to the outrageous charges recently introduced we find our customer numbers declining". Surely any enterprising organisation would see `declining customer usage' as a challenge to improve the product rather than see it as a reason to pack up, move on and ignore many loyal, local customers.

I think Mrs Walsh has made a very interesting comment, that the banks blame the need for branch closures on a declining number of customers when in fact their policies, including the jacking up of fees and charges, drive customers away. It seems to me that if bank fees and charges were being monitored by the ACCC we would have a whole range of benefits, including fewer bank branch closures.

We have seen the banks move to increase their fees and charges in an extraordinary way, massively increasing their fee income over the course of the last two or three years. It does seem to us that this is an area where there is a role for the ACCC. Regrettably, however, we have a government that is not prepared to act in this area. It does seem to us that we are not getting competition in this area. In fact, what we are getting is a race to the top: when one bank raises its fees, all the others follow suit. This was the subject of a study that has been conducted by the Sydney based Financial Services Consumer Policy Centre. Their director, Chris Connolly, said:
We are keen for the ACCC to investigate the conduct of banks in setting fees and charges, particularly in light of the dramatic spiral in the last couple of years.

So when the Treasurer and the Prime Minister talk about the red-hot competition which is supposed to exist in the banking sector what we really get in the area of bank fees and charges is red-hot competition to see who can get away with the highest fees and charges.

I know the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation, who is at the table, is a great defender of the banks. I think we would not be too far wrong if we described him as a spokesman for the banks. In December last year, the Commonwealth raised many bank fees. Over-the-counter withdrawal fees were raised from $1.50 to $2, cash withdrawals from an ATM fee went from 45c to 60c—

talk.start.para: —What did you do about it? You had one, two, three, four, five—
—This was immediately after—
—Order! Minister!
—What year?
—The increase in bank fees and charges has risen massively in the last two or three years during the period in which this government has been in office.
—Oh, massively!
—Absolutely. That is where bank fees and charges have been coming from. We proposed in opposition that these things ought to be formally monitored—

speech.para: Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! The honourable member for Wills will resume his seat. Minister, I have asked to you restrain yourself. Try not to be a windmill with your arms, and I ask the member for Wills to please address your remarks through the chair and totally ignore any interjection by the minister.

—Thank you, Mr Deputy Speaker, I was being provoked. The increase in fees and charges has occurred during the last couple of years. In the 12 months to November 1998, Australia's five biggest banks raised over $10 billion from customer fees, charges and commissions. That raised their combined non-interest income by more than 17 per cent. That is not red-hot competition. What this government needs to do is to protect the people of Australia from these sorts of bank fees and charges which simply cannot be justified. We have a similar example existing in the petroleum market. In the second reading speech on the confused and, I sense, doomed Petroleum Retail Legislation Repeal Bill 1998 , the Parliamentary Secretary to the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources promised that by removing the impediments to competition downward pressure would be placed on petrol prices, particularly in country areas. This is simply not the case. In an article in the Age on 16 February, Ben Mitchelle wrote:

speech.para: The predicted benefits from the deregulation of the oil industry have yet to materialise . . .

The national petrol price figures for January show that petrol in an urban region costs on average 66.8c per litre while in rural areas it costs 74.4c a litre. This is after the famed petrol deregulation that is supposed to deliver a decrease in country petrol prices compared with city petrol prices. The Service Station Association has described the deregulation as a failure. They blame the changes that the government have introduced for squeezing out smaller service station operators. They have also pointed out that the ACCC has been doing very little to endeavour to bring those petrol prices down and use its influence over the industry.

In conclusion, we are going to support this legislation. We hope that it has some impact on kerbing price rises in the event that a GST is introduced. Our amendments point out that this is only necessary because of the government's unfair and job destroying GST. We point out that there are absolutely inadequate financial resources to do the job—a mere $27 million dollars over three years—a mere 40 staff to police GST base price rises right across the nation, limited scope of application and a limited time period for application. Indeed, we have already seen prices go up in the area of pre-paid funerals, and so on. There is some anecdotal evidence that retailers are getting in early and jacking up their prices.

What is the ACCC doing about these problems right now? This legislation is not scheduled to take effect until later on. There is a whole series of inadequacies in this bill which we will endeavour to address through amendments. But, clearly, the best thing for this nation to do is to avoid the GST altogether. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It has been quite amusing sitting here listening to the rantings of the member for Wills and, before him, the member for Hotham. Particularly amusing were the comments of the member for Wills about Labor's supposed intention to do something about bank fees and charges. I remind those opposite that for 13 years Labor had the opportunity to do something about bank fees and charges. Did they do it in year one? No. Did they do it in year 2? No. Did they do it in year 3? No. Did they do it in year 4, 5, 6, 7, 8, 9, 10, 11, 12 or 13? No. One week before the 1996 election the then Treasurer, Ralph Willis, came out with a press release saying that if they were re-elected in their 14th year they would do something about bank fees and charges. It is the old Labor line: `We couldn't do it in year one, we couldn't do it in year 2, we couldn't do it in any of our 13 years, but give us another go in our 14th year and maybe we'll get around to doing something about it.'

speech.para: This morning's rantings by those opposite are typical. We had from the member for Wills the same tired, hypocritical line about the supposed 10 per cent tax on everything. The member for Wills failed to mention Labor's 12 per cent hidden tax, Labor's 22 per cent hidden tax, Labor's 32 per cent hidden tax, Labor's 37 per cent hidden tax, Labor's 41 per cent hidden tax or Labor's 45 five percent hidden tax. If the rantings of the member for Wills were amusing, the member for Hotham who spoke before him really takes the cake. I was particularly interested when the member for Hotham had the gall to mention fiscal responsibility. The member for Hotham mentioning fiscal responsibility! He was a member of the frontbench of the former government that in its last five years blew out Commonwealth government debt from $30 billion to $97 billion, a government that more than trebled Commonwealth government debt in its last five years, a government that left us with a $10 billion deficit that this government has already, in the last two years, turned into a surplus.

The member for Hotham also had the gall to talk about interest rates. His government gave us the highest interest rates we had had for decades, home loan rates up to 18 per cent and small business loan rates close to 25 per cent. In just one term this government, the coalition government, has delivered the lowest interest rates in 30 years. Home loan rates are at about 6½ per cent, saving the average home buyer $300 a month, and business rates are down to less than 10 per cent.

The member for Hotham had to the gall to talk about inflation when Labor's inflation over its 13 years averaged 5.2 per cent. This government has already, in the last three years, brought inflation down to an average of one per cent. I could go on. Under Labor real wage growth averaged 0.5 per cent. Under the coalition it has already averaged 2½ per cent. Under Labor for 13 years unemployment averaged 8.7 per cent. Under this government unemployment is already down to 7.5 per cent. Under Labor for 13 years productivity growth averaged 1.5 per cent. Under the coalition it is already averaging three per cent.

When it comes to managing the economy, when it comes to reducing unemployment, when it comes to jobs growth, when it comes to reducing interest rates, when it comes to getting inflation down, when it comes to strong GDP growth, when it comes to good productivity growth and when it comes to ensuring real wage growth the coalition has the runs on the board. Labor was out for a duck. They were in the dressing-room pacing up and down, ranting and raving, trying to tell us that they knew better how to run the economy. We have the runs on the board. They were out for a duck because they could not keep their eyes on the ball.

This bill before the House is an essential part of this government's tax reform package; an essential part of tax reform which will continue this strong economic management, which will continue strong GDP growth, which will continue employment growth, which will continue to put downward pressure on interest rates, which will continue to give our exporters a fair go and a competitive edge and which will continue to give our families and our workers a fairer tax system that they need and that they deserve. It is this government's determination to provide an equitable, efficient, transparent and workable tax system—something that we did not see under 13 years of Labor and something that Labor is trying to prevent us introducing.

This bill ensures protection for consumers. It is part of the government's commitment to introducing a tax package which will ensure that consumers in this country, buyers of goods and services, are adequately protected and are not affected unduly by the tax changes. This measure is in addition to the other benefits that this tax package will introduce: benefits that will reduce marginal tax rates significantly so that 80 per cent of Australian workers will be on marginal tax rates of 30 per cent or less; measures which will bring about income tax cuts of $13 billion for Australian workers; tax reforms which remove some of the many tax loopholes that Labor wants to keep, that will remove many of the anomalies at the interface between welfare and work.

These tax reforms will remove Labor's hidden wholesale sales tax that has rates of 12 per cent, 22 per cent, 32 per cent, 37 per cent, 41 per cent and 45 per cent that they do not want you to know about. This tax package will reduce compliance costs for small business. It will remove totally that iniquitous provisional tax, remove the PPS tax, remove the RPS tax, and will give small business a fair go. This tax package will remove the unfair competitive disadvantage that importers have over Australian producers and it will give a fair go to our export industries.

This bill ensures that prices are controlled. It ensures that consumers are protected, that any price rises as a result of the introduction of these tax changes will be limited and that the removal of the 12 per cent, the 22 per cent, the 32 per cent and the 45 per cent indirect taxes will actually have a downward pressure on prices.

This bill commits $27 million to the ACCC to monitor prices over the next three years, starting in July this year. It gives the ACCC the power to monitor prices. It gives them the power to ensure that there are no excess price increases and to ensure that appropriate price reductions occur because of the removal of Labor's hidden wholesale sales tax. It gives the ACCC power to issue notices to corporations specifying maximum prices which can be charged and it gives the ACCC, significantly, powers to impose fines for breaches of those instructions—fines of up to $500,000 for non-corporations and up to $10 million for corporations. The government is serious about protecting consumers. The government is serious about introducing a fair, workable and transparent tax system. The government is taking no chances here. The government is absolutely committed to delivering a fair system.

I point out the comparison between this government's honesty and determination in this matter compared with Labor's dishonesty and deceit after the 1993 election. Straight after that election, despite campaigning against indirect taxes, they added two per cent to every indirect tax in the country. The 10 per cent rate went up to 12 per cent. The 20 per cent rate went up to 22 per cent. The 33 per cent rate went up to 35 per cent. And what did they do in terms of compensation? Nothing. What did they do to ensure that that did not flow through to prices? Nothing. They did nothing to protect consumers. They snuck in those extra taxes with no compensation and no protection. What did they give us instead? Instead of giving any protection, they took away their promised l-a-w tax cuts. That is typical of Labor's deceit and Labor's track record on the whole issue of taxation.

This bill is part of an essential tax reform measure which will provide $13 billion in income tax cuts to Australians, which will simplify the indirect tax base, which will remove 10 of Labor's hidden indirect taxes—a tax reform which will deliver fairness, simplicity, transparency, efficiency and incentive to Australian workers.

I am appalled, as most Australians are, at the obstructionism by Labor and at the obstructionism by the Democrats in the Senate, at their refusal to allow us to introduce a tax system that we took to the electorate, and a tax system that will bring about these much needed changes in Australia. And I am not the only one. I suggest that those opposite might like to look at yesterday's comments in the media about their obstructionism. The Sydney Morning Herald yesterday, for instance, says this about the obstructionism by Labor and the Democrats in the Senate. Yesterday's editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald said:

Tax reform, including the introduction of a broad-based goods and services tax (GST), was a central plank of the Government's 1998 election campaign platform. Voters knew the options and decided in favour of the Government's package. For the Democrats to obstruct a vote on the tax reform legislation—
