and can I add, for Labor to obstruct a vote on the tax reform legislation—
until after July 1 is nothing more than an attempt to impose the tyranny of the minority on the popularly elected government of the day.
This is the Sydney Morning Herald speaking about the dishonest tyranny of obstruction by the Democrats, aided and abetted by the Labor Party in the Senate. This editorial went on to say:

Most academic economists, both major parties, all States, business groups and even the welfare lobby agree that a fundamental overhaul of the tax system is overdue. Delaying it now will make it even less likely to be achieved after July 1.
The editorial then went on to say:
Has he—
Mr Beazley—

forgotten that he lost the last election? It is time for the Opposition and the Democrats to stop insulting the electorate and for the Senate to wind up its inquiry and allow the tax reform package to be passed.

I think that editorial in the Sydney Morning Herald says it all about Labor's and the Democrats' obstruction. I add a comment that was in the Financial Review yesterday from Angela Ryan, the Director, Taxation, of the Australian Society of Certified Practising Accountants. This comment is about the impact that such a delay might have on small business. Angela Ryan talks about the submission that their association made to the Senate inquiry. She said:
We made it plain in our submission and in evidence presented to the Senate Committee that there needs to be a smooth and orderly transition to the GST—
A smooth and orderly transition; that is what this government wants. That is what the Democrats and the Labor Party are opposed to. Angela Ryan goes on to say:
This requires that the GST Bills attain passage according to the announced timetable of June 30, 1999, to allow business to prepare for the GST.
If that transition is elongated because of a delay in the passage of the legislation, this could literally mean the difference between survival and bankruptcy for many businesses.
I repeat: the difference between survival and bankruptcy for many businesses. She goes on to say:

It is critical that passage of the legislation occurs as soon as possible to allow for 12 months between the passing of the legislation and its implementation—an absolute minimum based on overseas experience.
She concludes by saying:
In short, it is essential for the survival of many businesses that the GST receives passage by June 30, and that the tax take effect from July 1, 2000.

She says it is essential for the survival of many businesses. It is an indictment of Labor and the Democrats that they do not care about the survival of small business. They are willing to pursue their own hypocritical, political, obstructionist agenda which jeopardises the survival of small businesses in this country, and which therefore jeopardises the job opportunities of thousands, and possibly tens of thousands, of Australians. It is shameful for Labor and the Democrats to take this approach which will so jeopardise small business and job opportunities.

Labor's approach, and the approach of the Democrats, is pure, superficial, hypocritical point scoring. If they were concerned about taxpayers in this country, they would want to allow a tax cut package which would deliver $13 billion to Australian workers. They would want to stand aside from those hidden taxes, oncosts and burdens that so impede our exporters and small businesses. They would want to stand aside and allow us to change those indirect taxes that are such a burden on ordinary Australian families.

This tax package which the coalition is putting forward is the only way ahead for this country. It will address the problem of a shrinking tax base. It will address the problem of ordinary income earners being pushed into higher and higher income tax brackets. It will address the burdens on small business. It will promote GDP growth and jobs growth. It is the only answer for a stable, secure economy.

The coalition government has the runs on the board when it comes to managing the economy. The coalition government wants to get on with the job of managing the economy for the good of all Australians. It is time that Labor and the Democrats stood aside, listened to the will of the Australian people and let us get on with the job.

talk.start.para: —The issue of profiteering, when and if the GST comes into effect, is one which needs a watchdog—a watchdog with good teeth and who is well fed, because we have a very large backyard. The ACCC is best able to watch, to report, and to condemn unfair trading practices, to educate business and consumers and to enter into public debate about competitive prices or abuses. What the ACCC does not have, as a Commonwealth agency, is control over prices.

speech.para: A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 gives the ACCC the power to enforce fairly hefty fines against businesses and individuals caught taking advantage of the shemozzle in the period when the GST starts to bite. If we did not have the GST, we would not be facing what amounts to an anticipated rush into dishonesty. When retailers and service providers should be simply adjusting prices to accommodate the new tax, we automatically assume they are going to get greedy. That is a sorry reflection on our private sector, much of which is involved in setting up complex business structures in the name of tax-effective accounting.

The GST changeover provides an opportunity for an outbreak of price collusion. Unless the consumer has a spreadsheet mind, the sorts of confusing `deals' you get with mobile phones, cable TV, cars, computers or banking services—where you cannot get a straight answer on a basic price which you can match up with a competitor's product—are going to provide a cover for a complex set of price manoeuvres. This is where the price goes up across the board but no-one can figure out which part of the price was the part that rose. It is like who owns what under the Prime Minister's revised code of conduct.

It is my opinion that the ACCC will not be doing simple arithmetic in sorting out whether a retailer has a case to answer. I am sure they know how complex the task will be. The government, however, wants us to believe that the scrutiny of price movements—when and if they introduce the GST—will be a 10-finger exercise. Perhaps they are not giving enough thought to the role of the ACCC because some of them believe that the glow of that distant sunset is how their fabulous GST will look not too many moons from now.

They were the ones who forgot the undertaking by the Deputy Prime Minister, Tim Fischer, to include a reference to the Diesel Fuel Credit Scheme. It is going to be outside the scope of the ACCC's powers. That will not please the farming industry. That was just an oversight, we assume. How many more oversights, exceptions or special cases are there to be? What else is buried at the bottom of the yard? Maybe a bone that someone else wants to pick? Because if the ACCC takes on the job, they know they will have to move with care. Business reputations will be at stake. Profiteering is almost as bad as looting. It is generally considered repugnant. It is certainly a taint to be avoided because, as the banks know, a bad reputation takes a lot of shaking.

It will need a great concentration of mind and talent for the ACCC to avoid any wrongful imposition of penalties. Their focus is on almost 1½ million traders in our own back yard, and possibly some outside the country. It is a big ask. But they will have an extra $27 million over three years to work on it and report back to the Treasurer. That will go on a public education campaign—probably something a little more modest than the metric conversion campaign—and, we are advised, the funds will provide for an additional 40 staff.

Not that the ACCC has not got a big enough bone to chew on. They have the newsagents. They have wine industry mergers and takeovers. They have bread price battles. They have grocers against supermarkets. They have electricity power surge and brown-out damage issues to deal with. They have whitegoods mergers, the docks, a landlord and tenant case in Adelaide, telecommunications and soft drink and oil company merger questions. That is a quick review of press reporting on the dog's breakfast they have had over the past two or three weeks. Only the last two or three weeks! They could probably do with a few extra staff.

When it is operational—12 months before the new tax on everything—the `price police', as they have been dubbed, will have the job of tracking down offenders and issuing notices on what the correct price should be. That will not be easy, and accountants are hostile to the idea. Accountants spend a lot of time writing rude letters to the tax office. I imagine they will be happy to expand their list of penfriends to include the ACCC, but it will mean more work for the watchdog.

We on this side of the House support an expanded role for the ACCC. Their work is quality work. Their brief should be more comprehensive. Nevertheless, the commission is the appropriate means by which to check that 100 per cent of any savings brought about by the abolition of the wholesale sales tax will be passed on to the consumer. This legislation would not be before us if there were no doubt that this would happen.

The government has worked on the assumption of a 100 per cent pass-on. It told us that the inflation resulting from the GST will be `just a little'. Of course, if we do not get the full benefit of the pass-on, the inflation impact will be just a little more than a little— it will be all the way to a lot. This tax spreads over everything. Take motor vehicles. These days you do not buy a car; you buy an accessory package. You buy different combinations of options. So if you want dual airbags, you have to take something else in addition. And, of course, it is a different combination from a competitor's package. It is promoted as choice, but it is about muddying any comparative shopping.

Although the marketing and complicated price options for cars are similar to a number of products, motor vehicles have their own special place. The full effect of motor vehicle pricing will not have worked its way through the system until after the ACCC's transitional powers are over. The GST is all embracing, but the effects are only to be selectively monitored.

Still, the government has made its assumptions on a 100 per cent pass-through. We will have an additional 40 staff to make sure it is 100 per cent and that there will be no profiteering. What if it is not enough? What if monitoring this turns out to be a dog of a job? What if the news from the ACCC is bad and it needs more resources to be accurate on how bad it is? Will the government provide additional resources? If indications are that the pass-on is less than 100 per cent, this government will not want to know about it. A little bad information is better than a lot, especially when it comes to the GST.

There is another problem which the government has to put on an adequate length of leash—proper price enforcement. The proposed price exploitation code to be adopted by the states will amount to price control if it is going to be more effective than the `Dog and Goat Act'. Why do we need such a bold instrument? Not for any good reason of responsible government. It is because of the GST—it's a fix, it's a gamble. Will the states all fall into line? Who knows. Is the ACCC adequately resourced to properly monitor the changeover to the GST? No. That is the only certainty. It's a big backyard. It is a good dog, an excellent watchdog, but we all know the leash is far too short.

talk.start.para: —We are having this debate today because this government showed determination, leadership and courage in going to the Australian people at the last election with what I think every commentator in this country described as a very bold plan. This government showed leadership and courage because it believed that this is what is needed to provide relief for very hard working, average Australians and to provide relief for business, whether it be small, medium or large business.

speech.para: This stands in very stark contrast to the previous government which had 13 years to do something about this tax system, but they did absolutely nothing. In fact, they frittered away opportunities for tax reform for 13 years by merely talking about it. We all remember the tax summits where the former Prime Minister got rolled on his very good option C by members of other ideological factions within his party. We had various promises made over the years, but all of that amounted to a great heap of rhetoric. There was absolutely nothing delivered on the ground to provide relief for people.

This government stands in stark contrast; we listen to people. Let me give an example. Some months ago, I attended a function in my electorate at a very small area of great disadvantage, that is, King Lake, at the King Lake country fair. A man came up to me and firstly asked whether I was the local member and I said yes. He said, `I have got a real complaint. Do you realise that I can't support my own family on what I earn?' On questioning him, he told me that he had three children, all attending primary school.

That man was working overtime. He had a very good job. But the reason that he was complaining to me and the reason why he could not look after his own family was that he was losing so much of what he was earning in tax. Most of what he earned for the hours of overtime that he put in went to the tax man.

Unfortunately, that man's story is not a story in isolation. It is a story shared by hundreds of thousands of hardworking Australians. That is exactly why we are standing in this chamber today and having this debate. This government—unlike the previous government, which frittered away all of those opportunities for 13 years—at great risk, as many acknowledge and as I acknowledge from personal past experience, went to the Australian people and said, `We understand. We have listened to you and we understand what is needed.' This debate we are having today is about implementing change. It is about changing a tax system that has penalised people.

Previous speakers, whom I have listened to with great interest in this debate, in particular the member for Wills, had the audacity to talk about what is happening in regional areas of this country. The legacy of the previous government in not addressing this very issue can still be seen today. You have only to drive through small towns, like many of the towns in my electorate of McEwen, to still see what was once a thriving small family business now a vacant shop, the family forced to leave the district. The local employment that it provided no longer exists. Why? Because that previous government frittered away those opportunities.

Previous speakers have spoken about a number of economic indicators. Let us just look at a few of those. In contrast to what happened over those previous 13 years, when all of those opportunities were frittered away, let us look at what is happening today. Let us look at what has been achieved by a government that is prepared to show leadership, determination and courage.

talk.start.para: —And get a mandate.

—And get a mandate for it, most importantly. The previous speaker talked about the costs built into motor vehicles. She may be interested to have a look at the number of car registrations, which are on the increase throughout the country. Look at the level of consumer confidence. Look at the building rates. They are all on the increase. Look at the level of unemployment: it is still too high, and certainly far too high in our regional areas, but it is starting to come down. Look at the level of investment that is at long last happening in this country. Look at the level of inflation and at the level of interest rates. They are the lowest that they have been in 30 years. Look at how this government has set about the task of reducing debt.

speech.para: Instead of merely talking about these issues, as the previous government did for 13 years, this government has actually got in and started to do something. We are starting to get those runs on the board, and the Australian public appreciates and understands that. That is why we are in government and that lot are still in opposition.

talk.start.para: —We won and they lost.

—That is absolutely right. In particular, this legislation that we are debating today is about providing protection for consumers. In addition, this government listened to people and said, `We understand that you have to have relief from these high levels of taxation.' Let us not forget that those opposite are effectively saying to the Australian people, including to all of those people like that man who came to me at Kinglake, `We do not support you getting a tax cut. We want you to continue to work and to work your hours of overtime, but we are not going to reward you for your effort—we are going to penalise you for that.'

speech.para: This government has listened. We are going to provide the relief for individuals. We are also going to provide relief to help small business to thrive. For those 13 years of Labor government, small business was merely in survival mode. They were on their knees. This government is doing everything that it can by providing an economic environment with the lowest interest rates and low inflation—a good environment for investment. This is generating interest and growth in small business, allowing small business to provide those much needed jobs.

Let me turn briefly to some of the details of the legislation we are debating here today. I want to go into some of this detail, emphasising that it is all designed to protect the consumers and to protect those small businesses. This bill amends the Trade Practices Act 1974 by inserting a very important new section, to be known as part VB. This section will deal with price exploitation in relation to a new tax system—the system that hardworking Australians have been crying out for for so long. It specifically provides the ACCC with the power to monitor prices in order to protect consumers from any price exploitation. Im portantly, it will also provide protection for small business from being exploited by any large suppliers. The ACCC will have this authority during the transition period leading up to the implementation of the GST and for a period of two years from the date of implementation.

In this monitoring role the ACCC will have the ability to assess the general effect of the new tax system changes on prices charged by corporations for supplies during this transition period and for that two-year period. It will have the power to require a person to provide the commission in writing with specific information relating to possible exploitation, prices and the setting of prices. The person or company must not fail to provide that information required by the ACCC and neither can that person provide false or misleading information. If it is found that an unreasonably high price has been charged by a corporation or person and that price is not attributable to the supplier's costs or supply and demand conditions, the ACCC will have the power under this legislation to impose penalties of up to $10 million for a company and up to $500,000 for an individual. The ACCC will take action to have these penalties imposed by the Federal Court.

As well as this course of action, the ACCC will have the authority, as an alternative to this Federal Court action, to seek injunctions to restrain conduct that is or could be considered to be exploiting prices. Further, the commission will have the power to accept voluntary undertakings by those individuals or companies who have transgressed. This power already exists for the ACCC in section 87B of the Trade Practices Act, but I mention this power today to further illustrate that the government is determined to ensure that the ACCC has every means at its disposal to monitor any examples of price exploitation and to use appropriate measures to change irresponsible corporate behaviour. This measure, as well as the measure whereby the ACCC will have the power to issue a notice to any corporation where the ACCC believes there has been a breach of the prohibition, represents a range of measures the government is placing at the disposal of the ACCC.

As well as issuing a notice on a corporation that may be the first step in leading towards legal action and penalties, the ACCC can use its discretion by issuing a notice on a corporation as a means of prevention. In such cases the ACCC would need to specify a maximum price that it believes could be charged for specific supplies in specific circumstances and for a specified period. In other words, the ACCC would be putting a company or individual on notice and in effect would be saying that any price charged above the designated maximum price would constitute price exploitation. Both supplier companies and those businesses reliant on the suppliers will be well aware of the position taken by the ACCC because the ACCC will publish guidelines giving details of when a price may be regarded as contravening the prohibition on price exploitation.

As well as all these measures, the ACCC will be required to report within 28 days after the end of each quarter to the government on all actions it has taken under this new part VB provided for in this legislation. This report will be comprehensive and will detail all actions, whether they be issuing notices, imposing penalties or proposed further legal action. Further, this report to government will be made public, and this I believe will act as a further deterrent to any rogue individual or company. It will ensure that those involved in supplying goods and services do not breach the prohibition on price exploitation.

In summary, this legislation honours an election promise to ensure responsible corporate behaviour during the transition period leading up to the introduction of the GST as well as during the period following its introduction. This legislation places both individuals and corporations on notice that this government is simply not prepared to tolerate any exploitation of prices and has introduced a range of measures to ensure that the ACCC has the authority to monitor, prevent and if necessary penalise any price exploitation. There will be some who say that the powers contained in this legislation giving the ACCC extended powers are draconian and too punitive. I certainly do not subscribe to that view. We gave an undertaking to protect Australian consumers and those businesses dependent on others for goods and services, and this legislation delivers on that undertaking. This legislation also delivers on the undertaking given by this government to the Australian people to provide tax relief at an individual level, to provide protection to the consumers and to start rewarding people for their own individual efforts rather than penalising them.

I want to emphasise in closing that the opposition stands starkly opposed to these commitments given by government. What it is standing for is opposition to any forward thinking and opposition to providing relief to average hardworking Australians. It is denying them the opportunity of real reward for their efforts.

talk.start.para: —I had great pleasure in seconding the Labor second reading amendment to A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 . I must say I am somewhat perplexed as to why we are debating this legislation at all if the government is to be believed. I really do question the need for this bill if the government is to be believed. The bill itself gives new powers to the ACCC to police the passing on of savings from indirect tax reductions. You may recall that in the lead-up to the election campaign, Mr Deputy Speaker, every household in Australia received a booklet, courtesy of the taxpayers, from the government setting out its tax proposals. In that booklet it described the position of various types of households. Predictably, it said they would all be better off. The government indicated that the cost of living increases associated with the goods and services tax, a 10 per cent goods and services tax, would be only 1.9 per cent.

speech.para: On the first day of the hearings of the Senate GST inquiry, Treasury officials let the cat out of the bag. They revealed that the true impact of the government's tax package on the cost of living would be 3.1 per cent. The Treasury officials let the cat out of the bag—and what a dirty, smelly animal it was—because they told the Australian people that the inflationary impact of the government's tax package was much greater than the government had told the Australian people in the lead-up to the 3 October election.

The first day of the hearings of the Senate GST inquiry was a bad day for the government and it has not gotten any better. The 3.1 per cent assumes that there is a full and immediate passing on of the savings from the indirect tax reductions, including those from the abolition of the wholesale sales tax, by businesses to consumers. However, a delay in the passing on of the indirect tax reductions—and, of course, there will be a delay; that is why we are here debating this bill, because the government has to acknowledge that there will be a delay—will mean the cost of living increase in the initial years of the tax package, instead of being 3.1 per cent, will be in the range of four to five per cent. The government went to the election saying it would be 1.9 per cent; in reality it will be four to five per cent.

The Prime Minister's modeller of choice, Mr Chris Murphy, told the Senate inquiry on 5 February that Professor Dixon's Monash base case scenario in which he modelled the economic impacts of the tax package was `under the most plausible assumptions'. So what are the assumptions for this base case? The first assumption is no wage response to the cost of living increases associated with the goods and services tax. We have just heard that the true impact on the cost of living is going to be in the range of four to five per cent, not 1.9 per cent. Of course, wage earners will seek to recover some of that cost of living increase through wage rises. This is the only reasonable thing that they can do to protect their living standards and those of their families. So that is an absurd assumption, and Professor Dixon goes on to relax that assumption to do some real world modelling.

The second assumption in this base case is no GST paperwork burden. We have actually heard previous speakers try to tell this House that the paperwork burden from the GST will be smaller than that from the existing wholesale sales tax. What a ludicrous proposition! There are 75,000 businesses in Australia paying the wholesale sales tax. When the GST comes in—if it does pass the Senate, and I hope it does not—there will be 1,500,000 businesses caught in the GST net, bearing the paperwork burden of complying with this tax. So that is going to make things a lot worse in the real world.

The third assumption, which is highly relevant to the discussion here, is this instantaneous passing on to consumers on Saturday, 1 July 2000 of all the cost reductions from the abolition of the wholesale sales tax. As I said, Professor Dixon from Monash, who was commissioned by the inquiry, created that base case to form a basis for modelling the real world scenarios. What did he find? That if in fact wage earners do seek to recover the increased cost of living from the GST in the form of higher wages—which is a reasonable thing to do—there will be up to 100,000 jobs lost as a result of the goods and services tax. Professor Dixon went on to have a look at the situation where there is a delay in the passing-on of indirect tax reductions to consumers. With half of the indirect tax reductions, if the savings are delayed by just one year there will be 15,000 jobs lost.

Yet the Prime Minister's modeller of choice told the Senate GST inquiry that this instantaneous passing-through to consumers of the indirect tax reductions was the most plausible assumption. So what are we going to see? According to the Prime Minister's modeller of choice and the government, on Saturday, 1 July 2000 every business in Australia will have staff working overtime. They will be busily marking prices for new stock to reflect the abolition of the wholesale sales tax on that Saturday. On the same Saturday—1 July 2000—every plumber, every gardener, every repairman and every hairdresser in Australia will have calculated how much wholesale sales tax is embedded in the price of their services and will have deducted that before adding on the cost of the 10 per cent GST to their clients on that Saturday. Who is the Prime Minister's modeller of choice kidding?

Why do we need this bill if Mr Murphy and the government are right? Of course, Mr Murphy contradicts himself in his pre-election paper released on 29 September, at page 5, where he says his model is a long-run model which:

. . . implies that changes in taxes are passed on fully by business. In reality, tax changes may not be passed on fully in the short run, leading to changes in profitability. However, such changes in profitability will affect the pattern of investment until rates of return are ultimately restored to the rates required on world capital markets, so that taxes are passed on fully.

So the Prime Minister's modeller of choice is saying, `Yes, there will be a delay in the passing-on.' This is just another example of the Prime Minister's modeller of choice altering his conclusions to suit the Prime Minister's needs. Between 29 September 1998 and when he appeared before the Senate GST inquiry, he said, `No, the most plausible assumption is instantaneous passing-on on 1 July 2000.' That is quite revealing.

Not even the Prime Minister believes Mr Murphy on this full passing-through. The Prime Minister was in full flight at the South Australian Liberal Party State Council on 15 August 1998 when a series of dorothy dixers were bowled up to him by Liberals. This is how he handled one of the dorothy dixers from someone who said, `Well, you know, of course, there will be price reductions from the abolition of the wholesale sales tax.' The Prime Minister's answer was:

We certainly will. And the point that has to be made again, and again, is that the GST will replace existing taxes. I mean there are many services that will be cheaper. Medical services will be cheaper because they are GST free, and the people who provide them will be able to deduct, get back the taxes paid on their inputs. Same with dental services. The same with child care. Three very critical things where the costs of those services ought to fall. Fall. Not just relatively but in absolute terms ought to fall.
He finished by saying:
And if there is enough competitive pressure that will happen.
Obviously the Prime Minister has doubts about this instantaneous passing-through, as revealed in his answer to a dorothy dix question.

But the Prime Minister's preferred modeller continues to aid and abet the PM in his deception of the Australian people. In his critique of Professor Dixon's work, Mr Murphy downgraded his own estimate of the benefits of the GST package by 40 per cent. How did that happen? He was criticising Professor Dixon for changing the elasticities in his model without advising the people. He described this as `disturbing'. Yet Professor Dixon did in fact write and provide a paper advising of the changes to the elasticities that he made. When Mr Murphy was questioned on how he managed to downgrade his own estimate by 40 per cent from $1 billion to $607 million, he said that he had been talking to the Minerals Council. That is why he changed his own elasticities to produce a result of just 65 cents a week per person from the government's tax package. Mr Murphy did not publish that. He did not mention that. It was only under questioning by Labor senators that it was revealed.

The Prime Minister's modeller of choice did a paper for the Housing Industry Association showing job losses in the housing industry, yet he told the Senate inquiry on 5 February that that was just because sectors such as housing `have paid less than their share of tax in the past'. So he has shafted the housing industry to explain away job losses in that industry. He has shafted his client who commissioned him to do the work.
The next example of changing the story to suit their needs was in tourism. Mr Murphy told Radio National on 8 February this year:

. . . but I would agree with Peter that with respect to overseas tourism, there is a case for zero rating because it is an export. So in principle at least, it should be GST-free along with other exports.
Just six days later he reported to the Senate GST inquiry the opposite conclusion. He said:

Also, while there is debate on the precise value of the price elasticity of demand for tourism exports, everyone agrees that this elasticity is not particularly high. According to the Monash Model it is 3, while according to MM303 it is 2. Using these values in the above formula, gives optimal tax rates for tourism exports of 50 per cent for the Monash Model and 100 per cent for MM303.
The latter being Mr Murphy's model.

These optimal rates are well in excess of a GST of 10 per cent. This means that making inbound tourist packages GST-free, instead of taxing them at a rate of 10 per cent, would be a step in the wrong direction from the viewpoint of maximising economic efficiency.

So here we have the Prime Minister's modeller of choice again changing his story to suit the circumstances. He now believes that the optimal policy is to apply 100 per cent tax to tourism, but 10 per cent will do for starters. The tourism industry should be very worried about what the Prime Minister's preferred modeller is advising him.

In his critique of Professor Dixon's report to the Senate GST inquiry Mr Murphy, on page 24, chastises Professor Dixon for daring to suggest that there will be any losers at all from the government's tax package. He says:
Chart 3.9 of the Monash Report adopts the misplaced populist notion that there are winners and losers from ANTS.

So here we have Mr Murphy falling over himself again to support the Prime Minister's absurd claim that apart from tax cheats everyone is a winner from the tax package. This is despite the fact that Mr Murphy himself has done modelling that completely refutes his own claim.
He refers to job losses in the housing industry in his evidence on 5 February, where he said:
Sectors such as housing which have paid less than their share of tax in the past may experience lower levels of employment, other sectors exactly offsetting higher levels of employment.

In secret advice to Treasury before the tax package was released, he reported job losses in 12 out of 18 industry sectors. In the evidence he provided to the Senate GST inquiry he said that there would be job losses in Queensland, Tasmania and the ACT. No wonder this man is the Prime Minister's modeller of choice. On the one hand he says it is ridiculous for Professor Dixon to assert that there would be any losers, and then he contradicts himself by pointing to thousands of losers from the government's tax package. It is no wonder that the coalition senators insisted that Mr Murphy do the critique of Professor Dixon's work.

Flying in the face of Mr Murphy's `most plausible assumption' that every cent of saving from abolishing the wholesale sales tax will flow on to consumers on Saturday, 1 July, was a litany of evidence from the business community and consumer groups that businesses will not behave in this accommodating manner. This includes evidence from the ACCC itself, which is the subject of this legislation, which could not identify one industry that was perfectly competitive but could identify plenty of industries that had engaged in anticompetitive conduct. That is why the legislation is necessary.

But the legislation is manifestly inadequate. It provides just $27 million over three years of extra funding for the role of the ACCC in ensuring that indirect tax reductions are passed on to consumers. The legislation provides only 40 extra staff who would have 4.1 seconds a week to monitor the pricing behaviour of each business. I can see exactly what is going to happen with their staff. The phone call to each business will go something like this: `Hello, I'm from the ACCC. Goodbye.' I have timed that; it takes about 4.1 seconds. So they will be ringing up every business in Australia saying, `Hello, I'm from the ACCC. Goodbye.'

That is the extent of the government's commitment to enforcing the savings from the indirect tax reductions being passed on to consumers. Interestingly, the bill does not give the ACCC more power in relation to bank taxes, stamp duties and diesel fuel. We have seen the anti-competitive behaviour of the banks. The Prime Minister was asked about the four-pillars policy and he said, `Oh well, we do not know if we could move on that because we are waiting for red-hot competition.' The Prime Minister knows that there is nothing like red-hot competition in bank behaviour.

This bill exposes the government's fraudulent claims in its $19 million GST propaganda campaign leading up to the election on 3 October that the cost of living increase from a 10 per cent GST will be only 1.9 per cent and that, as a consequence, everyone will be a winner from the tax package. Interestingly, the bill relates to the wholesale sales tax. We have heard the Treasurer and the Prime Minister say that the wholesale sales tax system is broken. Last night, Access Economics released a document, which I have here. It shows wholesale sales tax revenue projections as a proportion of GDP.

That document projects that, for the entire wholesale sales tax system, including cars, over a 10-year period there might be an erosion of $1.1 billion, or $100 million a year. If we take out cars and look at the balance of the wholesale sales tax system, the erosion would be in the order of less than $500 million in total, or less than $50 million a year. What are we getting? We are getting a $32 billion GST sledgehammer to crack a $100 million nut. Interestingly, Access Economics did not do any projections of the revenue raising capacity of the proposed GST system. That is a stunning omission from my point of view.

Someone else has done that work—Professor Dixon. The other night, I sought leave to have Professor Dixon's graphs incorporated in Hansard. I was unsuccessful on that occasion. The minister said that the reason why he did not agree was that the legislation we were debating was not strictly about the goods and services tax. This legislation today is strictly and absolutely about the goods and services tax, so I seek leave to incorporate in Hansard Professor Dixon's graphs entitled `Forecasts: no change indirect tax rates (percentage growth rates)' and `Forecasts: tax package adopted (percentage growth rates)'. They are the same graphs that I showed the minister the other night. They were censored then and I think it only reasonable that they be incorporated this time.
Leave granted.
The graphs read as follows—

talk.start.para: —We are left in a position where we have a job destroying GST that the Prime Minister told the Australian people would produce an increase in the cost of living of 1.9 per cent. He told them that before the election. Treasury officials have now admitted that, even with the immediate passing on of all those indirect tax reductions, the inflationary impact will be 3.1 per cent. If any delay occurs in that passing-on, the impact will be four per cent to five per cent, in which case, as Professor Dixon advised the Senate GST inquiry, we are looking at massive job losses from the proposed goods and services tax. We should reject the goods and services tax. An inquiry report is coming out today and I am sure that it will make fascinating reading because the government has completely failed to make its case. (Time expired)

—I am pleased to talk on the A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 . The question I am probably asked most about tax reform implementation—and have been asked as far back as the 1998 campaign—is, `How are you going to make them pass on the savings?' `Them' invariably refers to the three major supermarket chains in particular and business in general. I am not being at all disparaging of business—although I do have a very strong view on the centralisation of ownership of supermarkets, but that is not the question we are looking at here today. We are simply stating the fears of ordinary people as they express them to their members of parliament.

speech.para: Naturally, I did what I could to explain how the government would achieve what it desired. Hence, I am delighted to see this bill introduced. The integrity of the GST system could well depend on the effectiveness of this scheme. However, I do not think it is reasonable, as the member for Rankin said, that because $27 million is being spent that necessarily reduces it to dividing that by every business in Australia. Obviously, other factors will determine whether or not there are complaints.

Not every business in Australia is shonky. A lot of businesses will act on a sectoral basis rather than on an individual basis and, if it is found that $27 million is not enough, then no doubt we will do something about it. But it is true to say that people are worried and concerned that, although the tax reform package sounds good in theory, the flow-on of price reductions could be diverted during the transitional period by businesses acting to distort the benefits, and thus increase their profits. We have heard that the figure of 1.9 per cent is the likely increase. We also had evidence from Treasury that it could be as low as 1.8 per cent.

In this legislation, we are putting the concerns of ordinary Australians to rest. We are going to make sure that no business or entity can profiteer at the expense of the rest of the community. It is about time a government came along that was prepared to do more than just put measures in place and expect the market to act fairly. While most people in the market act fairly and most people react to competition, I recognise that there are some who will not. It raises the question of just how moral the market really is. I may be cynical, but neither I nor the government is naive enough to think that all the participants in the market will act in the best interests of consumers in my electorate or, more broadly, across Australia.

That is where the Labor Party went wrong with its reform program in previous parliaments when it was in power. It caused a lot of hurt and damage in the bush. Regional and rural Australia is still hurting from many of its policies. In fact, the ALP itself actually participated in the system of hurt when the Keating government raised sales taxes by one per cent across the board for all wholesale sales taxes, not once but twice, during its 1993-96 term of office, to say nothing of the five per cent loaded onto cars.

Let me remind the member for Rankin—and I am sorry he is not here to hear this—that there was no one-off compensation for pensioners at that time. There was no compensation for low income earners. There was no assistance for people whose car prices went up by five per cent. Those people, I might add, were already being hit by increased excise. As we know, the same Labor government increased excise by two per cent on leaded petrol, supposedly for environmental purposes, but there was not a person in Australia who did not believe that that was just a revenue raising matter. In fact, when the increase was first introduced it was 5c a litre, but the Labor government backbench almost revolted on the issue and that is why it was brought back to 2c a litre.

We are talking about pensioners and low income earners and, when you think about it, they were the people who had the cars that used leaded fuel. There was no one-off compensation for the pensioners in that package. There was no one-off compensation for the low income earners. The people who were most affected were those who were least able to buy the new cars. So don't let us have all this pious nonsense that you are concerned about the low income earners and the pensioners. When you were in office, your own track record does not bear examination.

I believe the new tax system will impact in a much fairer way on consumers if there is a carrot and stick system adopted. The carrots for business are the inherent benefits of the new scheme which will cut red tape and taxes on production and create a level playing field for Australian business, primary producers and exporters, while the stick is the power and resources that the bill gives to the ACCC to discipline exploiters and rorters.

We promised to protect the community at large from unprincipled business operators that might seek to engage in profiteering and exploitation during the transitional period of the new tax scheme. This government has always taken its duty of care for Australian people seriously, and this matter will not be any exception.

We recognise that the concerns of people are legitimate. This is a very complex and muddied area, and we do not want to degenerate into the populist scaremongering that occurs when some new measure is introduced to the Australian community. It is very interesting that the member for Werriwa talked about the `scab-lifting' of the ALP. It refuses at times to look at these things in a positive way, but lifts the scab on its own performance in past eras. I repeat: we recognise that the concerns that people have are legitimate, and we intend to ensure that the weak are protected from the strong.

Treasury's economic modelling of the CPI effect on the removal of 10 indirect taxes and the introduction of the GST assumes that all participants in the chain will pass on the savings on their costs and prices. In order to arrest the concerns that this will not be done, the ACCC will have sweeping new powers vested in it and significant additional resources to draw on during the transitional period of the three years from July 1999 to July 2002. It is not a tame measure, as the member for Rankin has suggested. Businesses will face the prospect of public exposure and severe financial penalties of up to $10 million for corporations and $500,000 for individuals if they use the transitional period as a cover for taking advantage of customers.

The best way for business to avoid public exposure in the Treasurer's foreshadowed quarterly reports and the relegation to `shame files', with a consequent nasty hit on the hip pocket, is, of course, to do the right thing. It is the only way to treat them. The ACCC will name names to ensure that unscrupulous operators receive the maximum negative publicity for their actions. Here is where the media organisations, whether they be national, metropolitan or provincial, can play a crucial role in the success of the new tax reform regime and, at the same time, do an invaluable service to their readers, watchers and listeners. There would be nothing worse for businesses in provincial centres like Bundaberg, Gladstone and Rockhampton and, indeed, in the smaller towns in and around my electorate than to be publicly named and shamed by the local media in such a way.

I would envisage that newspapers could run columns such as `GST watch'. Talkback radio programs could have a GST watch segment. The local television could carry regular GST enforcement items in their news bulletins. The media have generally played a very negative role in this whole debate because it is in their nature to be rather reactionary. In this particular instance, they could take a positive proactive role and see that the measures that the government and the ACCC will implement are enforced to the full. However, the consumer interest and feature pages contain advice on investment and money management and have provided excellent services of good information for people thirsting for real explanations, and I applaud their efforts in this field. I therefore ask them that, with columns such as `GST watch', they carry out a similar activity.

Having said that, this is not to be a Spanish Inquisition. We recognise that many factors affect prices and any genuine price increases will not be prosecuted, although there will be an onus of proof on the various retailers and businesses to demonstrate that the increase is not exploitative and is a reflection of a genuine increase in costs. The ACCC will set guidelines about when prices may be regarded as exploitation. The methods that will be particularly harmful to those who want to exploit this period of transition are these: failing to reduce the price of an item on which the amount of tax falls because the GST payable is less than the total wholesale price previously paid in respect of that item, and increasing the price of an item by more than the actual price effect of the GST on that item.

The ACCC will also have the power to prosecute and seek court injunctions or accept voluntary undertakings in relation to the price settings. That is quite an extreme power, and I hope it is exercised. It goes further because the ACCC will also be empowered to issue a notice to a business specifying the maximum that may be charged for the supply of a particular product. This will act as a warning to a business that, if it charges a price in excess of the maximum, it will be engaging in exploitation. That is very important because it means the ACCC can be proactive and not simply reactive.

I urge the states and territories to apply the new tax system price exploitation code outlined in the bill to their own legislation as soon as possible and without any fiddling at the margins. Perhaps a Labor government might be tempted to have a go at this just to muddy the waters of the GST scheme, although I hope that will not be the case, but I believe if any state government did that for purely exploitative political purposes they would be judged very harshly by their citizens.

In conclusion, I am sure all members will agree that there are substantial penalties and sanctions outlined in the bill. The powers this bill will vest in the ACCC are a first for Australia. We are indeed handing them a very heavy stick to wield, and I am sure that this will place in the minds of people in my electorate and in other parts of Australia the sort of confidence they need to embark on a very interesting period in Australia's political history, one which I think will make us world competitive. It will go a long way to job creation. There is no stronger evidence than this bill of the government's absolute and resolute determination that all Australians share in the full benefits of this revolutionary—and, we trust, very positive—tax system for the Australian people.

talk.start.para: —The A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 before us today is part of the complex policy and administrative architecture underpinning the government's proposed 10 per cent consumption tax. The problem we have before us is that both the policy and the associated administrative arrangements are fundamentally flawed.

speech.para: The policy logic does not exist, particularly once we remove ourselves from the hoopla of the post-election triumphalism of those opposite and soberly subject the proposition to rational analysis in the cold light of day. Because the policy logic does not exist, because there is no compelling macro-economic rationale for this entire consumption tax enterprise, because there is no persuasive evidence that the tax package will result in greater economic growth than otherwise would be the case, because there is no persuasive evidence that this package will result in more jobs and less unemployment, and because there is no evidence that the existing tax structure is incapable of delivering sufficient public finance for the Commonwealth to meet its future needs, it follows that any administrative or institutional arrangements built on so unstable a policy foundation will also be fundamentally flawed.

That is what we have before us today in this piece of legislation to amend the Trade Practices Act. So what precisely are we looking at? It is based on the most transparent of logical contradictions. On the one hand, the economic and public finance assumptions of the entire package are further predicated on the assumption there will be both 100 per cent compliance by business and 100 per cent pass-through to consumers. On the other hand, the proposed augmentation of the ACCC contained in this bill rests on the assumption that there is going to be a truckload of people out there whose concept of a pass through will be somewhat less than 100 per cent.
In fact, before the ongoing Senate inquiry into the GST, we have seen the delightfully candid admission from no less than the NFF that:
Farmers are no different to any other businessmen. If there is a possibility that they can claim some profits in the system, then no doubt they will.
Even the head of the Treasury task force, Dr Ken Henry, when asked whether some of the WST reduction would be consumed as profit, said:
I am not saying that will not happen.
So, as a consequence, what we have before us in this bill is a classic case of a bob each way bet that is destined to fail.

So in this brave new world of the all-singing and all-dancing GST, what is the ACCC now supposed to do? It is supposed to determine guidelines on the circumstances under which prices may be deemed to be too high. It is supposed to monitor prices. It also is supposed to have the power now to determine a maximum price. It has the power to determine corporate breaches of price exploitation. It has a compulsion power for corporations to produce documents to substantiate prices. It has the power to impose injunctions, it has the power to impose fines and, in the officers' spare time, during the afternoon tea-break, they are supposed also to monitor the general impact of the GST, whatever that happens to mean. Furthermore, in terms of constitutional reach, we add a price exploitation code for adoption by the states, with corporations being governed by the Commonwealth act, sole traders and partnerships by the states.

So what are the problems with all this? The first and most basic problem is that of resources. The ACCC is to be granted the princely addition of 40 further staff, the princely additional budget of $27 million over three years and, with that amount of extra staff and with that amount of extra money, Felsy and the competition coppers out there on Northbourne Avenue are going to take out their binoculars, observe the economy at large—the 1.4 million businesses subject to its scrutiny. If you think about it, with about 12 million adult consumers in this country, each, say, on average engaging in 10 economic transactions a day, they would be making something like 120 million economic transactions each day. Felsy and the boys out there on Northbourne Avenue, the extra 40 of them, are going to keep their eyes on all of that.

I suggest that this is nothing more than the most extraordinary public relations exercise. The entire Fels hit squad would fit into a single ACTION bus, yet their charge is to somehow ensure, through the ACCC, that full pass-through occurs for the benefit of consumers. The only benefit that I can conceive of from this legislation, in terms of the proposed additional resource to the ACCC, is that it would be probably the first time since 1996 that there would be some addition to one branch of the Commonwealth Public Service here in Canberra, particularly since the reign of Max the Axe.

A second problem arises with this whole proposition, in terms of the scope of the ACCC. We read that it covers the WST and the GST only. It does not cover the Diesel Fuel Credit Scheme, bank taxes and stamp duty. On that basis alone, irrespective of how it performed its functions in relation to the WST and the GST, it could not achieve 100 per cent pass- through. That is simply a palpable nonsense. The resources are inadequate, even to achieve this narrow brief, let alone a broad one, were it to be given it.

Third, we have the time line—three years—one year before the full operational effect of the tax package and two years after. Let us examine the evidence of the Prime Minister's economic modeller of choice, Chris Murphy. He has said that we will not see the full impact of the total tax package for some seven years, yet these powers extended to the ACCC disappear into the sand in three years time. There is nothing in the documentation provided to suggest that there is any likelihood that these powers, or these minuscule resources, would then be extended.

One can assume that the logic underpinning what the government has in mind here is that, somehow, at about that three-year point, after we have picked up a few reports here and there, after the 40 competition coppers in the ACTION bus actually bust a few people around the country then, at that point, Adam Smith and the invisible hand kick in, market forces and competition take over and we shake any possible corruption out of the system. I think that is not credible.

The fourth problem that is evident in this piece of legislation relates to its methodology. I just take one example, the task of formulating guidelines on price exploitation. I would ask experts in this field, including advisers in the box, how you would go about disaggregating normal market changes in supply and demand, supplier costs and so on, from a plain old rort. It is a logical impossibility.

You have a related problem of timing. At the point at which this package is introduced and becomes operational, in July 2000, it is possible that you can make a calculation as to what constituted a cost structure to a business prior to that date and what constituted its cost structure just after that date. But what happens two or three months down the track? It becomes very difficult on any comparative basis to analyse what other factors may have entered into the cost calculus of a firm. They could always claim, for example, that the overall supply and demand situation within their business had changed. I again come back to the fundamental methodological flaw and the flick pass to the ACCC to somehow magically develop these guidelines on price exploitation. I await with eagerness their publication.

The fifth problem that arises from this legislation, dare I say it, is that of ideology. Here we have a government made up of free marketeers not really believing in what Ronnie Reagan used to call the magic of the market, not really believing that Adam Smith, after all, had got it right, not believing that the invisible hand was doing its task—thinking, in fact, that the invisible hand might be just a bit too invisible—and instead constructing for themselves a price fixing machinery that would make the first ministry of machine building in the old Soviet Union quite proud. The intellectual contradictions of all this are breathtaking. On the one hand, bob's your uncle, competition is okay; on the other, competition is going to fail as will, in step, the price regulators.

So what do we do? We set up, on paper at least, something akin to an instrument of Soviet pricing policy from the new economic period then disembowel it by not giving it any resources. This is not policy, it is a public relations exercise—and the officials in the advisers box probably know it—like the multimillion dollar public relations exercise that we had prior to the last election. This ACCC exercise is a comparable stunt of the first order. The only benefit is, as I said before, that it will possibly provide a slight jag up in public sector employment in the ACT.

The bottom line is that there will not be anything like a 100 per cent pass-through from this tax package. This is the evidence of the expert witnesses. It is also clear from the inability of this legislation to structure, empower or resource the ACCC to perform this function. And, because this is so, because there is less than a 100 per cent pass-through, a raft of macro-economic consequences flow from it.

The first impact is inflation. The inflation figures associated with the debate on this entire tax package are bouncing all over the place. We have Chris Murphy's 0.9 per cent. We have the tax package: 1.9 per cent—long run effects, but not until 2001 when the package is implemented. Then we had a bit of fessing up during the Senate inquiry and it is rounded up to 3.1 per cent. If you aggregate the rest of the evidence before the Senate inquiry, suddenly 0.9 per cent lurches from four to five per cent. What is the impact of all this? Apart from the obvious problem of compensation for low income earners, the real problem is its capacity to engender a wages break-out.

This leads to the second impact—the macro-economic impact of this package on jobs. Professor Dixon, who gave evidence to the Senate inquiry, has provided us with a range of employment scenarios, the most optimistic of which assumes that there will be a short run addition of 30,000 jobs, assuming the most benign of economic circumstances, and the most benign of labour market circumstances in particular. At the other end of the spectrum, he says the nation could lose 100,000 jobs in the short term under an alternative scenario—a not unreasonable alternative scenario given the statement of the trade unions, in particular, that they will be seeking wages claims in order to make up for the bracket creep impact on their members, not to mention the price surge which will accompany the implementation of this package. So, on jobs, the GST—as Professor Dixon so eloquently summed it up—is a job destroyer.

The third impact goes to economic growth. The tax package produced in the election period stated almost ex cathedra—as one of the Borgia popes would have done—that it would be good for growth. We searched for the data to substantiate that. Treasury—again, before the Senate inquiry—admitted they had done no modelling of the growth impact of the package. Through the Senate inquiry it was also admitted that the so-called `growth dividend' referred to by the government publicly is based on guesswork. Professor Dixon, in his work for the Senate inquiry, found:

The government's proposed tax changes will have little impact on Australia's long-run macroeconomic performance . . . any modest impact on growth would be as a result of fiscal stimulus, not the consumption tax.

I find it astounding that we could be contemplating a change of this order of magnitude, the largest single change in the taxation arrangements of the Commonwealth since the war, when those charged with the professional responsibility for predicting its impact on the economy in terms of growth have not done that work. As an Australian community we are being asked to buy a pig in a poke: `Just trust us. It'll all be okay in the morning.'

The fourth impact is the underlying assumption—the one that we are harangued with on a daily basis by the Treasurer opposite—that the existing taxation system is broken. Again, I ask the humble and empirical question: where is the evidence? Treasury has not provided us with any. Treasury said before the Senate inquiry that they had done no such modelling in terms of the current taxation system's capacity to deliver sufficient revenue for the future to fund Australia's expenditure responsibilities. Again, we have to turn to Professor Dixon to do the work. Professor Dixon said:

The tax package implies that a major change in indirect taxation is necessary because without increases in tax rates the present array of indirect taxes will raise insufficient revenue in relation to Australia's future public sector requirements. However the tax package includes no explicit forecasts. We find no evidence to support the tax package's proposition.
As with growth, as with the other key macro-economic factors involved in this debate, we are asked to take this statement that the existing tax system is broken on blind faith.

Where is the overwhelming empirical case that the nation needs this package? We turn to long-term economic welfare. As with everything else in this debate, the evidence—to the extent that it exists—is bouncing around like a yoyo. Chris Murphy, the Prime Minister's economic modeller of choice, said last September that the economic welfare effect would be $850 million. In December that number had been rounded up to $1 billion. But—surprise, surprise!—in February the number had collapsed to $600 million. However, the point is primarily this: the $600 million represents 0.2 per cent of GDP. It raises the fundamental question: if that is the overall economic welfare gain for the people of Australia, why is this exercise worth undertaking in the first place? So, if it fails on all the fundamental tests—if it fails on inflation, if it fails on employment, if it fails on growth, if it fails on living standards—why are we doing it?

I think there are two reasons we are doing it. The first is a political accident. We all remember the nursing homes fiasco. We had an agenda-less government drifting nowhere, overcome with political problems of its own making, and suddenly out of the blue, out of right field rather than left field, we had the consumption tax, the tax that Australia would never have. Members of the government were, I am sure, as surprised as members of the opposition at that stage when it suddenly reappeared on the agenda.

The second reason, however, if there is a logical reason underpinning why this tax has been brought into the Australian policy debate, is that it is a redistribution tax. It is a tax which redistributes Australian wealth from poorer people to richer people. There is a great similarity between the policy postures of our Treasurer, Peter Costello, and the minister for workplace relations, Peter Reith—P1 and P2. P1 is about maximising inequality of the tax system. P2 is about maximising inequality of the wages system.

The impact of all this on the Australian community will be profound. When this package was announced, the Treasurer was found to be missing in action. However, once the election had been won, he became its champion. I suspect it is part and parcel of the ongoing leadership battle between P1 and P2. The victims, however, are the citizens of Australia. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am delighted to assist in this debate on the A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 and to add my support for the new system to ensure that the introduction of the government's tax reform measures is carried out in an equitable and sensible way. The amendment to the Trade Practices Act will ensure that those people who are using the goods and services tax, traders and proprietary companies, will do it in a fair and equitable manner, and it will ensure proper monitoring.

speech.para: Whilst the previous speaker was attacking the tax reform proposals of the government, let me assure him that this measure will ensure that they will be fair and that they will be monitored. In the case of New Zealand, where I had a look at the introduction of that new system, people assured me that the introduction of the goods and services tax had worked well. They wondered why there was a debate back in 1992-93 here in Australia, because they saw the system working very well. We found no evidence in New Zealand that there was any exploitation in the changeover from the former system to the new system of a GST.

This amendment will ensure that all those people who have to implement the new system over the two-year period that is referred to in the bill will be forced to do the right thing. There will be $27 million allocated to cover this period and there will be considerable penalties for those people who do not implement the new reformed taxation system: $10 million for a corporate body and up to $500,000 for a person other than a corporate body if it can be proved that they had misrepresented the GST and its implementation, especially in their pricing mechanism.

From this debate on the introduction of the new tax system—which is how those of us on this side of the House like to refer to it rather than as a GST—we can see that the government have done everything possible to prepare the ground to make sure that the transition from the current system to the new system will be done in a manner that Australians will understand, to make sure that Australians act in a fair manner and that traders and shopkeepers obey the new regime.

The minister at the table would be aware of the Trade Practices Act in relation to other activities in Australia, as he readily acknowledges the case of the newsagents and other people who have enjoyed certain protection. I am confident that the Senate will eventually agree to the introduction of the new system, especially when they see this part of the program which will ensure the smooth transition. It has always been part of their argument—that, when we move from the current arrangements of wholesale sales tax to a new set of arrangements where a new GST will be applied to a number of goods which did not have a tax on them, there was always the possibility that some unscrupulous traders might add more than the 10 per cent in their pricing mechanisms.

The government is quite confident that this measure will assist in the transition and that after that there will be a competitive pressure on people to provide a price that includes the GST, which has happened in every other nation around the world. I notice that the opposition spokesman at the table is showing some scepticism about that. But he has travelled the world and he understands that these indirect tax mechanisms have worked well and the marketplace over time has taken them into account in setting the price.

I suggest that this bill will be part of the government's total position in the transition, making sure that the new tax regime is bedded down and comes into effect, especially in view of the experience of New Zealand, of Europe, and of other nations which have encountered the transitionary arrangements. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to speak in this debate on A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 and to speak about the GST. I am also pleased to be supporting the opposition amendments before the House today. This is quite extraordinary legislation. The big question that has to be asked is: why are we having this debate at all? The GST inquiry, in all its hearings so far, has failed to provide any evidence of the benefits of this new tax for Australia in terms of new job creation, inflationary impact and economic growth, so we have to ask ourselves why we would go through this debate to introduce a new tax on everything we buy and everything we do.

speech.para: The reason is that this is an ideologically motivated tax. For the last 20 years, John Howard and the conservatives opposite have raved about two issues: the introduction of a broad based consumption tax, and the second obsession is about labour market deregulation, the cutting of wages and the lowering of living standards. We have seen evidence of this today and I am sure we will hear further debate. There is no doubt that there is a link between the two. There is no doubt that the implementation of the GST will lead to a redistribution of wealth away from those who can least afford it and will lead to the regressive reform which the GST represents.

Why is it that this government has failed to score a single hit with the inquiry? It has had its own modellers appear before the GST inquiry, and still there has not been one day of positive news. This bill is almost a declaration of defeat—before the GST is even implemented. On the one hand, you have a government introducing a new tax, and, at the same time, it is introducing legislation, saying, `We need to amend the Trade Practices Act because we believe—we know—that there will be attempts by unscrupulous corporations and individuals to profiteer. This is a one-off opportunity for those people to make a profit at the expense of ordinary consumers.'

This bill is necessary because the government's plans for tax reform are so flawed that damage control is needed even before the legislation is put in place. This is why the opposition is not objecting to the basic premise of this legislation. The amendments we have moved today are over issues such as resources. If you accept that there are going to be attempts to rort the system, you then have to accept that there is an obligation to properly resource the ACCC to ensure that the legislation is not just a public relations exercise. Frankly, 40 extra staff at the ACCC is just a farce, and the government knows that is the case.

The government does not know what the impact of the GST will be in a whole range of areas—in particular in the housing sector, which I want to address this morning. If you want hard proof of this lack of research, you only have to look at the Hansard of the GST inquiry from 2 February. Senator Chris Evans asked:
What about the flow on to the cost of rents? Has the department done any work on that?
The head of the housing section of the family and community services department, Dr Ogborn, said:
We have not done any modelling of the impact of the GST.
Senator Chris Evans said:
What about the flow on to public housing?
The answer from Dr Ogborn:
Again, we have not done any work.

That is the problem with this legislation, and that is the problem with the GST. We are asked as an article of faith to believe that this nirvana of a GST is going to somehow fix problems, but when we ask for the evidence and the research, we are told, `Well, we haven't done any work. We haven't done any modelling. Whether it be on inflationary impact, whether it be on the creation of jobs, whether it be on economic growth, we haven't done any modelling.'

I now want to take the House through the details of how this will impact on a couple of areas. One is in the area of private rentals. The GST will apply right across the board. It will apply to new home building, land development, renovations, additions, repairs and maintenance. Right across the board, the GST will be applicable. If you are buying a new home, the Housing Industry Association has estimated there will be at least a $400 increase in house and land packages as a result of this GST. So, if you are buying a house, you will be hit.

Secondly, if you are a renter, the 2.3 per cent estimated increase in private rentals relies again on articles of faith. For all those people in the private rental market who are faced with one-off rent increases, particularly in areas like Sydney and Melbourne, we all know what will occur. Renters will be told, `We have to increase your rent by 10 per cent because that's the fact of the GST.' It is extraordinary to believe that there will be a limit of 2.3 per cent. I do not believe that that will be the case.

One of the factors that occurs with rents is that, when they go up, there is often a rounding up as well. As has been pointed out by the National Association of Tenants Organisations, chances are that people will not put their rents up by $7.80; they will choose a figure like $10. Again, you will have a one-off gain with no watchdog except for the ACCC, which will have to look after every facet of economic activity in this country. We are going to have 40 people overseeing this process. Once again, I think that is extraordinarily inadequate.

The shadow minister, Wayne Swan, has very effectively raised the issue of individuals who are forced to live long term in caravan parks, mobile homes and in what would not normally be classified as short-term accommodation. The minister is confused about this. When the minister was asked a question, he went on about tourists not being affected, but there is a minimum of 100,000 people living in these sorts of housing. The Minister for Community Services—
Mr Hockey interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Financial Services and Regulation dissociates himself from his colleague, and I do not blame him. If he had performed as badly in question time as that particular minister, then he would not last long on the frontbench. He does not benefit from the Queensland positive discrimination program, which is the only possible justification for that minister staying on the frontbench.

—Madam Deputy Speaker, I rise on a point of order. I think the member for Grayndler is straying well away from the bill before the House, and I ask you to please bring him back to the substance of the bill.
—The member for Grayndler, you have digressed. Please come back to the subject.

—Thank you, Madam Deputy Speaker, I certainly will. I was talking about the issue that the government does not want to talk about—the effect of the GST on people who live in mobile homes, caravan parks and those forms of accommodation. We have had before the Senate committee some quite extraordinary debates. Questions have been asked, as a result of which we find that there is a two-tiered system. The GST will apply fully to those people for the first 27 days they are in that accommodation. After 27 days, it will apply at the five per cent rate. That shows the sorts of difficulties which will come up when the GST is fully applied at that time and not half applied. It relies upon an article of faith. The minister himself is confused about the impact on the housing sector, which ensures that consumers will suffer even more.

speech.para: This legislation highlights that the government must know that their figure of 1.9 per cent inflation is a gross underestimation. The reason why this legislation is being introduced is that they simply do not know what the inflationary impact will be, because it relies upon an article of faith. There are two sides to the inflationary impact. Firstly, it relies upon people who do not have to charge the full 10 per cent GST on items to not charge it. Secondly, it relies upon the fact that some people will charge more than 10 per cent GST—they will round up—and therefore have an inflationary impact. Thirdly, it relies upon those taxes which will go down as a result of the government's tax package being passed on to the consumer: for example, bank taxes such as BAD—a 100 per cent flowthrough. For those people who have looked at bank charges over recent years, I think there is a great deal of scepticism out there about the timelags and about whether those reductions in prices will flow through.

To conclude my speech before the House this afternoon, I want to say that if the government was fair dinkum about this legislation—if it was something other than simply a public relations exercise—it would be adequately resourcing it. It would be fair dinkum about it. But once again we have a half-baked scheme to try to rescue a package which has been half thought up, in which there are no projections on jobs, no projections on economic growth and no projections on inflationary impact.
