No wonder the Treasurer wants to get the GST inquiry out of the way and wants quick votes on this tax package—because the greater the examination of this tax package, the more the flaws and the impact on individual consumers are exposed and the more this government has to concede defeat on this legislation. I urge the House to give full consideration to this bill. We will certainly continue to pursue through the GST inquiry all these questions, and we will continue to express our concern about the impact of this unfair `greed and suffering tax'.

talk.start.para: —I would like to summarise the debate and respond to the amendment moved by the member for Hotham. Anyone who listened to this entire debate could not help but be confused about the position of the Labor Party on this bill. On the one hand, some members of the opposition questioned why we needed to have this bill, given the large amount of competition in many consumer services related areas, and, on the other hand, some members of the opposition said it was not going far enough. This bill puts in place procedures that can clamp down on any attempts at price exploitation during the three-year transitional period of the introduction of the new tax system.

speech.para: I remind the House that prosecutions for breaches of the prohibition on price exploitation will be taken by the ACCC in the Federal Court with penalties of up to $10 million for corporates and $500,000 for a person other than a corporate. So the fines are significant. But, as with the current taxation system, the most significant prices surveillance resource that our nation has is the consumers. Consumers are currently the price monitors out there. It begs the question: if there is to be this huge attempt to gain a windfall by some corporates or individuals during the transitional period of the GST, why don't corporates and individuals do that now? Why don't they exploit consumers now? The answer is: competition. Competition is about consumer sovereignty. It is about giving consumers choice and giving them the opportunity to shop around for their goods.

Some people have had the gall to suggest that people in country towns may be disadvantaged because they have only got one supplier. Well, that one supplier would be ripping them off now under the current taxation arrangements. If that supplier is involved in exploitative conduct, then we urge consumers to contact the ACCC so that they can move forward to prosecute that supplier. As I said, in the case of corporates that is up to $10 million and in the case of individuals that is up to $500,000.

The amendment moved by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition focuses on everything but consumers. Not once in the amendment put forward by the Deputy Leader of the Opposition is there reference to consumers. There is nothing about consumer protection, nothing about enhancement of consumer sovereignty; it is just the same old bile and political rhetoric that we are hearing at the moment from a policy dysfunctional Labor Party.

Even though no part of the amendment moved by the Labor Party deals with the substance of the bill, I will address the three key points that it refers to. The first one is: is the GST job destroying? The same old rickety mantra that they used unsuccessfully in the last election they choose to repeat in the amendment before the House. My response is simple: look at the facts. Whatever model you use, every model depends on the inputs. If you put garbage into a modelling machine, garbage will come out. If you put facts into a modelling machine, facts will come out.

Professor Peter Dixon pointed out in relation to jobs that employment will be stimulated in the short run by about 30,000 jobs. This was supported by Access Economics, which has the unemployment rate falling 0.9 of one percentage point in 2000-01, while Chris Murphy's Econtech has it falling by 0.6 of a percentage point. Access Economics in their December 1998 AEM forecast report say:
The good news is that the tax cuts sweetening the GST are expected to stimulate renewed job growth, perhaps sending unemployment down to seven per cent in 2001.
They further state:
In the long run, the impact of the tax package raises national output by 2.5 per cent and there is an additional 190,000 jobs.

That is our response to point (1). In point (2) the opposition says that we are not spending enough. We are increasing the ACCC's budget by 25 per cent. That is $27 million over three years. They will be employing 40 supervisors. At the end of the day, as the general manager of the ACCC pointed out to the Senate, there are 10 to 12 million prices surveillance individuals and they are the consumers of Australia.

We believe that the competitive pressures that result in consumer sovereignty are going to deliver a fair passing-on of the benefits of the tax package. An important part of the ACCC's role under this bill is to educate the public and inform the public about the guidelines which, under proposed section 75AV, will be used to advise consumers about how much prices should change as a result of the introduction of the new tax system. So not only are we saying to consumers that they have sovereignty and choice in this but also we are giving them a guide as to what the prices should be so that they have something to measure and compare prices at the local grocery store or the work done by the plumber with. They actually have greater power over the supplier of goods than ever before because we are providing them with the information, the recommended prices.

I am advised that the ACCC has already said that it will be relying on the public to report examples where price changes are not consistent with the tax changes. That is a basis upon which we will be supporting the current arrangements.

The third point relates to CPI modelling. I come back to the point I made earlier: the opposition has chosen to put garbage into their modelling machines and, predictably, they are getting garbage out. The government stands by its prediction, its estimation, based on all of the appropriate assumptions that the CPI increase in consumer prices, over what they would have normally been, will be 1.9 per cent in 2001-2002. You can have lots of variations in the assumptions, but that is the bottom line in the tax package. We will be moving a technical amendment later at the consideration in detail stage.

There is one further point that I wish to refer to. The Deputy Leader of the Opposition has chosen to make a mountain out of a molehill on changes relating to diesel fuel. I am advised that proposed section 75AV prohibits price exploitation in relation to the new tax system. That is the focus of this bill. These tax changes include the abolition of wholesale sales tax and the imposition of the GST. That is the primary focus of the bill: federal taxes, federal focus. There is also a regulation making power to specify other changes that must be passed on to consumers. All of the other state taxes are going to be focused as they come under the power of the Commonwealth. We fully intend to specify the Diesel Fuel Credit Scheme to ensure that consumers gain the full benefit of this change.

We will be doing that by regulation once the state and territory taxes fall into the GST package, which should occur on the final signing off by Premiers and Chief Ministers in early April at a Premiers Conference. Once that occurs, we will be in a position where those regulations—contrary to what the Deputy Leader of the Opposition has suggested, those regulations will be disallowable, they will be subject to parliamentary review, as with other regulations—will cover some of the other taxes which are not specified in this bill. Therefore, I commend the bill to the House.
Question put:
That the words proposed to be omitted (Mr Crean's amendment) stand part of the question.
The House divided. [1.28 p.m.]
(Madam Deputy Speaker—Mrs J. Gash)
Question so resolved in the affirmative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move amendments Nos 1 to 4:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 5, page 4 (line 19), omit paragraph (c), substitute:
(c) the imposition of GST and other measures as provided for in
(i) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1998 ;
(ii) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Imposition —Excise) Act 1998 ;
(iii) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Imposition —Customs) Act 1998 ;
(iv) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Imposition—General) Act 1998 ;
(v) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Administration) Act1998 ;
(iv) the A New Tax System (Goods and Service Tax Transition) Act 1998;
(2) Schedule 1, item 5, page 10 (after line 13), after subsection (4), insert:

(4A) The Minister must cause a copy of each report received under subsection (1) to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days of that House after the day on which the Minister receives the report.

(4B) On presentation of a copy of each report in the House of Representatives under subsection (4A), the report shall stand referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration.

(4C) As soon as practicable after the report has been received by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration under subsection (4B), an officer representing the Commission must appear before the Committee at a public hearing, in accordance with arrangements agreed to by the Committee, to give evidence in connection with the report.
(3) Schedule 1, item 19, page 16 (line 24) omit paragraph (c), substitute:
(c) the imposition of GST and other measures as provided for in
(i) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax) Act 1998;
(ii) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Imposition —Excise) Act 1998;
(iii) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Imposition —Customs) Act 1998;
(iv) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Imposition—General) Act 1998;
(v) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Administration) Act 1998;
(vi) the A New Tax System (Goods and Services Tax Transition) Act 1998;
(4) Schedule 1, item 19, page 22 (after line 16), after subsection (4), insert :

(4A) The Minister must cause a copy of each report received under subsection (1) to be tabled in each House of the Parliament within 5 sitting days of that House after the day on which the Minister receives the report.

(4B) On presentation of a copy of each Report in the House of Representatives under subsection (4A), the report shall stand referred to the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration.

(4C) As soon as practicable after the report has been received by the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration under subsection (4B), an officer representing the Commission must appear before the Committee at a public hearing, in accordance with arrangements agreed to by the Committee, to give evidence in connection with the report.

It was most interesting to hear the member for Hinkler in the debate earlier saying that we ought to have GST watch columns and spots on talkback radio and television to monitor the GST based price increases. That is how much confidence the member for Hinkler has in the operation of the markets and in how they are going to keep the prices down and make sure there is no profiteering and price gouging. That is how much confidence the member for Hinkler has in this bill and the measures that the government is suggesting if this bill is carried. He has so much confidence that he is saying, `What we actually need out there is a price watch, a media watch, to keep companies honest and make sure that there is no profiteering as a result of the GST.'

In the consideration in detail stage of this debate, I want to ask the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation a couple of questions about the government's intentions concerning the way this legislation will operate. The first area is the need to look at the situation prior to the introduction of a GST. The point here is whether there is going to be some kind of direction from the Treasurer or the government for the ACCC to set a maximum price for sensitive base commodities, such as petrol or rural products. That is something that we would like to hear from the minister about.

The second area is what sort of monitoring is going to be done of these base commodities so that we know what the price is now and what a fair thing is now. I mention to the House that already there is concern being expressed about what has happened in the pre-paid funerals area and about retailers putting up prices in anticipation of a GST. The question of what sort of pre-monitoring will go on ahead of the introduction of the GST—if that occurs—is an important area, and we want to hear about the government's intentions and plans for it.

We also want to know what kinds of instructions the government is giving the ACCC concerning the way in which this legislation will be monitored. We had a discussion about diesel fuel. Has the government informed the ACCC of its intentions concerning the diesel fuel excise area? It certainly was not the indication we got from the Senate estimates that there had been this kind of communication with the ACCC.

The member for Hinkler suggests that the public ought to report instances of price gouging or profiteering and dob in those who take advantage of the GST to unjustifiably put up their prices. That theme is supported by the government as well, where the minister in his closing remark said that the ACCC says it is relying on the public to report rorts. Our response is that that is all very well, but how are the people who have this responsibility placed on them to know what is a fair thing in terms of pricing and what is not, when there is to be no separate line item for the GST?

As I said in my second reading remarks, the Treasurer says that the sales tax was a secret tax and that the GST is to be transparent but in the next breath he tells us that there will be no separate line item for the GST, so a member of the public is simply not in a position to know what is a fair thing in terms of post-GST mark-ups. There is to be no opportunity for members of the public to actually understand what level of price increase might be due to GST or whether sales taxes have been cut from an item and so they are entitled to expect a reduction in price for that particular item. We are concerned that in practice this will not work at all. I want to get some responses from the minister on those questions.

Paragraphs (1) and (3) of the opposition's proposed amendments to the bill deal with what is an apparently extraordinary omission by the government. (Extension of time granted) Prior to the election, both the deputy Prime Minister and the Treasurer assured Australians that the ACCC would be given powers to ensure that all savings resulting from the new tax system would be passed on. The Treasurer said on 24 September last year, in relation to this 10 per cent tax on almost everything, `It is important when we abolish existing taxes that prices come down for consumers, and we are going to have the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission ensuring that the reduction in prices from the 10 taxes being abolished is being passed on.'

The Deputy Prime Minister said on the 7.30 Report on 9 September last year that, as part of the coalition package, `we will empower the ACCC to see that fuel savings will flow right across Australia'. Having studied the bill, I find there is no specific reference to the ACCC having the power to monitor price changes as a result of the Diesel Fuel Credit Scheme. There is a power relating to the imposition of GST, but the Diesel Fuel Credit Scheme is, as its name suggests, a credit to be offset or credited against GST imposed. Even the ACCC itself does not think it has the power.

Last week in evidence before both the estimates and the GST select committee, Mr Hank Spier, General Manager of the ACCC, indicated that it was his understanding that the scheme was not specifically defined in the legislation as coming within the ACCC's powers and would probably have to be covered by regulation. The Leader of the Opposition asked the Deputy Prime Minister in question time yesterday to explain how the ACCC had the power in relation to diesel fuel. No explanation was forthcoming. On this basis, we are moving that the scope of the ACCC's powers be widened to explicitly cover the imposition of the GST and other measures imposed by the government's GST bills. This is in no way indicative of Labor softening its stance on the GST. It is still an unfair tax; it is still a job destroyer; it is still bad for the economy.

The minister said in his closing remarks that this was something that the government could take care of by regulation. He talked about the capacity of regulations to be disallowed; he said they were disallowable. But there is nothing that enables us to force the government to enact a regulation if it chooses not to. If he comes into the House and says, `It is all very well; we are going to do a regulation on diesel fuel prices,' and then afterwards the government does not stick to its word, this parliament is in no position to enforce such a piece of regulation. So let us keep the government honest by supporting the idea of an expressed power for the ACCC to monitor diesel prices. I might say that we are very suspicious of the government in this area, given that, concerning petrol prices generally, it has acted to take away the maximum wholesale price and has been expressing the view generally that it does not want to engage in petrol price monitoring.

Even this amendment is inadequate to give the ACCC power to monitor price changes flowing from the tax system change. That is because we have not seen all the changes yet. Who knows what the actual price impact of the abolition of bank fees and charges and stamp duty will be or when it will occur? The explanatory memorandum to this bill is effectively saying, `Take us on trust. When those changes are made, we are going to whack through some regulations to give the ACCC power.' In other words, while the government is stating that any savings from the changes that occur are going to be passed on 100 per cent, it has not yet set in place a monitoring regime which will ensure that this occurs.

The second part of Labor's amendments, sections (2) and (4), impose more stringent reporting requirements on the ACCC. Under the bill, the ACCC has to provide a written report quarterly to the government. However, it is imperative to ensure that the price polic ing and education are occurring as effectively as can be throughout the whole period. Labor considers that it would be assisted by the ACCC appearing before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration to be examined on presentation of each quarterly report. I commend Labor's amendments to the House.

talk.start.para: —We will be rejecting these amendments primarily because they are a stunt. The attempt by the opposition to put in place a whole range of procedural changes to the bill is nothing more than a stunt and an attempt to bypass what is already a fairly clearly described scheme of arrangement in relation to the bill.

speech.para: In the first place, we have undertaken that the regulator, the ACCC, will report back to me on a quarterly basis. The ACCC quarterly reports will be disclosed as and when may be appropriate. The ACCC already appears before the House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration on an irregular basis. I am very confident that that would be an appropriate forum for questioning of the commissioner and the assistant commissioners in relation to this matter.

The House of Representatives Standing Committee on Economics, Finance and Public Administration has already asked the commissioner a vast number of questions on a range of areas. I cannot see that that range of questioning will be curtailed in any way, especially in relation to the GST package.

The remaining amendments proposed by the opposition are rejected because they restrict the flexibility of the government to respond, through regulation, to various issues as they arise. The Labor Party is trying to get us to put into legislation what we can do adequately by regulation. The Labor Party has good form on delaying legislation. After all, together with the Democrats, they are saying that seven months is not a long enough period to discuss the taxation legislation; therefore, let us put everything into legislation instead of into regulation which provides some flexibility in relation to these matters. We are providing a real alternative to the nothingness that has been dropped by the ALP since the last election and their tax package proposal, the response to our tax package. Our proposal is that we retain some flexibility in relation to regulation and, therefore, we will be rejecting these amendments.
Question put:
That the amendments (Mr Kelvin Thomson's ) be agreed to.
The House divided. [1.51 p.m.]
(Mr Deputy Speaker—Mr G.B. Nehl)
Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move government amendments Nos. 1 and 2:

speech.para: (1) Schedule 1, item 5, page 6 (lines 1 to 5), omit paragraph (c), substitute:
(c) the price for the supply is unreasonably high even if the following other matters are also taken into account:
(i) the supplier's costs;
(ii) supply and demand conditions;
(iii) any other relevant matter.
(2) Schedule 1, item 19, page 18 (lines 10 to 14), omit paragraph (c), substitute:
(c) the price for the supply is unreasonably high even if the following other matters are also taken into account:
(i) the supplier's costs;
(ii) supply and demand conditions;
(iii) any other relevant matter.

Upon advice from the Office of Parliamentary Counsel, amendments are proposed to paragraph (c), subsection 2 of clause 75AU in schedule 1, item 5; and clause 75AU in schedule 1, item 19 of the A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998.

These are technical amendments intended to remove the possibility of an unintended interpretation of paragraph (c) and clarify the relationship between paragraphs (b) and (c). The subsequent subparagraphs, which specify matters that may be taken into account when determining whether the price for the supplier is unreasonably high, are not changed by these amendments. I table the supplementary explanatory memorandum which covers the information obtained in the government's amendments.

talk.start.para: —It is our understanding that these are simply technical and drafting amendments and therefore we are happy to accept them. We were discussing the issue of the diesel fuel rebate. I draw the attention of the House to the fact that yesterday, in answer to a question concerning this issue, the Deputy Prime Minister said:

speech.para: In fact, the ACCC has full power . . .

We were advised by the minister at the table during the course of the previous discussion that it will require regulation. So, in fact, it does not have full power and the Deputy Prime Minister ought to apologise for misleading the House yesterday in question time concerning this matter.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, we reject the proposal made by the member for Wills in relation to the diesel fuel rebate. The ACCC does have power in relation to that matter, as I am advised, and it will have further power in relation to that matter once the states and territories have signed up to the GST package at the Special Premiers Conference in April and the appropriate regulations are put in place.

speech.para: Amendments agreed to.
Bill, as amended, agreed to.

subdebate.1.para: Bill (on motion by Mr Hockey)—by leave—read a third time.

talk.start.para: —I inform the House that the Treas urer will be absent from question time today and the Minister for Finance and Administration and the Minister for Financial Services and Regulation will be very happy to answer questions on his behalf.
—My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and concerns his ministerial statement on the second Sherman report when he said:

question.para: . . . the government has remained concerned for the next of kin. Officers of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade have provided copies of the report to the journalists' relatives and invited their questions and comments on it.

Minister, why did you say this, when a number of the relatives only received their copies long after your statement in this House? Why have you added to the distress of the families and why have you so clearly misled this House?

talk.start.para: —I begin by saying that I think the question is seriously pathetic. It is absolutely pathetic. This government, more than any other government since 1975, has been completely transparent on this issue of the Balibo Five. You would have thought that the opposition, which had 13 years in government to address this issue, would at least have the decency to congratulate us on our integrity over this difficult issue.

answer.para: For 13 years, you covered up this issue, then we continued an inquiry set up by the man condemned by the member for Holt. We have a further inquiry and we allow intelligence material to be examined, and you have the audacity to ask a question like that. The answer to the question is that we did endeavour to get all the reports to the relatives of those who died by the time the statement was made. Because of a courier company, which I think is called DHL, in one case in Melbourne—

talk.start.para: —More outsourcing, eh? Why didn't you use Australia Post?
—The member for Banks!

—You see, it is just pathetic. People die, you spend 13 years in government and do nothing about it, then you make the sort of childish interjections you are making now. DHL failed to deliver to a gentleman in Melbourne and failed on one other occasion. We have taken this matter up with DHL. We are obviously profoundly disappointed. These people have been contacted by my department.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The member for Batman! The member for Kingsford-Smith!

—I was determined that the families would get the copies. It is disappointing that in a couple of cases they did not, but they are perfectly free to make any remarks they like. But you stand condemned because you were part of that cabinet and you did nothing about it for 13 years, so let us not have any more cheek from you—

answer.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —or from this person here who was the defence minister through part of that time.

answer.para: Honourable members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The House will come to order. The Minister for Foreign Affairs and the member for Brisbane will stop their cross-chamber interchange. The member for Aston has the call.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Is the Prime Minister aware of recent analysis outlining the need for major increases in tax rates over the next decade if the current taxation framework is maintained?

—I thank the honourable member for Aston for his question, which goes right to the heart of the tax debate. It goes right to the heart of any findings by Senate committees. It puts into sharp relief the attitude taken by the Labor Party and the minor parties on the issue of taxation reform. Indeed, a recent analysis released yesterday, I believe, by Access Economics into Australia's indirect taxation system has found that a severe erosion of indirect tax revenue is in prospect over the next decade under the present system. Without fundamental change now, Access finds that a $7 billion shortfall will emerge by the first decade of the next century.

answer.para: Mr Crean interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Deputy Leader of the Opposition!
—It says:

answer.para: This shortfall will continue to rise thereafter as growth in services continues to outstrip that of goods, ensuring the indirect tax base continues to erode.
It goes on to say:
To keep revenue at its current share of the national cake, Access says that increases in tax rates would be required over the next decade.

That analysis, of course, is in accord with the field evidence, as I might call it, that we had in 1993. The former government found it necessary, after the 1993 election, having won re-election on the basis of opposing a goods and services tax, to increase a whole range of indirect taxes.

The reality is that, unless the fundamental reform put forward by the government is adopted in its entirety, there will be a further erosion of the indirect tax base. We will see pressure for increases in indirect taxes similar to what occurred in 1993. In the eyes of some, that would be no bad thing. Senator Lees, the Leader of the Australian Democrats, in an interview this morning, indicated that she is in favour of increased taxation. In answer to the question, `Does that mean we have to collect more tax?', she said:
Well, that is a very good question. Indeed, the argument goes that the answer is if we want to keep the standard of services we enjoy now, the answer is yes.

There is only one policy on offer that can guarantee to the states of Australia the capacity to provide the services that they need into the future, without imposing a massively increased tax burden on the Australian people, and that is the policy that I took on behalf of the government to the last election.

I say again to those in the Senate who are delaying this taxation package, to those who would seek to defeat the verdict of the Australian people: listen to what the Australian people said; understand that unless we reform the Australian taxation system, root and branch, we are condemned to an inadequate, second-rate solution that is going to deny to the Australian economy the full measure of the esteem that it should occupy, even above what it has now, in the eyes of the rest of the world.

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Skehill Report

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Transport and Regional Services. Minister, can you assure the House that no changes or excisions have been sought or made to the yet to be tabled full report of the Skehill inquiry into last year's seaplane crash in order to protect Mr Dick Smith, the board of CASA or CASA itself from adverse reflections upon their performance? If changes or excisions were sought, when and by whom were they sought?

—I thank the honourable member for her question. I have to say that I am completely, genuinely and absolutely unaware of any such requests and have no reason whatsoever to believe that they might either have been made or acted upon.

—My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Can the Prime Minister inform the House of the government's top priority in relation to our nation's future? Is the coalition government sparing any effort in seeking ways to create jobs for Australians?

—I can inform the House that the top priority of this government is to maintain the magnificent economic performance of Australia over the last three years and, in particular, to ensure that the full benefit of that economic performance is allowed to flow through to the Australian labour market. In terms of an individual policy, our top priority is to reduce unemployment. That is why, within less than a month of being appointed as the new minister responsible for employment, the honourable member for Flinders, the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business had written me a letter of some 19 or 20 pages outlining new ideas to tackle unemployment.

answer.para: I notice that the opposition thinks there is something wrong about this. I can say that I am proud to have a minister who cares about reducing unemployment. I am proud to lead a government that has policies to reduce unemployment. I am absolutely ashamed that we have an opposition which is prepared to destroy 50,000 Australian jobs by defeating the unfair dismissal laws and is going to vote against 230,000 jobs for young Australians.

Let me make it very clear that there will be no retreat by this government from policies to reduce unemployment. We are about examining all of the proposals that are relevant to reducing unemployment. Of course those proposals will be assessed against the election undertakings that we gave both in 1996 and in 1998, particularly those undertakings in relation to entitlements under Australian workplace agreements being the same as under the relevant award. They will be maintained.

Unlike those opposite, we are not afraid to have policies to reduce unemployment. We are determined, despite your obstruction, to further reduce unemployment. The benefit of the magnificent economic growth of the Australian economy should be allowed, without obstruction, to flow through to the men and women of Australia who want work but cannot get it. You will do Australia a great service if you join the government in fighting unemployment instead of engaging in your tactics of obstruction, delay and blind negative opposition.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Prime Minister. Prime Minister, you promised that no Australian worker would be worse off under your industrial relations changes. Why did you secretly commence planning, within weeks of last year's election, to break that promise for the two million Australians who start a new job each year?
—Mr Speaker, the answer is I—

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I issue a general warning to members in this House. As I indicated when I became Speaker, I think it would be the ultimate indignity for a member of the House to find themselves suspended from the service of the House for one hour or one day. Our electors expect us, having elected us here, to be here, but I will take action under standing orders 304A or 303 if necessary. The electors of those people so named might bear in mind the fact that their members have chosen to leave the service of the House.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, given the widespread support from mainstream Australia for the coalition government's employment initiatives, what is the government doing to further the creation of jobs in Australia?

—I thank the member for Kalgoorlie for his question. The good news is that this government is absolutely determined to press on, to do absolutely everything within our power to support people—and they can wave that letter around as much as they like. I encourage it. I tell you what: more people are going to read my letter than will ever read the books from the frontbench of the other side.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business will not encourage disruptive behaviour.

—While this government adopts an optimistic view about what can be done by way of constructive policy to help those people who are unemployed, as to what we can do to build the Australian economy, we had a very interesting glimpse into the negative `opposition for the sake of opposition' attitude of the Leader of the Opposition this morning on AM. He was asked, `What is the Labor Party's attitude to try to boost productivity?' and he uttered these most incredible words. He said, `You know, I think we have gone as far as we can go, I think sensibly, in getting productivity out of contestability.' In other words, what he is saying is that, as far as the reform agenda is concerned, the oppo sition went as far as it could by the time it lost office in March 1996.

answer.para: We know that because members opposite have opposed every sensible measure to boost productivity that we have introduced in the meantime. What an indictment on the Labor Party when it comes to major reform. It is a confirmation of the statement that he made before Christmas—his promise to the unions for their funding of his campaign back in 1998—namely, that he would not change the industrial relations policy of the Labor Party by one jot or tittle as a result of the demands on him by not just the Labor movement but also the 52 per cent of the ex-trade union officials who sit on his frontbench.

The fact is that productivity has been surging under us, and that is good. It is good for employees and it is good for our businesses. It means higher living wages and it means that we have been able to make inroads into the problem of unemployment.

This week the Labor Party showed their true colours when they voted against yet another measure to try and create jobs—the unfair dismissal laws. I call on every small business in the country, every person who is unemployed and those people who are concerned about unemployment, to write to the Labor Party. They should write to Kim Beazley, care of Parliament House, Canberra, and tell him what they think of his obstructionist policies.
I conclude by noting that the letters seem to have started coming in. One letter written to the Leader of the Opposition and copied to me was from a gentleman who said to Mr Beazley:

Rather than firms such as ours employing more people, which we won't currently because of the threat of the draconian law you are defending, you seem to prefer to keep people, including the young, on the dole, unproductive and in a hopeless government-induced vacuum which says little for the future of this country and even less for yourselves.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, I direct my question to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, do you recall saying, in your secret plan in relation to Labor's tax credit idea, that `providing compensation through tax credits allows more targeted compensation than income tax cuts and increased family payments'? Do you also recall saying that there may be more that we could do in terms of lowering effective marginal tax rates further? Minister, have you discussed these ideas with the Treasurer and does he agree that this flaw in the tax package will need to be repaired?
—I have not discussed the matter with the Treasurer, but if you read the letter you will see that it was attempting to put together in a succinct way—

answer.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Good. You should read it a few times and maybe you would learn something from it. The letter said that this was an idea that had been floated around some time ago. In fact, the letter said that that particular measure had gone to the government's tax reform task force back in 1997 and it was decided not to proceed with it. So rather than it being your idea, we had considered it and discarded it. We did not proceed with it—end of story.

—Mr Speaker, my question is addressed to the Minister for Employment Services. The Work for the Dole scheme has been an enormous success in my electorate of Cowper. Is the minister aware of proposals to expand the Work for the Dole scheme? Can the minister outline any alternative proposals that have been advocated and explain why some members of this House support different approaches to assist the unemployed?

—I thank the member for Cowper for his question. Mr Speaker, I am aware of proposals to expand the Work for the Dole program and to extend the mutual obligation principle. They are based on the fundamental attitude that you do not help people by pretending that the world owes them a living. Why shouldn't this government or any other government aim over time to eliminate sit-down money from the Australian way of life?

answer.para: The difference between the government and the opposition is that we are discussing the pros and cons of policy amongst colleagues while opposition members are shouting at each other in public. The difference is that we do not use ideas as weapons in the leadership struggle; we do not think of ideas as daggers to plunge into the back of the party leader.

talk.start.para: —You're joking; ha, ha!

—I have been asked about alternative proposals. This morning the Leader of the Opposition called for a return to the Working Nation program policies that his colleagues know were expensive failures. The member for Melbourne wrote, in his recent book:

answer.para: Labor MPs regularly encountered people who had done several courses and still had little chance of finding a job.

I was curious about who these Labor MPs might have been who were honest in private but not in public. In his book, the member for Melbourne acknowledges a number of people for their comments, including the member for Grayndler, the member for Kingsford-Smith, the member for Rankin, the member for Jagajaga and the member for Perth. I am looking forward to their own honesty in future publications.

I have also been asked to explain why there are these different approaches, and the explanation is not far to find. The truth is that members opposite are slaves to the trade union movement. If any proof is necessary, it comes in the form of a press release dated Tuesday from the member for Hunter, which says:
The Caucus unanimously supported a motion of support for the CFMEU . . .

The caucus unanimously supported the socialist aristocracy that believes in hereditary jobs for coalminers. It is very clear that this is a government of innovation and ideas and that that is an opposition dominated by party hacks and fading trade union dynasties.

talk.start.para: —I inform the House that we have present in the gallery this afternoon the South African Minister for Public Enterprises, Ms Stella Sigcau. On behalf of the House, I extend to her a very warm welcome.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to the Minister for Employment Services. Minister, isn't it a fact that your senior minister's secret plan recognises that the long-term unemployed—now over 34 per cent of the unemployed—are not helped by your Work for the Dole Program but need a wage subsidy coupled with genuine training? Isn't this the same scheme which your government slashed in the 1996 budget and which has now been shown to be twice as effective as Work for the Dole across 50 times the number of unemployed people covered by Work for the Dole?

—The fact is that the numbers of long-term unemployed have been falling over recent months, thanks to the policies of this government. The fact is that Work for the Dole is proving to be far more effective in helping the unemployed than the Working Nation policies pursued by the trade union hacks and heavies opposite. As I was able to tell the House yesterday, the Work for the Dole Program has a 32 per cent outcome rate at the price of $3,900 per success. The New Work Opportunities Program, which was the flagship of Working Nation, had a 21 per cent success rate at the cost of $52,000. So these people ought to stop criticising the Work for the Dole Program. They should stop treating these fine young Australians who are participating in it as a political football. They should stop treating people who are trying to better themselves as lepers. Most of all, they should give up their allegiance to the trade union movement.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Can the minister inform the House how poor literacy and numeracy levels affect youth unemployment? What action is the government taking to encourage unemployed young people, particularly those in my electorate of Deakin, to address their literacy difficulties? How does this compare with previous policies?

talker.name: Kemp, Dr David, MP
Dr KEMP
talker.role: Education, Training and Youth Affairs; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Public Service

talk.start.para: —I thank the member for Deakin for his question. As the member for Deakin is aware, numerous research studies have shown that many job seekers have literacy and numeracy problems which prevent them from getting the jobs that they are seeking. For example, males with very poor literacy and numeracy skills have been twice as likely to be unemployed in their late teens compared with those with average or better skills.

answer.para: One of the lasting scars of the 13 years of the previous Labor government was that one-third of young Australians were coming out of school without adequate literacy skills. They could not read and write properly. Indeed, the Leader of the Opposition, who was education minister for some years under the previous government, is personally accountable for this massive failure which lies at the heart of youth unemployment today. He not only left Australia with a deficit of $10.3 billion but he left 30 per cent of young Australians with inadequate literacy skills. He more than anyone else should take responsibility for this failure. The member for Melbourne must have been very ashamed when he wrote in his book, reflecting on those years of Labor government:
One in five have not attained appropriate literacy and numeracy standards by the time they leave primary school.
He said, quite correctly:
These children are already struggling to participate in the day-to-day life of their schools. The struggle will be intensified when they leave school and look for work.

The Labor Party abandoned a generation of young Australians. They did this because they are nothing more in the end than the mouthpiece of the bosses of the education unions, who fought for years to prevent literacy standards being established and who still oppose the testing of young Australians and the accountability of schools and teachers to parents. We have over there a party in which every member is a member of the trade union movement, where 52 per cent of the frontbench have been officials in the trade union movement and where no policy can be adopt ed unless that policy is compatible with the ideology of the unions behind the party. That is why we have so many young Australians today who cannot read and write adequately. It has been up to this government to emphasise the proper values of mutual obligation in this community and to provide young Australians with the opportunity to pick up these literacy and numeracy skills.

talk.start.para: —My question is again to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. It refers to his earlier answer to me and to the reference by him of the tax credits issue to his employment committee. Minister, your letter, the secret document, refers on page 11 to the fact that, following the reference of the tax credits issue to this committee:

question.para: . . . no decision was reached at that time.
Minister, you have just told the House that the tax credit was discarded by your government. Were you telling the truth in your letter or have you just misled the parliament?

talk.start.para: —It must be a continuing disappointment for the Deputy Leader of the Opposition that an idea which he thought was worth having was not adopted by the government.

answer.para: Mr Beazley interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Well, we understand his disappointment. But the fact of the matter is this government has got a tax policy and we are in the process of implementing that tax policy. And what do you do? You are doing absolutely everything within your power to prevent the implementation of a policy which would create real jobs.

—Mr Speaker, a point of order on relevance: he was asked a very specific question as to whether or not the answer that he had given was at variance with the answer that was in his letter—a simple question—and yet he is diverting the argument far afield from that.
—I call the minister and call him to be relevant to the question.
—Mr Speaker, not much further needs to be said. The letter says:

answer.para: In my view, while such a proposal has some merit, it would be more appropriate—
while it has some merit—
to consider it in the context of an examination of the so-called Five Economists' Proposal—
which I have already referred to. If you look at the five economists' proposal and my analysis of it, what I basically conclude is that in my view it was not—

talk.start.para: —I raise a point of order, Mr Speaker. It goes to relevance.
—I will hear the deputy leader. I must say I was obviously following the leader's interjection and I felt that the minister had been relevant. But I will hear the deputy leader.
—I was too. My point, Mr Speaker, is: are they considering it or have they discarded it?
—The question has been asked and the minister is responding to it. I call the minister.
—I would conclude by saying we obviously had an analysis of the five economists' proposal, we were not enamoured by it and that was the end of the matter.
—So it is discarded?
—The Deputy Leader of the Opposition forgets just how thin the ice everyone is skating on this afternoon is.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry. Minister, I understand you travelled to Far North Queensland yesterday with the members for Kennedy, Leichhardt and Corio, as did Minister Anderson travel to Gympie and Maryborough last week with Minister Truss, the member for Dickson and me. Could you advise the House of the findings of your inspection of cyclone damaged crops in Queensland?

—I thank the member for Fairfax for his question. Yes, yesterday I did travel to Far North Queensland to inspect particularly the crop damage as a result of Cyclone Rona in that part of Australia in recent times. As part of that process, we took the local members—the member for Kennedy and the member for Leichhardt—with us and, in a gesture of bipartisanship, the member for Corio.

answer.para: We had a rather extensive and exhausting day, but the people of North Queensland were certainly appreciative of the fact that we took the opportunity to go and have a look at the devastation that has been caused by Cyclone Rona to the crops in the area concerned. We saw extensive damage to the sugarcane industry in the Far North Queensland area. From 20 to 40 per cent of the crop has been damaged. Seventy per cent of the banana crop has been damaged and about 80 per cent of the pawpaw crop.

We have maintained all along that we are providing assistance through the Natural Disaster Relief Fund from the Commonwealth. There were obviously a number of suggestions made by local growers in the areas that we visited yesterday which I will take up with my ministerial colleagues in discussions. Whilst we were there, there were also issues raised about comments from the Premier of Queensland. He has been making some suggestions on what the Commonwealth should and should not do with regard to disaster relief. We stick by the arrangements that we have in place—and the Prime Minister enunciated those last weekend—with the Natural Disaster Relief Fund. But we might also make some suggestions to the Queensland government that, if they want to be constructive, they might replace the $58 million that they took out of their budget, after winning government, from their emergency relief fund. They cut it from $158 million to $99 million. So Mr Beattie might just have a look at that area.

There is an interesting point, which I should inform the House about, that arose yesterday. I have been speaking a fair bit around Australia about the prospects of improving access to insurance products for farmers generally in Australia so they can better manage their risks. And we found yesterday some innovative farmers in North Queensland, particularly the banana growers, who had actually insured their crops in a cyclone area against cyclone damage—an expensive exercise where one grower had indicated that it cost him $40,000 in a premium to cover his crop for $500,000. But the telling point that was made was that they have to pay an 8½ per cent stamp duty on that insurance.

talk.start.para: —How much?

—8½ per cent stamp duty. So on that $40,000 premium he is paying $3,400 to the Queensland government for stamp duty. Another suggestion for Premier Beattie: he might consider reducing or removing that stamp duty on that policy. I think the honourable members who travelled with me yesterday—the members for Kennedy, Leichhardt and Corio—and certainly the farmers in North Queensland were appreciative of the interest and concerns of the Commonwealth in the plight that the farmers find themselves in at the moment.
—My question is to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Do you recall stating in your secret plan:

question.para: Couching Work for the Dole . . . in terms of an employment relationship would also directly reduce recorded levels of unemployment . . .

and `there is not necessarily a case for dealing with "mature aged" unemployment other than with' existing programs; but: That will not prevent us from `badging' some of these programs in such a way as to acknowledge the genuine issue of mature age unemployment.
Minister, don't the unemployed deserve real solutions to unemployment, not fiddling figures to hide it?

talk.start.para: —I thought that part of the letter was a fair and reasonable statement. It is surprising that the Labor Party seems so infected by outrage at the statement.
—Confected.

—Confected, thank you, Prime Minister. This was simply another one of many ideas floated which can be considered. It refers to the fact that the way the ABS collects statistics could potentially result in that. Why would we raise that matter? Firstly to be up-front about it in our own consideration of it and, secondly, because when you were in office for years you had a deliberate policy to hide the unemployed on make work programs that did nothing for this economy. You spent billions of dollars. The $2 billion dollar man, the former ex-ACTU president, spent billions of dollars of taxpayers' money hiding the unemployed and providing no solutions to Australia's long-term unemployment. You talk about long-term unemployment. Do you know what worries us on this side? We inherited a lot of people who are long-term unemployed. We on this side are genuinely concerned at the way this economy is structured. As we have had a downturn the number of long-term unemployed has been ratcheting up and up and up.

answer.para: When you fairly read my letter you will note that I start by saying that Australia has an unemployment problem which we inherited from Labor but within that problem there are particular components which are of concern to us—young people, that is why we are doing something about junior wage rates; the long-term unemployed, which is the reason I raise it; and indigenous Australians, where I believe the level of unemployment is too high and we need to have a specific further consideration of what we can do to improve those circumstances. Don't you come in here and talk to us about concerns for the long-term unemployed. The Labor Party in office punished the long-term unemployed by running a system at the dictates of the ex-ACTU presidents which denied those people a chance of a job.

We do not accept a censure of a government which is prepared to look at ideas. We say, proudly, that this government is prepared to look at any idea, to leave no stone unturned, to do the right thing by the unemployed—long-term or otherwise.

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Foreign Affairs. Can the minister inform the House about the aims of his forthcoming visit to Indonesia, the meetings he intends to hold and in particular the discussions he intends to have on East Timor?
—I thank the honourable member for Wannon for his sensible and constructive question. It stands in stark contrast to the smut we get from the other side.

answer.para: I will be visiting Indonesia from 23 to 25 February—that is next week—partly to participate in the Australia-Indonesia ministerial forum in Bali and also to hold a number of key meetings in Jakarta. I will be meeting with President Habibie and I also intend to meet General Wiranto, the Minister for Defence and Security and Chief of ABRI, and Amien Rais. I will also visit Xanana Gusmao under his new detention arrangements in Jakarta on 25 February. I have made clear to the House before, and I have made clear elsewhere, that Xanana Gusmao is a crucial figure in the resolution of the problems of East Timor. We have had considerable contact with him through our ambassador in Jakarta and I think it is appropriate that I call on him myself and discuss the future of East Timor, which is such an important issue to this government.

So this visit will allow me while I am in Indonesia to canvass a wide variety of opinion on the future of East Timor and to advocate in person the necessity of ensuring an ordered, stable and non-violent process of transition in East Timor, whether the outcome is autonomy or independence.

From Jakarta I propose to travel to Lisbon where I will discuss the future of East Timor with Portugal's Foreign Minister, Mr Jaime Gama, on 27 February. Given the quick evolution of events affecting the future of East Timor, Australia gives its full support to an ordered, peaceful and fair settlement of the East Timor issue. It is with this goal in mind that I have been meeting, and I continue to meet, a wide range of participants in the East Timor issue, including key East Timorese figures.

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. Minister, do you recall writing to the Prime Minister saying that the minimum wage safety net for the poorest wage earners is too generous and that it should be replaced by a new less generous rate? Isn't your proposal in that letter to have that rate set by a new tribunal, to include the Productivity Commission, the Reserve Bank and the Treasury, just a way of nobbling the industrial relations umpire because it does not agree with your political agenda?
—We did put the letter out last night, as the member knows, and on that basis there is no reason for him to be paraphrasing it the way he did.

answer.para: Mr Bevis interjecting—

talk.start.para: —That was not a quote, was it? No. In respect of the panel idea, the commission has had panels for many years. The idea of a panel to draw together expertise for a particular issue is not a new concept. The idea of ensuring that the commission has available to it economic expertise is not new, either. In fact, that has been discussed and acted upon for many years. It was one of a number of ideas. I do not think it is a bad idea.
—You want to sack the umpire.
—Oh!

—I advanced the idea because it is an option. It is very important that the commission, in making decisions, has regard to the economic consequences of those decisions. I would have thought anybody—even an ex-trade union official like yourself—might appreciate the point that when the decision is handed down by the commission it would add authority to that decision if people can see in a transparent way that it has been deliberated upon by those who have specific expertise in the area.

—I direct my question to the Minister for Aged Care. Minister, what is the government doing to support nursing homes in rural and regional areas like those in my electorate of McEwen? How are they responding to the challenges of accreditation?

—I thank the member for McEwen for her question because I know the concern that she has for older Australians in her own electorate, as indeed this government has for those right across the country. We inherited an appalling situation from the Labor Party, with 10,000 places short and an acceptance by the Labor Party of the substandard care given in various facilities across Australia. Quite frankly, we had to fix it up.

answer.para: Basically, we have introduced increased capital and recurrent funding for rural and remote facilities. We have introduced a system of accreditation which will no longer tolerate substandard—and, indeed, appalling in some circumstances—nursing homes for older Australians. I have seen a number of criticisms that have come forward from some quarters which tend to indicate that it is going to be all too hard for people to meet the new standards. I say this: we fund the 135,000 people who need residential care to the tune of $3 billion a year—that is $3 billion dollars a year on 135,000 people. We fund those individuals in order that they may get the care that they require. Providers are the means of giving that care, but our business is not to prop up providers who do not provide proper care.

So that people can see how well it is working, I would like to quote some comments from a letter from the director of nursing at a stand-alone rural facility—a 40-bed community run organisation in Deniliquin—which was published by the Aged Care Standards Agency. The director of nursing, Jean Booth, writes:

Let me tell you what accreditation has meant for us. Staff have formed working parties and become committed to the process, seeking positive outcomes for their efforts—for example, a reduction in skin tears and falls; a reduction in back injuries due to a no-lift policy; a reduction in our workers compensation premiums; regular maintenance programs for equipment; and introduction of specialty areas for nurses, i.e. we have specially trained nurses responsible for a particular area, such as palliative care, pain management and dementia care.
They did not employ a consultant. At the end of her letter, she says:

It is important that other nursing home and hostel proprietors, especially those in the country, be aware that accreditation can benefit all concerned and the process of preparing for accreditation can be a rewarding and positive exercise.

Those reforms that we have put in place, and in which the Prime Minister was so much involved, are proving to have a very positive outcome but, most importantly, they will get rid of people who are providing substandard care and will mean that the taxpayer is getting a good outcome for the dollar expended.

talk.start.para: —My question without notice is directed to the Deputy Prime Minister. Is the Deputy Prime Minister aware that Minister Reith's secret plan requires that social security payments be cut following cuts in wages? Do you agree with Mr Reith's proposal to cut wages even further in regional and rural Australia? Do you support cutting pensions and other benefits there too? Will you start in Boree Creek—or do you have any other ideas?

—I have been too busy boosting our export effort to the world to read the letter, but I am assured by the Prime Minister's response, which I have read, that what you propose is absolute nonsense and will not be part of government policy.

—My question is to the Minister for Employment Services. Is the minister aware of calls for a bipartisan approach to reducing unemployment? Is the minister aware of recently expressed views that might provide the basis for this approach? What are the obstacles to such a bipartisan approach?

—I thank the member for Pearce for her question. I am aware of calls for a bipartisan approach to reducing unemployment, most particularly the calls made by the member for Batman yesterday and by the member for Hotham this morning. How can members opposite seek unity between the government and the opposition when there is no unity inside the ALP? I have been asked about published views on which a bipartisan approach might be possible. I have a published view here from the member for Werriwa, who says:

answer.para: Unless the disadvantaged are willing to make an effort to develop new skills and take new opportunities, governments are wasting their time. Without effort—
Says the member for Werriwa—
there can be no achievement.
That is the kind of view on which a bipartisan approach might be possible. I have another statement of the member for Werriwa, who said last year:

I think what government needs to do is provide in-kind assistance to the unemployed and then basically have a system whereby after six months on the dole people are moved into a community based form of work.
That is the kind of statement on which the government might be prepared to offer bipartisanship. I have a statement here from the Premier of New South Wales, Bob Carr. He said of the Labor Party:
I have had a gutful, I have had enough of the Labor organisation, I have had enough of head office, I have had enough of the trade unions. If I could press a button and get—
Ms Hoare interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The minister will resume his seat. The member for Charlton is aware, as all members are, that I have issued a general warning. Were it not for the fact that she is here as a new member, she would be leaving the chamber at this point in time. The member for Dobell.

—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order that goes to the fact that, previously, you have told us that we do not have to take points of order on relevance, that you will rule. When will you rule on this minister being irrelevant and bring him back to the question?
—The member for Dobell will resume his seat. The minister will return to the question.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. If Bob Carr had any strength, he would act on this statement.

answer.para: Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —I am going to rule on the minister. I did not think it was fair to cut him off in mid-sentence when he had not indicated precisely what statement he was making.
—Thank you, Mr Speaker. Bob Carr would act on that statement and he would end the kind of mindless allegiance to the union movement that the Labor Party has shown.
—The minister is not being relevant to the question. The minister will resume his seat.
—Mr Speaker, I raise a point of order in relation to standing order 85. The minister is plainly being tedious and repetitious.
—The member for Griffith will resume his seat. The minister clearly understands the ruling and is responding to the question. I have ruled that the minister must be relevant to the question.

—The first requirement for bipartisanship is honesty, and what we need from members opposite is an honest appraisal of policies rather than cheap populism. The second requirement for bipartisanship is a bit of give and take. You cannot demand bipartisanship unless you are prepared to give it. Mr Speaker, if those opposite want bipartisanship, they have three opportunities to prove that they are serious: they can pass the Telstra bill, before the Senate; they can pass the unfair dismissal laws, before the Senate; and they can pass the tax package. If they are not prepared to offer bipartisanship, they cannot demand it. The fact is that, unless they are prepared to do something like this, their call for bipartisanship is a cheap populist stunt.

—My question is directed to the Prime Minister. Has the Prime Minister seen the report of Mark Textor which suggests that the government loses sight of its proper role when it takes sides in industrial disputes? Will you take note of these concerns and act in an impartial manner, or will you continue to permit your minister the balaclavas and guard dogs as you turn your attention to new industries such as the car industry?

—I assume that the advice of Mark Textor to which the Leader of the Opposition is referring is the research that was appended to the letter that was written to me by the newly appointed Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business outlining a whole menu of proposals to be looked at for tackling the ongoing problem of unemployment. Can I again take the opportunity of congratulating the minister for writing to me. Less than a month after he has the responsibility he is in there with 20 pages of ideas, and this mob over here are attacking him. I could be so lucky to have a minister who is so determined to do something about unemployment.

answer.para: I want to say to the House that you want ministers who care, you want ministers who are dedicated, and I am lucky that I have a whole frontbench of ministers who are prepared. I have a Treasurer who is prepared to overturn a budget deficit of $10½ billion; I have an education minister who is prepared to tackle the problem of literacy and numeracy; I have a foreign minister who has been responsible for bringing about a historic change in policy by both Indonesia and Australia towards East Timor—I have a foreign minister who was prepared to do it; I have a magnificent health minister over here on the left; and I also have some magnificent marginal seat winners on the frontbench.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The Prime Minister will resume his seat.
—The Manager of Opposition Business does not have the call and will wait for it—the sort of courtesy that everyone is expected to extend to the chair, regardless of who occupies it.

—Mr Speaker, I am raising a point of order under standing order 145 as it relates to relevance. As I said, we were reluctant to do so because we were enjoying the answer and we were waiting to hear about the Minister for Forestry and Conservation. But you know it is clear that this is not the slightest bit relevant to the question.

—The Prime Minister has the call and I was making a reasonable presumption that, while I may not have applauded as loudly as others, he was in fact planning to come to the Minister Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business as part of the response to the question.

—Mr Speaker, I certainly am coming to that. Of all the things that I am indebted to in this House, I am indebted to the opposition. I really am indebted because I am asked a question about double standards. I am asked a question about taking sides in industrial disputes. The whole of the opposition personifies taking sides in industrial disputes because of their irretrievable links to the Australian trade union movement.

answer.para: They talk about nobbling the Industrial Relations Commission. I remember 1991 when Bob Hawke was still the Prime Minister of Australia and Bill Kelty, of course—and it seems he has been forever—was the secretary of the ACTU. Talk about heredity; he has a lifetime peerage with the ACTU. In April or May 1991, when the Industrial Relations Commission brought down a finding that was unacceptable to the then Labor government, both the then Treasurer, Paul Keating, and the then secretary of the ACTU bitterly attacked that decision. They said it was unacceptable to the trade union movement. They not only nobbled the commission; they also nobbled the Hawke government of the time into defying that particular decision.
The Labor Party comes into this parliament and talks about partisanship, but you supported the nobbling of the Industrial Relations Commission.

talk.start.para: —Could I take a point of order on relevance? It is an irrelevant rant, and it is time he was brought to order.
—The Leader of the Opposition will resume his seat.
—The Leader of the Opposition by his interjection allows me to—
—No, Prime Minister. The Leader of the Opposition raised a point of order on relevance, and I invite you to come back to the question.

—Mr Speaker, the question was about partisanship in industrial disputes. It invited me to respond to some research by Mr Mark Textor. Can I say that I have some experience with Mr Textor's research. I will tell you what: his research is not too bad, either. He has a reasonable track record, Mr Textor, and there are a few people around here who rather like it.

answer.para: I have also had experience with something else—that is, I never rely on quotations of somebody else delivered from the other side, so I will go and have a look at what he actually had to say before I accept the Leader of the Opposition's version.

If ever a party had no authority to talk about partisanship in industrial relations, it is the Australian Labor Party. They personify one side of the argument. They personify a blind commitment to class warfare. They personify a political party that is bound hand and foot to the dying trade union movement of Australia.

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister for Trade. Building on the government's successful launch of the Trade Outcomes and Objectives statement last week, could the minister inform the House of steps he is taking to open up new trade and investment opportunities for Australian businesses.

—Mr Speaker, at the end of a good fortnight for the government, it is a pleasure to announce, in response to the question by the member for Mallee, that, in addition to several ministers going to Indonesia and Singapore early next week, I will go on to make important bilateral visits to India, Iran and elsewhere.

answer.para: Why is it important? It is important because South Asia has been a particular priority of mine. As Minister for Trade, I have helped facilitate trade, investment and tourism over the last 2½ years in that direction. Australia's 11th largest export market today is India. Our second largest market for coking coal is India. Therefore, I am very pleased to say I will be co-chairing the Australia-India Joint Ministerial Commission in New Delhi at the end of next week.

We will reflect on recent marketing openings for exporters of citrus, pears and peaches, which I know are major priorities for the member for Mallee and other members, including the member for Hinkler, and on expanding and diversifying our export efforts to the world and increasing jobs as a consequence.

In Iran, of course, it will be a case of being the first Australian cabinet minister to visit there since 1992. It will provide a priority and focus to building bilateral relations between Australia and Iran. It will build on the grain exports and also wool, dairy products and other breakthroughs which have been secured in recent times, and ensure further expansion in that trade effort.

The Australian export effort today is a very diversified one. Full marks to our exporters ranging across services from information technology to the aviation arena with a focus on the `airshow downunder'—an excellent exhibition of Australian product which is taking place over these few days. I hope to get there on Friday. As Minister for Trade, why would I not go to this magnificent exhibition of Australian product?

I simply want to say at the end of this fortnight, dominated by headlines of `ALP at war'—especially in proximity to Avalon up the road from Melbourne—we finish with the case that Bob Carr wobbles, Brumby giggles, Beazley blusters, and we get on with the job.

talk.start.para: —Mr Speaker, on that note I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Saftey Authority: Skehill Report

talk.start.para: —I wish to add briefly to an answer I gave in response to a question from the member for Dickson in relation to assertions that perhaps something not quite correct in relation to the Skehill report had taken place.

speech.para: My office has spoken to the writer of that report, Mr Skehill, regarding the member for Dickson's assertions. Mr Skehill advises that there have been no changes to the report. He said he stood by the report's finding that the director and board of CASA had acted with propriety. He said there was no substance to the member for Dickson's claims. He has indicated he will put that in writing, and I will table that at the first opportunity.

In the meantime, I take the opportunity to table a related letter from Mr Skehill in response to a matter referred to him by the Director of Aviation Safety. Really, it is about time we had some novel, new, fresh and decent contributions to the debate on aviation safety in Australia from the member for Dickson.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I move:

speech.para: That this House censures the Prime Minister:

(1) for his instruction to the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business to develop a secret plan which would break the Government's undertaking that no worker would be worse off under its workplace reforms and undermine the living wage for ordinary Australian families; and
(2) for his undermining of Australians' desire for high-wage, high-skill, secure jobs and not low-wage, low-skill and transient jobs.

What we on this side of the House want is Australian families to enjoy decent, high skilled jobs in a high wage economy with decent security and decent standards of living. What this government is about is attempting bogusly to solve unemployment problems by a low wage economy with low skilled jobs, with no security of tenure and with the consequent deprivation of families of the sort of security they need to survive in the sort of community they will confront in the future.

We are about hope for ordinary Australian families. We are not about the decimation of their living standards, we are not about doing it in secret plans, we are not about breaching solemn undertakings to the Australian people while we do it. The Prime Minister is deserving of censure here for the very reason that he has broken solemn undertakings to the Australian people in seeking this set of propositions from his minister.
Mr Reith interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The minister says he has 101 ideas on this, but he has one idea on this—one only—and that is to attack the wages of the least well-off in our community. When he gets in there and attacks the social safety net, as he does, the living wage safety net, as he does, and expresses objection through his letter to the determinations made by the IRC, what he is attacking is the living standards of Australian families who live on less than his travel allowance claims every year. We are talking here about attacking the standards of families who live on $20,000 to $28,000 a year, depriving them of the social safety net and undermining the capacity of the Industrial Relations Commission to consider their matters.

speech.para: What an absolute farce it was, what a deceit, when the minister stood up in this place and said that often things are referred to panels of the Industrial Relations Commission. They are, but they are panels of the Industrial Relations Commission, not a couple of selected members of the Reserve Bank board. In undermining them he does the double act. I think it is terribly important for people in regional Australia to comprehend this, because it goes to the heart of a problem that this government confronts or, more particularly, the people of this country confront. The problem is that when you attack the poor-but-earning you increase the burden on the budget. That is in fact how the social security system operates. Having done so, you discourage folk in those positions from getting out there and earning a bit extra. That is what you do.

The minister, in comprehending the logic of what he has done, in comprehending the logic of his assault on wages in regional Australia and his assault on the incomes of the poor earning in metropolitan Australia as well, realises it is no good doing this unless you attack their social safety net as well—lowering their pensions, lowering their supporting parents benefits and lowering their family incomes. You have to do that if you are going to get, from their point of view, bang for your buck from cutting wages.

This is an extraordinary proposition by a government that said it was devoted to a belief in its workplace reforms and to the proposition that no person should be worse off. Let us take that a point further and look at the question of awards.
