It is insufficient for the government that it has collapsed awards down to 20 allowable matters, that a whole range of health and safety issues have been incorporated within awards, and a whole set of good public purposes removed—like time off to be able to be members of the Australian armed services reserves. When the government removes all that from awards and collapses them to 20 allowable matters, that is not enough. It has to go further, according to it, and many people, particularly those who change their employment—some two million a year—ought then to be subject to an attack on awards and all effect.

What you place yourself at risk of experiencing, under this set of propositions, is that when you change your job you will find an employer saying to you, `You can forget any of the allowable matters in the award you are now covered by. You are now subject to a single benchmark award; take it or leave it.' That is their proposition. This ruthless assault on the ordinary families in Australia is an assault done by deception and secrecy. It is all very well for this minister to get out there now and say, `I am open about this and these are brilliant ideas I just want to fling out like confetti. More people are going to read this than read the books written by members of the Labor Party.' Well, Minister, you can count on it: more will; we will make absolutely certain of that. You can count on that proposition.

The minister knows darned well this was meant to be a covert exercise that had many motivations behind it, not least the advancing of his position in the succession. Jealous of the attention the Treasurer's got, he said, `I want to take over the agenda after the Treasurer has finished in relation to his tax package and, while I am taking over that agenda, I will take the Labor Party's tax proposals with me, thank you very much,' though he seems to have repudiated them during the course of today.

Having said in his paper `what a good set of ideas they are' to support the situation of low income and middle income people in the work force, as in the Labor Party's proposition, he has abandoned that today. Having done all this in secrecy, he has the absolute hide to come out and say, `It was obviously meant for some sort of public floating at some point of time.' Half the problem with this deception is its intention that it be secret, an intention blown by the diligent work of my spokesperson in this regard. There is a great deal that is interesting in this set of propositions as far as we are concerned, and I will get onto that a little bit later.

Given the cynicism with which this whole exercise has been approached, it is not surprising to find some incredibly cynical propositions in the document itself. This document says that middle aged unemployed people do not matter—that they are not a real problem. It says, `We'll get a few employment programs and badge them.' The folk who happen to be in their 30s, 40s and 50s and who are about to become unemployed as a result of the closure of BHP Steel in Newcastle, the folk who will become unemployed as a result of the closure of textile factories, the folk who will become unemployed as a result of downsizing in just about any industry that you care to name—folk who are finding themselves in difficulty with employment now—are not a real problem but they will be badged. `None shall sleep but all should be badged' as far as this government is concerned.

The ultimate cynicism of these propositions is shining in these papers for all to see. It is an extraordinary statement, but it is one which many in this community have come to believe is possible of this minister and this Prime Minister, particularly when more of their activities were exposed during the waterfront dispute last year. In other words, this is Howard and Reith in continuation as far as a tax on the ordinary workers of this country is concerned.

They defend themselves here by criticising the Labor Party for not supporting their unfair dismissal proposals. What they have failed to tell the population is that the legislation that they are affecting to uphold is theirs. It is not ours—it is theirs. It is their unfair dismissal legislation. They said when they introduced it that there would not be a ripple of change to it if there was no need because it was perfection. This proposition is about two things. It is about class war and it is about alibis. It is not about solutions to problems like unemployment. It is about class war, it is about alibis but it is not about solutions. That is what that proposition is about.

They fling about that ridiculous assertion by Mr Bastian that somehow or other 50,000 jobs will be created if it goes through. When Bastian was questioned in the Senate about all this we learned the real social basis of those statistics. It is a best guess—a best guess based on nothing. What we do know is that a result of it going through would be that a very large number of people would have additional job insecurity added to their many other woes. That we do know. It will not create employment, but it will destroy security as far as they are concerned. That is one piece of cynicism that is contained within this document. There are other pieces of cynicism within this document.

They have been standing before the public saying that their Work for the Dole program is a terrific new initiative. After three years, 16,000 people in this country have been through their Work for the Dole program: 16,000 out of 800,000 unemployed have been through their Work for the Dole program.

Read between the lines of this particular document and you will discover this: the assumption underpinning the Work for the Dole program is that all you need is a bit of job experience and that you will get a good outcome as a result of that. That is specifically denied and repudiated. What do they cynically say? They say, `What you've got to do is produce programs that combine wage subsidies with training.' Where have I heard that before? I guess I heard it when my deputy leader stood up in this parliament and introduced Working Nation. That is where I last heard that proposition. Hundreds of thousands went through the wage subsidy program and the training programs associated with it and their outcomes in employment and training were twice the level of their paltry 16,000 in work for the dole. They have exposed their cynicism in that regard.

You could bet your bottom dollar there would never have been a paper voluntarily emanate from the Liberal Party which so exposed their principal program that they have used to deceive the Australian people; the program that they ponce about in public saying is the solution to that particular problem. You can bet your bottom dollar they have never produced a public document that undermined it like this public document undermines it. Another piece of cynicism.

Let me take a further piece of cynicism. Having come to the Australian people saying, `We have a tax package which the Senate must pass, which the Australian people have endorsed, which will create growth, which will create jobs; this is the solution to unemployment,' what do we find in this document? We find that it is not the solution to unemployment. We find that it is a wise thing, as far as this document is concerned, to proceed down the road of looking at earned income tax credits. Where have we heard those things before? From the Labor Party at the last election. He got up in parliament today and tried to say that this had been rejected at the time that their employment committee considered it. That is another thing that is in the document, Mr Minister.

It says in the document that it had not been rejected. In other words, a massive change to the taxation system was out there, floating free, despite the fact that they said to the Australian people that it was supposed to have been comprehensively covered in the tax package they put out. Why wouldn't they have it floating around for consideration? We know from all the evidence that has been presented to the Senate that a GST is a job killer. We know that, but not on the Labor Party's say-so. You can forget the Labor Party's argument on that. We would say that, wouldn't we? Go to a Conservative modeller—including their modellers of choice—and what you will find is this: if there are any jobs in it, they will only come from spending the surplus. But that is more than offset by the consequences of the destruction of the employment of those who are in the service sector, which is the fastest growth area in jobs provision in this country now. Those people will, for the first time, find themselves heavily taxed and have a substantial administrative burden.

This is a wonderful document in terms of what it exposes of the poverty of the thinking of the Liberal Party and in terms of the arguments we have put forward for some substantial period of time about appropriate wage subsidies and training programs. If anyone is going to have any chance of getting into a decent skilled job and an opportunity for some permanency in the work force, an opportunity to support a family in the work force, an opportunity to save for retirement in the work force, they will not get it from anything that is being argued by this government.

I do not mind seeing Labor Party policy pinched, and I do not mind seeing undermined the government's argument that somehow we are out of ideas, when they have none other than ours. The thing I find hardest to take is what they want to do with that to conceal. They want to use our tax package and our proposals to support the unemployed to conceal the fact that they intend an assault on low income Australian families. That is what I hate about the deception here—that they want to use Labor Party policy as the carrot, the sweetener, the sugar coating to conceal their real intentions.

Their real intentions have nothing to do with solving problems. Their real intentions are about Liberal Party ideology and prejudice. In case you do not believe that, I strongly recommend that you read Mr Textor's research. I have had my road to Damascus about Mr Textor. I have had the opportunity now to read his research which would not have been there before. He is of course a well-known and notorious push poller. But there was not any push polling here.
Mr Reith interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Well, we did not have the opportunity to read it, did we? Now we have had the opportunity to read it. What a fool you were to release it. You have released it and now we know. What Mr Textor reveals is this. When they mount their attacks on the trade unions, when they mount their attacks on the fact that some members of my frontbench have served the 2½ million to three million people in this community who are proud to call themselves members of trade unions—as opposed to the 100,000 in this community who are joined by the majority of the Liberal Party in obtaining and owning family trusts in order to avoid their fair share of tax—what they know from Mr Textor is that just about everybody in the work force likes them, including people who are not members of unions.

speech.para: What they also know from Mr Textor is that with regard to the sort of behaviour you engaged in which was part of your deception of last year—as opposed to your deception of this year—they do not expect you to play the sorts of roles you have been playing, they do not expect you to come after their work force and slash it. That is what they do not expect of you. They do not expect you to get out there and take sides against the poorest members of this community—and, if they are not the poorest members, they are the middle income Australians. They do not expect that of you.

And what they expect from governments and from employment is not to be rendered more insecure, not to have their awards removed. What they are looking for is a relief from anxiety. What they are looking for is an opportunity to improve their skills. What they are looking for is a satisfaction from life. They are not looking for the sorts of heavy deception that this government is engaging in, which is another reason that it was a secret paper. Australians did not anticipate from this government—which went into the last election campaign with a load of baloney as far as the tax system was concerned plus a promise that no worker in this community would be worse off as a result of decisions they took in the industrial relations area—that within weeks of that election being completed the minister would be out there with his ambition on his sleeve, seeking to take over an agenda from his rival, Mr Costello—two strutting peacocks without a feather to fly, their feathers having been plucked from them and put in the hat of the Prime Minister to wear at the opening of the Olympics. That is what has happened with these two.

The ambition of Mr Reith is to ride on the backs of the poorest people in our community, the weakest at industrial bargaining, and launch an attack on decent servants of the public associated with the trade union movement. But these people in the government have been exposed and, having been exposed, they should now be censured. If the numbers determine that you are not censured now, let me tell you: you will be by the time we next get to grips with you at the polls. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Is the motion seconded?
—I second the motion and reserve the right to speak.

—The government will of course reject the censure motion. We treat it with the contempt it deserves. We have witnessed a pathetic performance from the Leader of the Opposition, whose speech amounts to nothing more than unadulterated drivel from a man whose leadership is drowning in a sea of verbosity in front of our very eyes, from a Leader of the Opposition who has no capacity whatsoever to break out from the manacles on each arm put there by the trade union movement and the former trade union bosses who sit behind him and dictate policy, from a Leader of the Opposition who has no capacity to look to the national interest and bring together the unruly factions within his own side to deliver a policy which is relevant and meaningful to Australia in this decade, let alone in the next millennium.

speech.para: This man talks of cynicism. No greater cynicism can there be than the record of Labor's 13 years in office, whose policies for the low paid and for the unemployed punished them for their unemployment by failing to ever provide a system that would have given people the dignity of work. The Labor Party talks about human rights. What about the human rights of people to have a job? What incredible cynicism it is for the Labor Party to attack the government for simply canvassing within the highest echelons of government what we need to do about unemployment. Not only do we reject this censure motion, but I move the following amendment to the motion:
That all words after "That" be omitted with a view to substituting the following words: "this House condemns the Leader of the Opposition for his:

(a) failure to support the employment creation policies of the Coalition Government which were endorsed by the Australian people at the last election, including Labor's direct rejection of the Government's unfair dismissal laws and regulations which has denied up to 50,000 people a job;
(b) failure to support the preservation of junior rates of pay which could result in up to 240,000 young people losing their jobs; and
(c) failure to detail to the Australian people any meaningful policies which would lead to a reduction in unemployment in this country.

The Leader of the Opposition deserves to have his motion turned upon him because he, in his opposition for the sake of opposition approach, is standing in the way of literally tens of thousands of Australians getting a job. And his policy of obstruction in the Senate is today threatening the jobs of 200,000-odd young Australians who today have jobs and would be denied those jobs if we are unable to secure our legislative program.

Labor had 13 years to do something about unemployment. When we came into office we had a high level of unemployment, a legacy of Labor; a $10½ billion deficit, a legacy particularly of the now Leader of the Opposition, who is a former Minister for Finance; and we had a legacy of an Australian economy that simply was not able to provide the job opportunities that we believe it ought to provide.

For all the negativism that comes from the Labor Party, I say to members on the other side that they should, for once, put their opposition for the sake of opposition attitude to one side. They ought to genuinely ask themselves what they are going to do as parliamentarians to advance constructive suggestions to deal with the problem of unemployment.

I think my letter is a good one. In fact, I am proud to have been able to write such a letter as the employment minister in this government. I think it is about time that letters like that were written. I am very happy to have released that letter last night, along with all the accompanying attachments. It is true that some of the research that Mark Textor did does not suit some of the arguments that we are putting. That is a challenge for us to mount our argument. Why shouldn't we be up-front about that and try to garner political support for what needs to be done?

As I say in my letter, when it comes to the management of a modern economy, it is clear that there is a lot more common ground about what needs to be done to create jobs. There is a lot more common ground than the opposition would have you believe. They are opposed to absolutely everything that we are doing. But, if you fairly put aside politics, the truth is that there are a lot of things that we could do in Australia that would genuinely give people a chance of a job, which they do not have today.

In my letter, I said to the PM that, whilst there is a lot of debate about the details, one of the real problems in Australia is not so much one of knowing what to do; the problem in Australia is gathering the political support to actually do it. It is an obvious statement of fact, for anybody who is genuine and objective about it, that we do need a better tax system. Even the Leader of the Opposition, back in those dim, dark days of 1985, was supporting option C. Why was he supporting Mr Keating's then consumption tax or GST proposal? Because that, as part of a broader package of reforms, is actually a good idea.

I do not mind mixing it with the Labor Party on a bit of politics. In fact, I reckon I could fairly say that I give as good as I take, and we enjoy our work. But the truth of the matter is that that is part of the atmospherics of politics. In the end, we are all elected to actually tackle these problems.

It should hardly be a surprise to anybody that, after an election, the Prime Minister, having made his appointments and having appointed me, in this case, as the minister for employment, should write to me and say, `What are we as a country going to do about unemployment, not just now, for the short term, but over the longer term?' So I set about writing a whole list of ideas, some of which were new, some of which have been talked about for years, in order to put together a comprehensive, articulated strategy as a discussion point for the future.

I took the OECD's 10-point plan for job creation and said, `Let's take those 10 points. We can perhaps concertina that down to five headlines.' I methodically went through each and every one of those five topics identified by the OECD as providing solutions to the problem of unemployment and discussed that within an Australian context.

They say that this is a secret, cynical, nasty, diabolical plan. I say: I am paid to do this. This is my job. I am elected as a member of this parliament to be concerned about unemployment. I am asked by the Prime Minister to advance a few ideas for discussion and they say that this is a shocking indictment of the government. I say: this is a government doing what governments ought to do. This is something that never happened when Labor was in office. Labor would be elected and the Prime Minister would write a letter to the ACTU and say, `What will you let me do during this term?'

The point I make at the beginning of this letter is that it is a genuine problem. I have spelt out the details of the problem. One of the good things that has happened in the last three years is that we as a government have through the better management of the Australian economy made inroads into these problems. When you look at the rate of unemployment, it is down. That is a good thing. You would never hear the Labor Party saying, `It's good that it has gone as far as it has.' But it is a step in the right direction.

If you look at the circumstances for small business, they are much better today than they were. So they are being encouraged to go out and give somebody a job. We are not, for example, running programs like Working Nation, which spent billions of dollars, under a Labor government, giving people pretend jobs or training them for jobs that did not exist, and then pretending that the problem was fixed. We have certainly cut expenditure, but in the Job Network we have set up a much better system which is genuinely helping people. So we have advanced the cause.

My colleague the Minister for Employment Services, who is also going to speak on this motion, has done a great job in the time that he has been the minister. He probably got a letter from the Prime Minister saying, `You're now in charge of Job Network. What are we going to do to make it a better system?' That, for the Labor Party, again, is a secret, cynical, diabolical plan. I actually think that that is a fair question to ask the minister, and he has done a great job and deserves credit for doing that. What we as a government want to do is to build on those reforms.

There are options in the paper for looking at what you do for people who are unemployed and at the inflexibilities of the award system. That is a fact of life. The Labor Party likes to say that this government is against the interests of people who are low paid—the old defence `offence is the best form of defence'. When you look at what happened to people on low incomes at the bottom of the award scale when Labor was in office over 13 years, they actually lost purchasing value in their wage packets. Labor is always saying, `We're going to look after the low paid.' As that very interesting book called Out of the Rut describes in its opening paragraph, the consequences of Labor's policies over those 13 years was that people at the bottom end of the scale were worse off.

We are attacked for having ideas, but we have had more than ideas; we actually have a few runs on the board. Not only have we got unemployment down, but if you look at the circumstances of the low paid the increase in wages after inflation—in other words, the purchasing value of those wage packets—has actually gone up by five per cent. That is a tremendous result.

What I say to people who are genuinely concerned about this—instead of people just wanting to make political points—is that, if you look at our record in the first three years, that ought to give people some reassurance that sensible reform really does give people an advantage. It really does start to address the problems. So in the paper I have presented, I have looked at expanding on that. Obviously we have a clear policy for implementation and we introduced that during the election. People have voted for that and since the election the Labor Party has spent a lot of time trying to prevent us implementing that policy.

I have also said to the Prime Minister, `This is an intractable problem and we need to have a medium-term strategy.' I think that is something which should be encouraged from politicians. Too often people say, `The trouble with politics is they just look at the next two or three years.' I have said, `Why don't we think longer term?' It is a big problem. We are going to have to be very determined and resolute to really get this down. So we should also be thinking about our policies for the next election.

The opposition say that this is a secret plan. The letter envisages the idea that we would present a policy to put to people before the next election and they would vote on it. Is that a secret plan? I think that is a first-class way to go. In the letter I say to the Prime Minister, `You have finally given this country leadership by what you did in the lead-up to the 1998 campaign because you outlined a plan. You told people in advance.' There were some parts that people did not like—the GST—and some parts they did like—the $13 billion income tax cuts; that's a great idea—and cutting the costs for regional Australia in reducing the cost of diesel fuel.

The great thing about it was that we had a plan, we were up-front, we told people what it was and they supported us. That is a big change in the way Australian politics has been managed in recent years. I think it is an approach to be encouraged. What my letter to the Prime Minister says is, `You've done it once, what about thinking about doing it again on the question of unemployment?' That is not a secret, cynical plan; that is a tremendous approach, a frank and honest approach to dealing with a significant and difficult problem for the country.

The sad thing for the Labor Party is that they had 13 years to do something about it and when the Leader of the Opposition was asked today what is his sort of approach, on the question of productivity he said that basically that is it; that is as far as you can go. That is the most nonsensical, stupid thing I have heard him say for a long time, and he has said a lot of things.

`Productivity' is an economists' term, but let us put it in laymen's terms. What produc tivity is all about is simply trying to encourage people to do things better at work. That makes their businesses more efficient, that is good for business and it will encourage business to invest more and to create more jobs. If we can do that, if our businesses are more productive, then the people who work in those businesses can enjoy higher pay. It is a simple statement but it is an important statement. But the Labor Party says, `No, we've gone as far as we can.' They were not just holding up my letter today during question time; they were holding up a white flag. They are saying, `No more ideas. We can't do any more. What we should do is go back and do what we did when we were in office.' We reject that. The Australian people have rejected that.

We are proud of this letter. We are proud that this is a government which has ideas and is prepared to discuss them. We are prepared to start with a clean sheet and genuinely concern ourselves about people who are unemployed. The unemployed in this country have been punished enough by Labor and the politics of Labor. It is about time they were given a fair go. We are absolutely determined that we are going to press on. Unemployed people will get a fairer go under this government. That motion deserves to be thrown out and I look forward to having the numbers for its amendment.

talk.start.para: —I rise to speak in support of the motion moved by the Leader of the Opposition and to speak against the amendment moved by the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business. In doing so, I also point out that the failure of the Prime Minister to respond to a very serious motion going to censure reflects what I think is the arrogance that now permeates the Howard government in its second term.

speech.para: Since the last election, slowly but surely we have seen a sense of arrogance and contempt for the Australian public become part and parcel of the operation of the Howard government. I say that in the context of a very firm view in my mind that any sense of a veil of decency that the Prime Minister has sought to cloak himself with following his election in March 1996 has been torn apart and thrown out the window since the election of October 1998.

If you have any doubts about that sense of inclusiveness, and the desire to rule and to represent all Australians as one Australian, then I need only refer in passing to a decision of the Prime Minister this week to put himself above all citizens of Australia in the jubilee year of Australian citizenship—the 50th year since the Chifley Labor government brought in the Migration Act, which was so central to the building of Australia and so central to our sense of decency and inclusiveness. I refer not to the contemptuous action of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business alone but to what I regard as a disgraceful endeavour by the Prime Minister to impose his own will on the whole Australian community. I refer to the fact that the Prime Minister, despite undertakings about inclusiveness, has instructed the Australian community that he alone will draft a new preamble to the Constitution that all Australians are supposed to identify with, that all Australians are supposed to stand up and defend and that all Australians ought to have a sense of ownership about. That is a disgrace.

That action really reflects the nature of this government. We have here today a government caught out in a game of duplicity. It is a government going back on its election promises to the people of Australia. It is a government that is prepared to further squeeze the less fortunate in the Australian community.

I think it is about time that, as a result of our actions in exposing the dead hand of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, we have a constructive debate about the major problem confronting the Australian community at the moment. I want to deal with the facts. Let us deal with the bleak picture that confronts Australia's unemployed and, more importantly, their families at this particular point in time. Let us go to the real, hard edge of unemployment—the issue of long-term unemployment. Let us deal with the facts as they stand today.

Today the long-term unemployment figures were released. What do they show? They show the biggest proportionate increase in long-term unemployment, up to 34 per cent, which is more than one in three, since January 1995. That is a bleak picture. Long-term unemployment in one month has jumped by almost 11,000. We now have in Australia almost 240,000 Australians—men and women who want to work, who know their responsibilities and who accept their reciprocal obligation—who are confronting a situation where the government's only action is to inflict pain and punishment.

It gets worse. It is not only about the raw figures relating to unemployment of a long-term nature for men and women; it also goes to the duration of long-term unemployment. These figures show that the ranks of those who have been unemployed for between 52 and 104 weeks have also risen by 6,100. More importantly, and I suppose the really distressing feature, is that between July 1996—just after Working Nation was slashed by the Howard government in its first budget—and July 1998 the duration of unemployment of a long-term nature has increased by seven weeks.

What we require on the basis of those figures and the failure of this government to match our jobs growth is action now. I do not mean what the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business suggests today, in his defence of the indefensible, in saying that this is the third-term agenda; we require action now. We require concerted action by a government that is prepared to listen to the Australian community, to take advice and to base its approach to a long-term strategy for making significant inroads into reducing unemployment in Australia on a sense of cooperation and partnership. That is what it is about: a sense of cooperation and partnership. That is exceptionally important because the facts spell out in no uncertain terms that this government has failed the Australian community. It has failed the working men and women of this great country on the employment front.

Total jobs growth in the Howard government's first 35 months was 54 per cent of that achieved by the Labor Party in its last 35 months of government. Full-time jobs growth in the first 35 months of a Howard government was 40 per cent of what the Labor Party achieved in its last 35 months of government. Part-time jobs growth—and these are decent jobs; I do not question the importance of part-time employment—has been slightly better at 74 per cent of what we achieved in the last 35 months of government.

I think the Australian community understands its responsibilities. The serious question that the Australian community is looking for an answer to goes to the capacity to lead, to involve all of the Australian community and to come up with decent programs based on a sense of cooperation, partnership and leadership. That is what is missing from this secret document that we forced the Australian government to release yesterday. I say that because it is a secret document that flies in the face of the very principle that I have spoken about: the sense of the Australian way of life, which means a fair go for all of the Australians who know their responsibilities and who are prepared to pull their weight.

Let us go to the issue of industrial relations. Strangely, unlike the other side of the House, I actually respect the independence of the judiciary. As a trade union official of 20 years, there were many decisions that I did not like, but I had to cop them on the chin. We now have a proposal by this government to dismantle the Industrial Relations Commission and to appoint friends from the Productivity Commission, from Treasury and from the Reserve Bank board to make decisions about how the less well off in this community—the low paid workers—ought to be looked after.

The problem is that, when you look at the appointments by this government to a range of boards, there is no impartiality. There is no sense of people being appointed to those boards on the basis of what they offer to the boards. More importantly, they were appointed on the basis of what they offered in donations to the coalition government. We are now expected to cop a situation in which this government is suggesting to the low paid in this community that the safety net wage increases ought to be determined by their mates—people like Hugh Morgan. I know his approach to industrial relations from my experience as a trade union official.

Let us make a comparison between what is acceptable to this government when it comes to looking after the low paid and what is acceptable when it comes to looking after their mates whom they have appointed on a political basis in an unfortunate endeavour to politicise the independence of the Australian Public Service. That is what it is about. We have had the politicisation of the Australian Public Service, and now we are going to have mates determining wage increases for the low paid in the Australian community.

I want to touch in passing on the question of safety net wage increases. In the decision of 1996-97, the living wage case, the commission awarded $10 per week. The Howard government supported $8 per week. In the living wage case of 1997-98 what we got was an increase of $14 per week. In the current wage case the government is supporting $8 per week. I believe in a little bit of equity. In doing so I also raise the new approach to looking after Australian workers. When I listened to the minister for workplace relations today on the question of industrial relations and employment, all I could hear him talking about was the wage packet. I suppose that really reflects the view of those stuck in the 1930s, 1940s, 1950s and 1960s—the period up to the election of the Hawke Labor government in March 1983. What the union movement learned from that period is that you can actually influence the standard of living of the people you represent by more than just direct negotiations with employers and by more than just direct argument in the Industrial Relations Commission.

That is why we, in our approach to genuine tax reform, in rejecting the dead hand of the job destroying GST, actually sought to revolutionise employment and the incentives to get the unemployed back to work as we move towards the 21st century. We wanted to build on our leadership of our 13 years in government: the way we completely reformed the social security system in Australia, the way we completely reformed the health care system in Australia, and the way we completely reformed the industrial relations system in Australia. We threw out of the window the industrial war of the Fraser years, when the current Prime Minister of Australia was one of the driving forces of industrial war in Australia as the Treasurer of this great nation. That is why I say to the Australian community, `Examine this document, but think about what Australia really deserves as we approach the 21st century.' We as a community do not believe in inflicting pain and punishment on the disadvantaged in the community. We actually believe in a fair go. That is why we support an industrial relations system that says that for a fair day's work you get a fair day's pay.

That is why we suggest to the government of the day that, having acknowledged it in this document, you ought to embrace and develop the Labor Party's tax credit proposal, because it is about putting genuine incentives into the community to attract people back to work. It is about trying to improve the standard of living of Australian workers by something more than the total focus by the minister for workplace relations on the wage packet. It is about a new approach to a sense of decency in Australia. It is about the Australian government saying, yes, it will use all its arms of government not just to develop an employment strategy across all portfolios but, more importantly, in association with that dedication and decisiveness, to actually create the incentives that encourage and attract Australia's unemployed back to work.

I very much agree with that particular approach because it builds on what we sought to develop in our last 13 years of government. It really is about trying to say to the Australian community, `Look, we are a government of the 21st century. We are not a government based on class war and divisiveness. We want to try to make serious inroads into creating an employment strategy that involves the Australian community and basically says to that community, "Thank you for accepting your side of the bargain. It is now for us to face up to our responsibilities to deliver on our side of the bargain."'

When you talk about an employment strategy, there are a couple of key aspects that the minister for employment ought to be talking about rather than attacking those in the community who need help. We ought to be talking about higher economic growth, selling Australia's exports overseas in places such as Asia, supporting industry in regional Australia, making sure that we skill the Australian work force and making sure that we have an ongoing process that ensures that, if someone loses their job, we have a transitional program based on education and training that guarantees the opportunity right throughout their whole working life to move from one job to another. That is the nature of the labour force today. The days of being employed by one employer have long gone, and we have to make sure that we build into a new vision for Australia a capacity to look after people when they lose their job. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —If the member for Batman and shadow minister for employment wants bipartisanship, if he wants generosity, if he wants national unity, why does he constantly accuse the government of a complete lack of goodwill? The two things simply do not go together.

speech.para: The member for Batman made a much better speech yesterday before he had actually read Peter Reith's letter to the Prime Minister. Obviously the problem is that, on reading the letter of the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business to the Prime Minister, he has lost nearly all of his points of attack. His case was so weak that he had hardly gone 2½ minutes when he started to criticise the government over the preamble to the Constitution. If the member for Batman has a problem with the Prime Minister's draftsmanship of the preamble, he is quite welcome to make a submission. If members opposite would like to make a contribution to the preamble, make a submission to the Prime Minister. Members opposite believe that any president, under their preferred model of an Australian republic, will be nominated and members of the public can make nominations to this star chamber committee. Why doesn't he make a submission on the preamble, as he suggests the general public should when it comes to nominating a president?

I am very proud to support my senior colleague the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business, I am very proud to support the Prime Minister, on this motion because the fact is that this is a government of ideas and innovation. This is a government which is prepared to slaughter the sacred cows of employment policy. This is a government which is not mindlessly adopting the orthodoxy that the way to boost employment is to cut wages or to madly increase government spending. This is a government which believes in increasing the wages of workers and it also believes in intelligently redirecting government spending.

The difference between the government and the opposition on this is quite clear. We have an orderly policy development process. Why shouldn't the Prime Minister ask the minister for employment to come up with ideas? Why shouldn't the minister for employment write at length to the Prime Minister outlining a wide range of policies, all of which should be given serious consideration? Why shouldn't the Prime Minister then respond by saying, `Let's bring some of them forward urgently and let's give others further consideration'?

There is a sharp difference between this government—which knows how to create policy, which knows how to actually get policy from the idea stage into practice—and members opposite, who are incapable of having an idea without rushing off to the publishers. The truth is that the constant flow of books and articles from members opposite is a sign of the seething tension inside the Labor Party and the fact that members opposite are now openly contemptuous of the weak and pathetic leadership of the Leader of the Opposition, a man who they know bends with every breeze, a man who constantly goes to the book launches of his colleagues and is left in Ros Kelly's unfortunate position of having to endorse the cover but not the contents.

The problem with members opposite is not that they believe in nothing but that they believe in everything. For every loony tune idea that is put up, there is someone opposite who is prepared to say, `Yes, I support that.' On Telstra, we have the member for Melbourne, who wants to sell it, and other members who want to keep it in public ownership. We have the member for Batman sneering at McJobs; we have the member for Melbourne quite rightly saying that these can build a realistic career.

We have the member for Werriwa saying that Work for the Dole is a good idea and then we have the Leader of the Opposition saying, `No, no, we can't do this.' We have the member for Melbourne saying the Labor Party needs to cut its links with the union movement and then we have the rest of them supinely echoing the call of the trade union heavies to simply do what they want.
Opposition members interjecting—

talk.start.para: —The members opposite should be judged on their record. I do not say for a second that there were not some good things that the former government did.

—The minister will resume his seat. This is the first time I have had to interrupt a minister in the process of this debate. I remind members of the general warning I issued. I will not again issue a warning to the member for the Northern Territory. The minister has the call.

—There were some good things that the Labor government did. I suppose, if you are in government for 13 years, you are bound to get something right. We will concede that, and what we expect of members opposite is some skerrick of generosity towards the policies that this government is putting into place.

speech.para: Members opposite should be judged not on their words but on their record. What was Labor's record? Eleven per cent unemployment—the highest unemployment since the Great Depression. In 13 years the disposable income of average families dropped by $100 a week. This is a pretty pathetic record for people who say they want to support the battler, people who say they want to support the little man. Under the former government, the rich got richer and the poor got less poor but they got more locked into their poverty. That was the tragedy of 13 years of Labor government and that is what the minister for employment, the Prime Minister and the rest of the government are trying to change.

For all their protestations of care and concern for the long-term unemployed, the Working Nation program was an expensive failure. It was a treadmill. It was a turnstile. The long-term unemployed went in these programs, they clocked on, they clocked off at the end of six months, and the only change was that the statistician no longer called them long-term unemployed. It was a con. I do not deny for a second that members opposite had good intentions, but the fact is their programs failed and our programs should be given a chance to succeed.

Why are members opposite so locked into this culture of carping criticism and complaint? They are simply taking yet again the messages from Trades Hall. They are simply demonstrating in opposition what they demonstrated in government time and time again—that when it came to a fight with the trade unions they lacked ticker. It is easy to understand why. As members of the government have pointed out, 52 per cent of that frontbench are former trade union officials; 100 per cent of the parliamentary Labor Party are members of a union.

We have had this week the Labor caucus unanimously endorsing the actions of the CFMEU, the socialist aristocrats who believe in hereditary jobs in the coal industry. This is a disgraceful thing for people who believe in employment growth, who say they want to help the battler to get a job, to do, because the CFMEU is trying to stop decent Queenslanders from working. It is disgraceful that members opposite cannot see behind the union facade and the union rhetoric.

This government has a good story to tell. This government has a proud record. Over the last 2½ years we have created nearly 400,000 jobs. Productivity has increased three per cent a year on average under this government; it increased by a mere 1.5 per cent a year under the former government. Inflation has averaged one per cent under this government; it averaged five per cent under the former government. And this is the figure that most gives the lie to their protestations: under this government wages have increased an average of 2.5 per cent a year. Under the former government average wages went up by less than half a per cent. So wages for the little man, for the average Australian, have increased five times as fast under this government than under the government that claimed to be the battler's friend.

I do not want to engage in sterile statistical argument, but the fact is that members opposite know that Working Nation was a failure. They know that Working Nation programs cost tens of thousands of dollars for every successful outcome. Work for the Dole, by contrast, is an effective policy, an effective program, good for the people who participate in it and good value for the taxpayer who funds it.

Work for the Dole is just one of a suite of policies that this government is implementing to bring down unemployment. There are three broad strands that we are pursuing. The first is to have a buoyant economy and that is why we cut $10 billion out of the bloated spending program that we inherited from the Leader of the Opposition. Did we get any help? Was there any support from members opposite when we tried to pare back government spending, when we tried to ensure that interest rates came down so that the economy would boom and job seekers would have a chance? Not at all.

The second thing we are doing is that we are trying to produce a more productive work force. That means industrial relations reform so that workers can work smarter and earn more. Was there any cooperation from members opposite? None at all.

talk.start.para: —Except the member for Dickson.

—The member for Dickson provided some last minute cooperation. We have the education and training reforms championed by the Minister for Education, Training and Youth Affairs. Has there been any support for him? Has there been any acknowledgment of the fact that apprenticeships and traineeships are at an all-time record—the highest in Australia's history? Of course there has not. Has there been any support for the Job Network—that network of 300 community based organisations like Mission Australia, the Salvation Army, the Brotherhood of St Laurence, Anglicare, Centrecare? Has there been any acknowledgment of the good work that they have done? Nothing at all.

speech.para: The final and perhaps most important arm of our policy is to create a culture of work in this country. We have to end the idea that the world owes people a living. We must end this notion that we are doing good for people by telling them that they do not have to help themselves. That is why mutual obligation is perhaps the signature principle of this government. Mutual obligation could be described as mutual commitment. It is about empowering people so that they can make the most of their lives.

It must have been very difficult for the Leader of the Opposition to deliver that tirade we have just heard from him. He attacked the GST, but he knows the GST is right and good and necessary for Australia—otherwise he was lying in 1985. He attacked industrial relations flexibility and he knows that we need more flexibility in the workplace—otherwise he was fibbing when the former government made tentative steps in this direction. He attacked education reform. I suppose you can understand that because he was such a weak and embarrassingly ineffective employment and education minister. He has attacked welfare reform in his speech today—even though he knows that too is absolutely necessary.

But most of all he has attacked the sincerity and the decency of every member of this government. That is the thing which must have stuck most in his throat, because the Leader of the Opposition grew up in the tradition of the Moral Rearmament movement, a worthy and a decent movement, which believes in building bridges and networks and in working with people to create a better world. Why isn't the Leader of the Opposition prepared to start that process in this parliament by attributing the same decency and sincerity to us that he claims for himself?

It must have been embarrassing and humiliating for the Leader of the Opposition to go through that performance of quivering self-righteousness when he knows that the accusations he has made are simply untrue. This government has not cut wages; we have increased wages. We have not cut pensions; we have maintained them at 25 per cent of average weekly earnings. We are the first government to enshrine in legislation that commitment. He said that we were harassing the disadvantaged. We are helping the disadvantaged by making the changes which are necessary to give them a fair go.

I was not intending to use this but, given the self-righteousness opposite, given the battlers' friend's prattle that we got opposite, let me simply read from the Daily Telegraph of Friday, 11 December an article titled `A story to dine out on':

Spotted dining in Canberra's most exclusive restaurant, the Oak Room, were Labor Party stalwarts and former union heavies, hereditary peers, Martin Ferguson and Simon Crean, accompanied by two lobbyists. The pair—
this is the member for Batman and the member for Hotham—
both of whom have built a considerable reputation and fairly hefty salaries by fighting for the battlers, spent almost five hours on Wednesday night leaning back in the padded armchairs.
Armchairs that no doubt bore a distinct resemblance to those which they criticised so much for appearing in the Prime Minister's office. The article continued:
The pair left their establishment with their guests well fed.

The total bill: $1,524—just the way the battlers eat. The member for Batman and the member for Hotham are entitled to a good feed, but they are not entitled to the sanctimony, the hypocrisy and the cant which has marked their approach to this government.

The opposition accuse this government of having ideas. I am proud to plead guilty. The opposition accuse this government of having a serious policy making process. Of course I plead guilty. And I move:

The year 2000 amendments that have returned from the Senate are agreed to by both the government and the opposition. talk.start.para: —The member for Banks interjected when the member for Corangamite shook hands with the Prime Minister that he should count his fingers after the encounter. We might extend that and say that all those people in the Australian electorate who metaphorically shook hands with the Prime Minister during the last election should, on two counts, count their fingers.

speech.para: Yesterday I spoke in the debate on Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1998-99. That bill provides for $19,443,000 to be appropriated—if this bill goes through—for the purposes of a community education and information program in relation to the new tax system. That was, in fact, first advanced in the $10 million advance to the Minister for Finance and Administration. As I indicated previously, by the end of the 1997-98 tax year only about $250,000 of that $10 million had been brought forward; in fact, only about $57,000 had been spent. The minister's fund is to be used for `urgent and unforeseen circumstances'. It was certainly urgent in a party-political sense to expend not $10 million but almost $20 million on this advertising campaign, but it certainly was not unforeseen.

The Auditor-General pointed out that surely the Treasury could have foreseen that these funds were to be expended in the next year and that, therefore, in the last budget proper appropriation should have been made. It is my contention that this is an expropriation of funds—they were used for an illegitimate purpose. Labor has been criticised by the government in the past for spending money on information programs. I make two points. Firstly, there generally was a $5 million cap on those education programs. Secondly, the education programs came into being only after the legislation had been passed through the parliament, and only at the proper and appropriate time. So, after the legislation was passed, the community was able to be informed of the details of that legislation. In contradistinction, this set of information programs went out prior to the last election and were used as a party-political tool by the coalition. So it is indeed true that in relation to the $19,443,000 people should at that time have counted their fingers because it is money that was spent for party-political purposes.

The Prime Minister has, in days gone by, accused the Labor Party of running campaigns where they spent moneys. In fact, this occurred in 1986 in relation to Labor's program which had already been legislated and been put into practice. The present Prime Minister said in relation to the then Prime Minister, Mr Hawke:

. . . he will undoubtedly fail to tell the House in the outrageously misleading advertising on taxation which is being paid for by the Australian taxpayer and not being paid, as it should, by the Australian Labor Party . . .

The key points I make are, firstly, that we had a cap on those programs. Secondly, we had actually legislated for them—it was through—and then there was a properly run education program. This massive program, a lot of which was deceiving, was used as a party-political tool. Therefore, rather than seeing this as being an appropriation of these moneys, I see it as being an expropriation of the moneys.

I also point out in relation to these matters of what is proper in the use of public moneys for advertising by a government that, in 1995, the Prime Minister spoke of a need to have some kind of control. I quote from a background brief. The Prime Minister said:
Today's Shadow Cabinet meeting in Gladstone decided that, in Government, we will ask the Auditor-General to draw up new guidelines on what is an appropriate use of taxpayers' money in this area.

Note the timing: 1995, before he was in government. It was probably part of his so-called headland speech program. He said that there would be new guidelines drawn up by the Auditor-General. It is now, as we well know, 1999. There have been no guidelines drawn up by the Auditor-General because the Prime Minister did not keep this promise. This is obviously another non-core promise. This is the difference between what he said in opposition and what he has done in government. The Auditor-General, in looking at this expenditure, indicated:

. . . in the interests of public accountability and confidence, it is necessary to establish . . . Parliamentary review of government information and advertising arrangements to assist in determining appropriate guidelines for taxpayer funded programs.

Given the extraordinary way in which public moneys were effectively expropriated to be used in a way they should not have been before the last election, I think it is utterly appropriate that that parliamentary review take place. It is utterly appropriate that strong and strict guidelines, in conformity with what operated whilst we were in power for 13 years, be incorporated in order to stop this government expropriating even more moneys prior to the next election.

I indicate that, because I was not able to speak in the debate on the GST or in the address-in-reply, I will deal with the GST in some simple detail now in the time left to me. I will start by quoting from a general background paper on this vast ream of bills before us. The background paper indicates that Dr Neil Warren, Associate Professor of Economics at the University of New South Wales, is an acknowledged expert—acknowledged by the government and the community—and gives a useful definition of the GST. It is useful because it is very simple, very clear and very direct. Professor Warren said:

A GST is a tax which is levied on goods and services consumed by domestic households. While the tax is collected at each stage in the production and distribution process, a credit is given for the GST on inputs and refunds are given for GST on exports. As a result, only households bear the tax.
It is very simple, very clear and very stark, and the last point is a key point that the Labor Party has underlined.

This is a regressive tax on Australian families and Australian households. The coalition is firmly in support of the GST because it takes virtually all input tax off all business in Australia. It puts the entire burden of the indirect tax system almost uniformly on Australian households.

This proposal has had a long history. The Treasurer presented the 16 or so bills abbreviated as ANTS—A New Tax System for Australia—and he stressed that this was a new and supposedly vital way of going about things. In fact, this is a return to the past, a return to the European Economic Community, a return to the models that were operative in the 1960s and 1970s. Indeed in 1975 the Asprey committee report recommended that a value added tax of 10 per cent be brought in. They also recommended a range of other things such as capital gains tax and fringe benefits tax. They said there should be a European style value added tax at 10 per cent. That was back in 1975—24 years the Treasurer has cast back into history for the preferred model. A lot has happened in the interim. That was not taken up by the Whitlam government. It was looked at by the Fraser government.

In 1977 the Fraser government launched their fistful of dollars campaign, where massive tax cuts were promised to the Australian people. Just as I started this speech by saying that if you metaphorically shook hands with the then Treasurer and now Prime Minister, the member for Bennelong, you would have to be careful and count your fingers after it, the Australian electorate discovered in 1978 when the budget was brought down when John Howard was Treasurer that all of those tax cuts were taken away—they disappeared into the ether. I do not think they were meant in the first place but they helped to gull the electorate.

In 1981 the then Treasurer, who never could get anything substantial through cabinet and who is now acting retrospectively to try to make up for his whole career as Treasurer, rejected the Asprey committee recommendations in a further report that had been put forward. And they laid out fairly clearly that there are three simple solutions when you are looking at expanding tax in the indirect area. The first is to extend the existing wholesale tax to additional goods and some services. The second is a general retail sales tax. The third is a value added tax imposed at all stages of production and distribution of goods and services. They are three things that have been looked at over time.
We note that right now the Prime Minister has gone back to that value added tax at 10 per cent. What did he say in 1981 in regard to it? I quote from the Bills Digest:
Mr Howard said that `a multi-stage VAT was rejected fairly quickly because it would have imposed an enormous paper work burden on both taxpayers and collecting authorities.'

It is not 1981, it is 1999, but that same point holds true all these years later. It does involve an enormous paperwork burden on both taxpayers and collecting authorities. And although it is projected as being efficient it is in fact very inefficient in those areas. He rejected a general retail sales tax which was put forward in 1985 by another Treasurer, saying it involved `a very expensive licensing system, and the necessity for a significant increase in the number of taxpaying units'. So in 1981 Mr Howard went to his third preferred base. He said:
. . . if the indirect tax base was to be broadened, the simplest method would be to extend the existing wholesale sales tax to some goods now exempt and to impose a tax on selected services.

To make up for his want of a concerted position and his inability to push through what we have been told is his underlying preferred approach he opted for just an extension of that existing system. But he gave a further point, and this one is critical. It was critical then, when in 1981 the current Prime Minister as Treasurer had taken inflation to heights we had not seen before, when he took unemployment to heights we had not seen before—into double digits. At that time he said that the fundamental reason underlying the government's decision not to proceed with a greater reliance on indirect taxes `was its concern at the impact on inflation and inflationary expectations of any significant shift towards reliance on indirect taxation'. That was true in 1981, and it is true in 1999.

The Treasurer, Mr Costello, on the basis of Treasury advice, has said that there will be only a 1.9 per cent inflation effect. We know, particularly from the material that has been brought before the Senate, that it is far more likely to be a four to five per cent inflationary effect and that the compensation mechanisms that have been proposed will not in fact be able to deal with this massive change in the indirect tax system. So in 1981 the Treasurer—then Mr Howard—preferred just an extension of the wholesale sales tax system. He has now turned to his really preferred model, and his really preferred model can still be seen as having the main disadvantages that there were in 1981: the fact that it was administratively burdensome and that it would have an impact on inflation and on inflationary expectations.

Even in a low inflationary environment largely the result of Labor's last years in office, even in that environment, that situation is still true. This government has not proposed a fair, simple, straightforward set of tax changes. Those tax changes could have been made, and they could have been simple, fair, direct, straightforward and equitable. This GST proposal, the bills that are currently before the Senate, are none of those things and they should be rejected. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —In speaking to the Appropriation Bill (No. 3) 1998-99 , the Appropriation (Parliamentary Departments) Bill (No. 2) 1998-99, and the Appropriation Bill (No. 4) 1998-99 today, I point out that we in North Queensland are in very necessitous circumstances as a result of the protracted flooding and the continuous—now over a three-year period—series of cyclonic conditions and very heavy rainfall. The net result of this recent disaster has been that in large areas of North Queensland—Far North Queensland, I would emphasise—some 20 per cent of the cane has been seriously damaged, maybe as much as 30 per cent has fallen over and will have very low sugar content. Subsequently the growers will get very little return for the cane that they will harvest later in the year.

speech.para: In the banana industry, there have been massive losses. Probably 50 or 60 per cent of production in Far North Queensland, which represents about 80 per cent of Australia's production, will be lost. There will be no production for another six or seven months. Because all the trees that had banana bunches on them have fallen over, it will take that much time for the smaller trees to become big enough to grow bunches and then to have the bunches yield. Mr Deputy Speaker Nehl, as you are most familiar with, and one of the great champions of, the banana industry, you would understand what I am saying. The losses will be such that there will be no production for another seven or eight months.

It proves the great importance of the New South Wales industry to Australia, because we would be under terrific pressure to bring in bananas from overseas if it were not for the resilience of the New South Wales industry. That is a position which has been held on many occasions in Far North Queensland and, I might add, Mr Deputy Speaker, somewhat as a result of your own endeavours and visits to Far North Queensland, during which you have put forward that proposition, and it has been listened to.

We need access to social security payments. If these people have no money, they should have the same right to receive social security payments as all other Australians. I do not refer simply to farmers but to the other follow-on industries that are intimately involved, such as the transport industry and others.

The natural disaster provisions have been triggered. They should be flowing through as expeditiously as possible. I am very familiar with the exceptional circumstance provision, because I represent areas that have been ravaged by drought. What happens is that we get no rainfall, the grass loses nutrition, the cattle and sheep do not grow, and therefore we have the terrible ravages and losses that drought entails.

On the coast, where we have too much rain, the sugar level in the cane—the nutritional level—falls dramatically and we have exactly the same phenomenon that occurs with drought in the western areas, which are exceptional circumstance areas. So the exceptional circumstance provision should be flowing into these areas in exactly the same way that occurs when there is drought in the western areas.

The honourable member for Dawson and I are well aware of the phenomenon of falling sugar content in cane. It is not just a phenomenon which is occurring because of the present circumstances; it has been very seriously exacerbated at the moment but it has been occurring for some time and it needs a more detailed, in-depth approach.

Agricultural industries are being driven into the usual cycle of droughts, fire, flood and devastation of various types, including the world market devastation which occurs when the world price for a commodity drops abysmally. This is the first time in Australia's history that we have been driven into these situations since King O'Malley introduced the Commonwealth Bank in 1902. To date, we have had special help banks available to us which have provided us with finance to get through these difficult periods.

If we are asked to work in a free market, we can ride the roller-coaster; let there be no doubt about that. The very great and famous Sir Joseph McEvoy, probably the greatest agricultural leader that this country has seen during this century, would say to me, as a young member of parliament, again and again, `Every single time in Australia's history that an agricultural industry has borrowed money, they have paid back every single cent of those borrowings.' In other words, in the long term, we are always viable, but in the short term, we can incur massive losses that are losses not only to us but to the Australian nation.

Before Mr Keating and Mr Kerin abolished the minimum price scheme for wool, we were getting $6,000 million a year for our wool; after their cavalier and irresponsible actions, we were getting $3,000 million a year for our wool. We are being asked to carry those massive losses. The net result is that, even if the price for wool were to come back, we only have 60 per cent of the sheep numbers that we had in those days. Our cattle numbers are down by 30-odd per cent on what they were 12 or 15 years ago. So not only is the country losing money because individual farmers are losing money but there are collective losses to Australia because the sheep and cattle herds that were once there are no longer there. In a lot of the cane farming areas, I suspect we will see them running cattle again, which produces nothing like the sort of wealth that they are producing at present, because a lot of cane farmers are simply going to fall over. They will not be able to continue; they will not be able to plant and carry on their activities.

In agriculture, not only do we have this roller-coaster that we have to ride but the point must be made with as much force as I can muster that when we ride the down side of the roller-coaster there is an extra down side added to it because we have to carry interest rates. So the bottom curve is exaggerated by the interest rates that have to be added to it, but the top curve is truncated by taxation. So we have a truncated top curve of the roller-coaster and an elongated bottom curve.

I mention some of the great leaders we have had in Australia: King O'Malley, Edward Theodore, Ben Chifley, John McEwen and Bjelke-Petersen. As I mentioned previously, the Commonwealth Bank was set up by King O'Malley. The Commonwealth Development Bank was set up by Artie Fadden, another great leader of the party to which I belong. PIBA and the AIDC were set up by John McEwen. In my state, QIDC was added by the Bjelke-Petersen government. God was kind enough to allow me a small part in the formation of that great bank which, sadly, operated only for two or three years before the Goss government commercialised it and flogged it off as part of the economic rationalist policies of the opposition in this place. Of course, one of the major reasons why they are the opposition in this place is those policies.

At the present time, the government can borrow money at around five per cent and is borrowing money at around five per cent. If a special help bank existed, that money could be parcelled out to people in Far North Queensland who are on their knees, people who are producing ordinarily about $1,500 million worth of sugar and horticultural production for our nation. These people could be given a fair go. All they are asking is to access money at around five per cent.

When I walked down a main street in Brisbane the other day, I noticed there are advertisements all over the place for money around five per cent for housing in Brisbane. So the money is out there for that purpose. But when these people try to access it, they are told, `No, you don't pay five per cent; you pay eight, nine, 10 per cent. That's what you pay.' Because a lot of them are now in questionable circumstances, you can rest assured there will be a 2½ per cent imposition upon that.

So we have the government able to borrow money at five per cent, able to pass it out to these people at five per cent, and yet they have to borrow money at figures around 10 per cent. We are not asking the government for any taxpayers' money. We are not asking, from these appropriations, that money be taken from anyone else and given to us; we are just asking that we be able to access the same terms and conditions as the householder in Brisbane.

When we set up the QIDC, we did very extensive research and study. It was very interesting that the three departments involved—my own department, the Department of Primary Industries and the Premier's Department—all said that over a 12- or 13-year time frame the safest sector of lending was agricultural lending. If you know what you are doing it is safer even than housing lending. Once again, we are not asking for any special treatment; all we are asking for is a fair go. Now all of those banks have been sold off, flogged off, corporatised and gotten rid of, so we do not have any of those banks any more. We need access to cheap, long, low interest loans.

When we had the floods in Brisbane, there was no difficulty in finding $70 million or $80 million at the drop of a hat. Even in Alice Springs a very substantial amount of money was handed out immediately by the government. If we are talking about $200 million being freed up for these people, then the interest at five per cent would be $10 million a year. If we subsidised that to the tune of $5 million, then those people would be able to have interest at 2½ per cent and they would be much more relaxed.

I quote Delmo Tarditi, Chairman of the Canegrowers Council at Tully, who—before we got back on the helicopter, and I thank Minister Vale and Gavan O'Connor from the opposition for visiting the area—said, `Even if we don't get any money, people are so desperately scared and frightened and morale is at such a low ebb that even the very presence of the minister and the spokesman for the opposition is of great importance to us.' I say that not because Delmo wanted us to visit there but because he was emphasising just how extremely serious is their plight.

In addressing the appropriations today, it seems to me that we constantly do structural things down here, such as the GST, which—and I have heard the arguments—may be a very good thing for Australia. But it is our job to make the cake bigger. John McEwen, in one of his landmark speeches in this House said, `The job of government is to provide jobs for its people.' When Edward Theodore wrote to Ben Chifley when he became Prime Minister of Australia, he said, `Ben, please, the job of government is, above all else, to provide jobs for its people.'

In North Queensland—I cannot speak with authority for other parts of Australia—we have 126 million megalitres of rainfall run-off on the inland of the northern half of Queensland. I emphasis the inland, not the superwet belt where it rains all the time. To put that in perspective, the Murray-Darling system, which produces over 40 per cent of Australia's entire agricultural production, has only 20 million megalitres of water. So the inland part of my colleague the member for Dawson's electorate, the inland part of my own electorate, and the inland part of the member for Leichhardt's electorate have 126 million megalitres of water, and the Murray-Darling, producing nearly half of Australia's agricultural production, has only 20 million megalitres of water.

You can get on the great inland black soil plain that starts at Blackall and Barcaldine and you can go for 1,200 kilometres north on that plain. There are hardly any trees, it is as flat as a billiard table and it has rich, fertile black soil. Between Hughenden and Cloncurry it is 600 kilometres wide and it hits the gulf between Normanton and Burketown where it is still 300 or 400 kilometres wide.

Where there are arguably 40,000 farmers in the Murray-Darling, we have five farmers. I know them all. I could give their names to the House. I know all five of those brave little heroes up there. Recently when I was at the airport in Cairns, there were three Indonesian businessmen visiting and the new deputy head of the Department of State Development in Queensland in the new Beattie government was there. He wanted me to speak to them. I was very busy but he insisted, so I spoke to them.

To cut a long story short, they said that they would like very much to be able to do some prawn processing. Then they elaborated and said that they would really like to do some prawn farming. The said, `Would there be any part of the Queensland coastline in Far North Queensland, say north of Cairns, that would not be developed which we could use for this purpose?' I found that I could not look them in the eye. I found myself looking at the floor. I was ashamed and embarrassed because, out of that 3,700 kilometres of coastline, there are 10 kilometres that are developed, that is, Weipa and the port of Karumba.

On the same length of coastline, Thailand is producing $4,000 million of prawn product alone. The reason I could not look these people in the eye is that they come from a country where 100 million people will go to bed not hungry tonight but starving. A mere few hundred kilometres away—of course, western New Guinea is part of Indonesia—there are 130 million megalitres of water, hardly a single drop of which is being used, and there are 1,200 kilometres of plain about 400 or 500 kilometres wide on average not being used, except for about 200 or 300 acres of it. Yet here they are saying, `Please could we open up some prawn farming on this coastline?' They asked if any of it was being used. Not a single kilometre, except for those 10 with the two ports, is being utilised at all.

What we people of North Queensland can provide for Australia on those figures is at least $10,000 million worth of agricultural irrigation production from those river systems, that giant inland plain and projects such as those spoken of enthusiastically by the member for Dawson. They include the Urana Dam project, which I know is an excellent project; the Hells Gate stem; and in my own electorate the Ravenshoe Dam and the Richmond Dam. We can produce for you $10,000 million a year very easily, with minimal input of funds.

There is another site there which we have been approached about for the production of salt. I was quite staggered at the figures because from that area—which is about 70,000 acres and only varies about a metre or two metres in height and depth; it is as flat as a billiard table and it runs into the gulf—it would be fairly easy to produce $4,000 million dollars worth of salt.
