The silicon deposits at Shelbourne Bay have already been found by the mines and energy department to be worth $5,000 million a year to the Australian economy. The ethanol, which I spoke of in another place today, would be worth $1,000 million if it were put in as an additive to petrol to replace the lead. It is a much cheaper additive than the additives they are using at present. Prawn and fish farming, on the Thailand experience, would be worth $4,000 million a year.

Then there are the various mines that have been delayed. We just got news that Valhalla, the uranium mine at Mount Isa, has been knocked on the head by the Beattie government. The aluminium processing, which is pending and which would probably benefit the member for Dawson's area, the stainless steel plant, Valhalla, and Century all add up to another $2,000 million. I have just run over projects that are worth $27,000 million a year, every single year, forever to the Australian economy. We are not plucking figures out of the air here; these are things that have been researched in depth by the best engineering companies that Australia has produced. I am sure that other parts of Australia can come up with similar figures for their areas as well, most certainly the north of Western Australia.
I would like to conclude by reading a statement which was prepared by Ernie Bridge, the very famous President of the Watering Australia Foundation and a very great Australian, and me. It says:

That our country's great rivers should, on their journey to the sea, pay a small tribute to those people living along their banks. This great land of ours provides for its people the opportunity of properly developing their talents, both their natural assets and the great richness of character that God has given each and every one of them. That Australia becomes a bigger and more fascinating world, a world of wonder, hope and excitement. That we again unleash the wonderful aspirations and dreams that took our forefathers tens of thousands of miles away from their homes towards adventure and a new and bigger dream. That we affirm again that we are the descendants of a brave-hearted, enterprising and intrepid people. That we are the descendants of people who faced the misery of hardship and oppression and that who, in spite of it all, survived and prospered. That we are descendants of people who looked out through the narrow, grimy windowpanes of the old world to a clear, shimmering, golden vision of what might be.
(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I am actually sorry that I will only have about 10 minutes in this appropriations debate to speak because I would like to take the opportunity to speak on two related matters having a direct impact on the Commonwealth Department of Defence. They are both matters of the gravest concern and were brought to my attention by Paul and Marie Stokes of Lindum, in my electorate of Bowman. As well as being my constituents and electors of my seat, I am proud to be able to call them good friends of mine.

speech.para: These issues concern the Department of Defence at its very core. This is entirely appropriate as the Stokes family is a great military family. Each of their children has worn an Australian uniform with pride. Their eldest daughter is a captain in the Army Reserve, their son is a petty officer with the Royal Australian Navy and their second daughter is married to an Air Force officer. Their baby, Clare Frances Stokes, aged 18, of Lindum was a senior cadet under-officer with the 12th Regional Cadet Unit based out of Camp Hill in Brisbane. She was a level one instructor with the Australian Army Rifle Association and very nearly a licensed pilot through the cadet flying program sponsored by the Army Aviation Regiment.

She was all of these things and more. She was a fine musician, a strong chorister and a first-year university student just completing her first semester when she met her death in a single vehicle accident on a sandy road 300 kilometres west of Cairns on the Cape York Peninsula at 20 past one in the morning on Friday, 20 June 1997.

Clare Stokes's death was a tragedy. It was a waste and an entirely avoidable consequence of gross stupidity, carelessness and reckless behaviour. I would like to explain to the House just why the defence department must hold an open board of inquiry into her death without further delay.

Three Army officers knocked on Paul and Marie Stokes's front door at 7 o'clock on a Friday morning. Their daughter had recently left home for a weekend long cadet survival camp on Cape York Peninsula. The Army officers told her parents that Clare had been killed instantly when a vehicle had crashed and rolled over at Bulimba Station outside Chillagoe 5½ hours earlier.

They also told Paul and Marie that a number of other cadets had been injured and had been transported to the Cairns Base Hospital. In the months ahead, Clare's parents learned more about her death from media reports and press coverage than they did from the defence department. Clare died on Friday, 20 June 1997, almost 20 months ago. The next official communication Paul and Marie Stokes received from the defence department was the investigating officer's report on the incident. It arrived at their home on Friday, 8 January this year—a mere five or six weeks ago. Do you know how extensive the defence department's investigation had been? The report was barely eight pages in length.

Paul and Marie Stokes wrote back to Minister Bruce Scott within 48 hours listing the errors that they themselves knew about. And yet Paul Stokes had told the Courier-Mail newspaper on the day of his daughter's death, `It's just one of those terribly unfortunate things that happen.' He did not blame anyone. How could he? He knew nearly none of the facts. The Stokes family knew that Clare had been decapitated and they knew that five other people had been rushed to Cairns Base Hospital. They thought six people had been involved in total. That was all they knew.

It was only at the first hearing of the coronial inquest at Mareeba in Far North Queensland on 7 July last year—over 12 months after Clare's death—that the Stokes learned that 24 Army cadets from five separate units were involved in that exercise. Two vehicles had been involved. The second one, with eight people on board—five cadets and three officers—followed some minutes behind the first vehicle. The first vehicle was a 1989 Toyota Landcruiser utility carrying 16 people. Two people sat in the cabin with broken seat belts and 14 people sat on top of their packs on the tray.

It was announced at the final session of the coronial inquest two weeks ago that the vehicle had only one headlight, which was misaligned, almost no suspension or shock absorbers, and that the rear brakes and handbrake had been disconnected. On an exercise the previous year, the same vehicle had been run into a tree to stop it when the brakes failed—and yet it was still being used. It was carrying almost two tonnes, nearly double its capacity, on a sandy road in the middle of the night at between 40 and 60 kilometres per hour after they had been travelling for 20 hours since the previous morning. Despite early reports in the days following Clare's death, alcohol was involved. These are the facts. They are without dispute.

Mr Deputy Speaker, here is where I should be a little careful. Coroner Gary Casey charged three people with manslaughter, and they are due to face court on 27 April. It is not my place to attribute blame. I merely want to know the truth, and Mr and Mrs Stokes want to know the truth. What I have told you is already on the public record, having come before the Coroner's Court at Mareeba on 7 July last year, at Mount Isa on 3 August last year, at Chinchilla on 13 October last year, and at Brisbane on 3 and 4 February this year. According to the Stokes family and the coroner's records, the defence department was not represented at the inquest hearings in Mareeba, Mount Isa or Chinchilla. I am not sure if they attended in Brisbane.

After the third session at Chinchilla, Paul and Marie Stokes started writing to Prime Minister Howard, to Defence Minister Moore, to Senator Ron Boswell, to Major-General Mike Keating, who is the commander of Training Command Army, to me and to many other elected and public figures. They sought an open board of inquiry from the Army into Clare's death. The only formal communication they had received at that time since their daughter's death was three Army officers standing on their doorstep at seven in the morning some 15 months earlier. The civil authorities acted. The Queensland State Coroner held an inquiry in four towns over a period of seven months, finally laying criminal charges.

It could have finished sooner than that, but Paul and Marie Stokes asked for the Brisbane session to be delayed from 14 December last year until early this year. Why did they do that? Because by early December last year they had still received no written details from the defence department. Major-General Keating wrote on 29 October but could not comment. He explained to Paul and Marie Stokes that he had asked the minister's office to release the completed investigating officer's report to the coroner and to the police. Meanwhile, Minister Moore had passed the issue on to Minister Scott.

On 21 December—two full months later and four days before Christmas—Minister Scott's office told the Stokes family that they were waiting until the minister returned from holidays on 18 January to approve release of the eight-page report. I grudge no-one their holidays, particularly my friend the Minister for Veterans' Affairs and Minister Assisting the Minister for Defence, but I understand this report had been finalised at least two full months before the minister left Canberra. According to written advice from the commander of the Training Command Army, it was some two months before he left Canberra that that report was available. Why did Minister Scott let this report lie on his desk for at least two months?

Two days later, the minister's office changed direction. On 23 December Paul and Marie Stokes were told the investigating officer's report was in the post. On the morning of Friday, 8 January they received an envelope postmarked from Canberra on Wednesday, 6 January—not 23 December. It contained a two-page letter from Minister Scott advising that the report had only been released to them and to the coroner—please don't show it to anyone else, the letter said. They could not have shown it even if they had wanted to, because the report was not attached. It was not until my office got onto Minister Scott's office that eventually they received it.

This comedy of errors added pain to an already difficult day, because Friday, 8 January 1999 would have been Clare Stokes's 20th birthday. Minister Scott has offered his written condolences to the Stokes family, and the letter arrived at their family home last Friday, some six days ago. He also offered his condolences verbally on the Carolyn Tucker program.

Time is going to beat me and there are a number of things I want to say. I will say them at a later time when I am able to resume this speech. But for the time being I call upon the minister to call an open board of inquiry immediately into the circumstances leading to the death of Senior Cadet Under-Officer Clare Francis Stokes on Friday, 20 June 1997. Furthermore, I call on the minister to ensure that this open board of inquiry is fully resourced by the defence department. To do otherwise would be to perpetuate the grief and pain of the Stokes family and to turn a blind eye to the reckless way in which some units of the Australian Cadet Corps seem to be run at present.

I understand that only yesterday two brigadiers advised that they will be visiting Mr and Mrs Stokes this Sunday. I just want to let them know that they are not going to smooth things over with the Stokes. The Stokes want a full, open board of inquiry to understand how their daughter died. I can tell you that they will pursue this issue for a long time to come.

Finally, before my time expires today, I want to commend the local newspaper, the Wynnum Herald, and its senior journalist Jackie Miller for being prepared to bring this out in the public arena as they have. I will take up the balance of this matter at some later stage.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 5.30 p.m., I propose the question:

interjection.para: That the House do now adjourn.

talk.start.para: —Today we have seen the government's true colours revealed on the rights of workers in this country. We have seen Minister Reith's document that spells out, in all its mean and sneaky glory, how this government sees the future for workers in Australia. It is a future where wages and conditions will be at the whim of employers, awards will be meaningless and the role of the Australian Industrial Relations Commission as the protector of decent living standards for workers in Australia will be abolished. I think it is great that the government has been forced to let the rest of us in on its secret plan. They are the sorts of tactics, backed by the minister and carried out by his mates, whether they are wearing balaclavas or pinstriped suits, that I want to talk about today.

speech.para: Australian workers do not have to look very far to see what their lives will be like under Mr Reith's plan. We are seeing it in the Central Queensland coalmining industry right now at mines like Gordonstone and Blair Athol where the companies in charge, Arco and Rio Tinto, have pursued an aggressive and counterproductive anti-union policy. It is a policy in which ideology rules—ideology over and above any respect for the rightful place of the legal institutions within the industrial relations system in this country, ideology over and above cooperative reforms to improve productivity and ideology over and above any concern for the damage and division generated in the communities where the miners and their families live.

In the workplace culture promoted by this government, the only way a worker can be sure of keeping his or her job is to renounce their right to be a member of a trade union. Their performance in their job is irrelevant. Their value as a worker comes down to whether or not they are prepared to renounce that union membership—a right, I might add, that is contained in the Universal Declaration of Human Rights.

The long-running dispute at the Gordonstone mine is a classic example of where this obsession with de-unionising the work force leads to. In 1996 Arco was happy to report on the record breaking production levels achieved by its unionised work force. The next year, following the introduction of Mr Reith's new industrial relations laws, the story changed and suddenly a non-union work force on individual contracts was the only answer. When the miners refused to cop such an illogical insult—that somehow, by definition, as union members they could not possibly be cooperative and productive workers—Arco dismissed all 312 workers at the mine.

The Industrial Relations Commission has since ruled those sackings to be unfair and the matter is subject to an appeal to the Federal Court. Arco has consistently defied the commission's rulings by refusing to recommence production with the former work force. At the same time, 16 miners from Rio Tinto's Blair Athol coalmine are giving evidence before the Industrial Relations Commission seeking reinstatement following their sacking last July, only days after the government's award stripping legislation came into force.

I am not here today to prosecute the union's case. I will leave that to the proper legal forums. What I want to do is breathe life into the government's policy—to give it meaning and names and faces. When I look at the results of the government's industrial relations experiment, I do not see flexibility and productivity and all those Disneyland catchwords. The government's industrial relations agenda, as carried out by the likes of Arco and Rio Tinto, has meant for the mining communities in Central Queensland division, insecurity and intimidation by security guards staking out miners and their families in their homes.

I see miners with 20 years of experience being sent out to pull weeds for months on end in 40-degree heat just because they want to stay represented by their union. I see other experienced miners applying for their old jobs and not even receiving acknowledgment of their applications. I see miners and their families having to pack up and leave towns that have been their homes for many years.

Meanwhile, Arco packs up and goes back to America without a care for what it left behind in Emerald. And Rio Tinto, for all its crying poor and criticism of unions, reports a 37 per cent increase in coal production and a full year profit of around $2 billion in Australian terms. Mr Speaker, I table a report from the Financial Review which documents that profit figure. Meanwhile, the mine that is literally across the road from Gordonstone—Crinum operated by BHP—has worked with its unionised work force to reach agreement on changed work practices. BHP's mines are reported as achieving an improvement in the tonnes of coal produced per employee.

Meanwhile, it has been the workers and their union, the CFMEU, that have consistently sought to resolve these matters through due process before the appropriate legal and industrial forums that have served this country for almost a century. The companies, on the other hand, seek to use corporate and emotional trickery to undermine the legitimate decisions of the legal system. When Australians look at what is happening in the coalmining industry, I say to them: do not be tricked by the government's rhetoric. Do not judge this on the basis of whether or not you support unions. The question is whether you support fairness and equity in the workplace rather than blind prejudice and absolute power. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I deliberately did not interrupt the member for Capricornia in her speech, but in fact it is not possible to simply table a document; you need leave to do so. You can, if you wish, show it to the parliamentary secretary at the table but, if it is something that can be read, it will in fact not be able to be tabled because it could have been read into Hansard . If she wishes to seek leave to table it, I will consider that at the end of the adjournment debate.

—I wish to draw to the attention of the House a very special event that occurred on Australia Day in my electorate of Moore. I had the pleasure of recognising 15 worthy recipients of the inaugural Mal Washer Community Contribution Awards at a very pleasant, albeit hot, ceremony on the Australia Day public holiday.

speech.para: These people came from all walks of life and represented many age groups and occupations. However, they all shared a common trait, this being their strength of character by wanting to help others in their community by voluntarily giving their time and energy, so making them outstanding Australians. I believe it is no accident that we live in such a lucky country. It is the volunteers in our community that really make it so. In these fast-moving and often tumultuous times, it is becoming more important to take a step back and pause for a minute to give these people a pat on the back and just say, `Thanks.'

Of course, it is in the very nature of our volunteers that they do not often seek praise and recognition for their efforts—they are quiet achievers. It is for this reason that I would also like to thank those people who nominated these volunteers. The recipients this year were Ann Jackson of Duncraig, Nick Cavie of Merriwa, Audrey Harris-Brown of Currambine, Walter Grubb of Kallaroo, Eve Sadler-Witham of Mindarie, Peter De-Rijcke of Merriwa, Dale Lings of Burns, Graham Hailstones of Yanchep, Joy Coleman of Heathridge, Jacyntha Gannaway of Yanchep, Tony Moloney of Clarkson, Jennifer Spence of Connolly, William Sanders of Ocean Reef and Tom Smith of Two Rocks.

talk.start.para: —It gives me great pleasure to speak tonight in the adjournment debate. I would like to do something that we do not often get the opportunity to do in this place and that is to pay homage to parents. In this case, I want to pay homage to my mother, who died recently. It is not commonly known that I was the first person born in the ACT to serve in this parliament. My mother was born in the ACT. She was born in Canberra in 1927—the year the first Parliament House opened. She was one of 11 children. Her family came to Canberra as part of pioneer families to establish the Canberra community. Her family lived and worked around the Causeway. For those of you who do not know the Causeway, it is a small community just near the railway station. It was built as a construction camp for people participating in the building of Can berra. My mother went to the local primary school and to St Christopher's Catholic Church in Manuka. She was a child of the Depression. Her father was a manual worker and each of her brothers and sisters was educated in the same way—she spent 12 months during her childhood living away in the country.

speech.para: In 1948 or thereabouts she met my father and they were married. My father came from Victoria—Greta, Kelly country, via Geelong. They got together and I was fortunate enough for them to produce me. I think that was a wise choice on their part.

The point I want to make is that we have condolence motions in this place for fine prominent Australians; we very rarely pay homage to those Australians we should pay homage to and they are our families, our parents and our friends.

My mother was brought up in Canberra and she moved from the Causeway to Narrabundah. Her home, where she died, was five kilometres from where she was born. That is quite unusual in modern Australia. The importance of Canberra then as a village and now as a community was clear from the number of people at her funeral service who were from the Causeway. The Causeway is a very important place in Canberra's history. Many of the people working around Parliament House and servicing us—drivers, attendants, the people who make this place function—come from the Causeway or their parents come from the Causeway.

I do not think that my mother had ever entered Parliament House until the day I was elected in 1987, although she worked as a copy person for many years transcribing Hansard in the old printing office. I think many people who live in Canberra or who are brought up in Canberra have never entered Parliament House.

What is clear is the strength of spirit that they had as a community. That was passed on to me and I hope I will pass it on to my children. I do not want to get into a political debate, but it is a bit offensive at times to hear the unctuous comments that come from the government when they talk about people from trade union backgrounds. My mother and father were workers; they were trade union members. My father certainly was an active trade union member in his later life. I am proud of it. But most of all they were humble people. My mother was a humble person. Her brothers and sisters, the strength of community she had and her family were what gave her the drive to survive the years she did, even though she lived in much pain. Unfortunately, she died on Christmas Eve, just prior to the time we were planning to go away on a holiday together. I want to use this opportunity to say thank you to her and to all those like her.

talk.start.para: —The House sympathises with the member for the Northern Territory and reflects on the fact that his remarks echo similar remarks made by the member for Bowman earlier this week.

—I also pass on my condolences to the member for the Northern Territory. We never realise how grateful we are to our parents until they have left us. I stand tonight to acknowledge the enormous contribution made by another great Australian, Neville Bonner. Neville Bonner achieved many, many things in his lifetime and his work towards peace for all Australians was enormous.

speech.para: Many people in this House would know him and can attest to the contribution he made while he served in the Senate for 12 years. I have known Neville for many years, mainly through membership of the Liberal Party. But I also knew about his past. I was brought up with Aboriginal people on Moreton Island. Many stories went around about Neville before I actually met him. The respect he had in Dunwich and on Stradbroke Island was enormous. I learnt about his start in life on the Tweed River, having been born under a tree. I learnt about how he had only three years of education and how he worked in a lot of places around Australia—ringbarking camps and so forth. He had a very tough beginning, but he fought on and soared to great heights to achieve a position as senator.

What I remember most about him was his contribution to the Liberal Party behind the scenes. Our Queensland members in here will not forget that it was about this time last year that he and the Prime Minister were on stage when we gave an award to former Senator Bonner. It was very emotional for the Prime Minister and for Neville Bonner, but he appreciated that we appreciated the many contributions he had made to the Liberal Party over the years.

I got to know Neville even better when he became patron of the Rivermount College in my electorate. He served as patron of that school for nine years. He never missed a Foundation Day. He contributed enormously to that school. I met with him on many occasions and we discussed the benefits of looking after Australia and making sure that we all work together.

I stand up here tonight because the people of Rivermount College—the college that he gave many hours to and was the patron of—sadly miss him. They wanted me to put on record their many thanks for the contribution he made to the school over the years. The head principal, Colin Young, has stated that for many students, parents and friends of the college, Mr Bonner's influence over the past nine years has been enormous. He said that Mr Bonner will live on in the hearts of the college and the community through his authentic demonstration of human dignity and the desire for genuine reconciliation.

I am sure we all remember the words of Sir James Killen at Mr Bonner's funeral when he said, `I never heard a word of hate from him. I saw no evidence whatsoever of personal malice. He was, indeed, a gifted and graceful man.' I am sure everyone in this House will agree with that. I hope that with his passing Aboriginal people have learnt that the only way Australia is ever going to achieve and go forward is if we all work together as Australians. That is exactly what Neville told me he wanted for Australia.

I would like to place on record a poem by Sally Bailey, a year 9 student of Rivermount College. At last year's Foundation Day, I had the pleasure of hearing Sally deliver this poem. I am sure she would be only too happy for me to read it into the record tonight. It says:
Our friend, our patron who has taken much care of our College,
an encourager, a man of excellence who freely shares his knowledge,
a true supporter working with many hearts and hands,
watching our school get better each day as Rivermount expands.
Today, Dr Bonner joins us and our community has much to say,
we are glad to see you here to celebrate our school's Foundation Day.
Generous and kind are words to describe this wonderful man,
I'd have to say Dr Bonner that Rivermount College is your number one fan.
Your advice and support is so genuine and true,
and from all of us at Rivermount College we'd like to say thankyou!
But words cannot explain how much you have done,
now Rivermount is booming and is in for the long run.
You've taught our school how to take a big stride,
in building bridges of harmony you have been a true guide.
Loving together in peace is what we intend,
to you Dr Bonner, our love we send.
Loving, forgiving and healing brings life anew,
and thanks to you Dr Bonner, you've made that dream come true.
I would also like to say thank you, Neville, for the honour of knowing you and for the excellent service that you have given to this country and to our people. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I would like to note that, as a new member, it is not often that in this place you agree with, welcome and, indeed, are moved by the two contributions made before yours, but I have been on this occasion. I would like that noted.

speech.para: I rise to raise an issue of major importance to my electorate—an issue which I raised on the last sitting day last year—and that is the continuing appalling condition of the Princes Freeway which links Melbourne and Geelong. I noted on that occasion that the Herald Sun has consistently reflected community concern about the major safety problems posed by the poor design and poor condition of the freeway.

It should be noted that since this House sat last year, there have been further accidents on the freeway and, indeed, there was a tragic loss of life on the freeway on Sunday, 24 February in the early hours of the morning. Two people were killed on the Maltby Bypass, which is in my electorate, in an accident in which five cars and 14 people were involved. Last Friday, I was in my electorate, having returned from this House to attend to electorate business. Unfortunately, I have no option but to travel regularly up and down the Princes Freeway because it bisects my electorate. That Friday was a day of fairly heavy rain in Melbourne and there were three major pile-ups on the Princes Freeway.

There was a four-car crash just west of the western ring-road interchange. There was a five-car pile-up near the Grieve Parade off-ramp in Altona North, just outside my electorate, and a six-car collision occurred two kilometres east of the Altona North accident. It was a very bad day on the Princes Freeway in Victoria.

Given the importance of this issue in my electorate and to the community in the west of Melbourne—and I would say to the community in Victoria generally—I have followed with some interest road funding announcements made in this House and in the media. I have noted with interest all of these announcements. I note that, in an answer to a question last week from the member for Page, the Minister for Transport and Regional Services said the following in relation to a road announcement about the Summerland Way in New South Wales:

I can confirm that the Summerland Way was declared a road of national importance. I can advise him that we are still awaiting the completion of negotiations with New South Wales over a work plan . . .

He said that the works—$20 million of promised federal funding—would proceed. I understand that that announcement was well and truly in the public domain before it was raised in this place, and one could perhaps be forgiven for thinking that there is a New South Wales election in the offing and that such announcements need to be made on more than one occasion.

Having heard the minister utter those words in answer to a question last week, I have followed the matter up and have since ascertained that a New South Wales, government financed, $50 million five-year upgrade has begun on the Summerland Way. The first expenditure was in the 1995-96 financial year, and some $38 million has already been spent on work that has been performed. To the New South Wales government's $50 million, the Commonwealth government has committed $20 million over a period of four years. I understand that the first amount of that money has been spent in this current financial year and a sum of $2 million of Commonwealth funds has been expended.

The Commonwealth money that has been allocated to the Summerland Way has been allocated as part of the Roads of National Importance Program. Given that I grew up in South Australia and now live in and represent a seat in Victoria, I cannot claim to be familiar with the Summerland Way, which runs between Grafton in New South Wales and the Queensland border. I certainly wish those commuters, businesses and ordinary people who will benefit from the upgrade all the luck in the world, but if the Summerland Way has attracted federal government funds and attention, it seems a great mystery to me why the Princes Freeway has not, especially when we look at the comparative statistics. The Summerland Way traffic varies from 25,000 vehicles per day at Grafton, through to 10,000 at Casino, and down to 2,000 to 3,000 at the Queensland border. The Princes Freeway carries 132,000 vehicles per day, with traffic volumes increasing at five per cent a year.

The Summerland Way is economically important to the agricultural industry in that precinct. The Princes Freeway carries freight on the vital road link between Melbourne and Geelong, where the greatest concentration of transport infrastructure and industry account for almost 40 per cent of the nation's exports. On this basis, we ask for something more than the funding received for the Summerland Way: we ask for the Princes Freeway to be included in the national highway system, and we specifically ask for the Howard government to meet Labor's election commitment of putting $100 million of federal funds towards upgrading the Princes Freeway to match the $100 million coming from the Victoria government. (Time expired)

subdebateinfo.title: Antarctica: 100th Anniversary of First Winter Expedition

talk.start.para: —Firstly, I would like to commend the honourable member for the Northern Territory for his thoughtful and very sensitive contribution. Antarctica is very important to Australia, and today is a very special day in the history of Antarctic exploration: 100 years ago today the first party to ever winter on the continent actually landed at Cape Adare. It was a British-funded Norwegian-led expedition, and they landed at the edge of Antarctica at Cape Adare, which is due south of New Zealand.

speech.para: The expedition was led by a Norwegian called Carsten Egeberg Borchgrevink. This was the first group ever to spend a winter on the Antarctic continent. The party included an Australian scientist, Louis Bernacchi, who was a Tasmanian physicist. He was so keen to go on this expedition to winter in Antarctica, and risk his life—as everybody who goes down there does—that he paid his own way to go to London so that he could leave with the expedition from the United Kingdom.

Borchgrevink was born in Norway in 1864, but he lived in Australia for a great many years. He had actually visited Antarctica in 1894-95 with a party led by a gentleman called Henric Bull. When Borchgrevink was involved in setting up the expedition, he tried desperately to raise some funding here in Australia, but he had no luck at all. He then went to the UK and was very lucky. He obtained £40,000, which was pretty significant back then. It was not a very large sum, but it was a gift from publisher Sir George Newnes. So, even though it was not an enormous amount, it was enough to mount a small expedition with enough supplies and equipment for the Antarctic winter.

There seemed to be some degree of jealousy within scientific circles in the United Kingdom at that time, and I think there are other examples of that if one looks back. A member of the Royal Geographic Society, Sir Clements Markham, claimed that Borchgrevink was incompetent and that the ship, the 531-tonne Southern Cross, was rotten. Well, it was not so rotten that it could not get to Antarctica and get back. Incidentally, it is interesting to note that the Royal Geographic Society, of which Sir Clements Markham was a member, later sent Scott to the Antarctic.

Borchgrevink's party left the United Kingdom on 23 August 1898 and went to Tasmania; they sailed from Hobart on 19 December 1898. Mr Speaker, having been to Antarctica with me, you would know about the pack ice, but other members may not. The expedition sailed from Hobart on 19 December, but they did not break out of the pack ice until mid-February—that is a very long time in that ice. They sighted the coast three days later and the next day, 18 February 1899, 100 years ago from today, they actually landed on Antarctica and started setting up their huts.

The crew of the ship came ashore as well and worked with the expeditioners to erect the huts which would enable them to survive the winter. Almost immediately, gales and blizzards blew up and the ship had to use the full strength of its engines to save it going on the rocks. Of course the leader, Borchgrevink, and five others were marooned onshore without a single hut having been erected. Fortunately, they had a Scandinavian reindeer skin tent and a team of dogs. So they all got into the tent, with the dogs on top to keep them warm, and they all survived. The expedition had a 10-man wintering team and, until May, they involved themselves in coastal exploration, but then it got too dark. A zoologist, Nikolai Hanson, had a strange illness and died on 14 October, and he is buried at Cape Adare.

I would like to take this opportunity not only to salute, as the Deputy Prime Minister would say, these first wintering expeditioners but also to pay tribute to the tremendous effort made by Australians and people of other nationalities, but particularly our people, who, over the decades, have wintered in Antarctica, undergoing extreme conditions but serving the best interests of humanity.

talk.start.para: —I rise to congratulate Steven Waugh on his appointment as captain of the Australian cricket team. Steven is a local Bankstown boy. He and his brother were raised in Panania and are true ambassadors for the Bankstown area. I recall seeing Steven and his brother some 17 years ago in local grade cricket; they were only 16 years of age and they basically flogged the Revesby Workers Club in a final and then trotted off to play grade for Bankstown.

speech.para: Steven and his brother are revered in the Bankstown area. They are statesmen of the highest order. I think that Steven's appointment, unanimously, as captain is a worthy one. From 111 tests his batting average is over 50. He has lifted his average in recent years from the low 30s. He has also taken 89 wickets. I think that Australia will be well served by Steven; he has impeccable credentials. He and his wife, Lynette, have a young daughter. I know that the family are very proud of them. We in Bankstown are proud of them.

I suppose in sport they are a bit more fortunate than we are in politics because we tend to have divisions in the community, whereas those who represent Australia in sport have the whole community behind them. I was impressed with his press conference. Steven has had a few setbacks—at one stage he was dropped from the Australian cricket team. He did not drop his bundle; he came back with a vengeance.

If one looks at his record in recent years, you can see that he has averaged over 65; he has basically been the mainstay. I wish him well with the Australian team in the West Indies. I think that he will serve the nation with distinction, as he has already.

I know that out in Bankstown we are delighted that Bankstown boys are still making an impact on this nation. We are proud of Paul Keating, our former Prime Minister, but we are even prouder of Steven because there are no politics involved in that, just immense pride for the district. It is a worthy appointment. I congratulate him and his family and look forward to many years with Steven as a great captain.

talk.start.para: —Order! It being 6 p.m., the debate is interrupted.

business.start.para: Mr DEPUTY SPEAKER(Mr Nehl) took the chair at 9.54 a.m.

talk.start.para: —I rise today on behalf of all the constituents who have contacted my office complaining about the health insurance premiums. These constituents believe that they have been duped, and that this government has not put forward the true picture of what was going to happen with the health insurance rebates. People who have had health insurance with companies such as NIB, Medicare, HCF and Government Employees Health Insurance have all contacted my office and been most upset by the government deceit.

speech.para: Add to that the fact that there has been this massive advertising campaign about health insurance and the fact that all Australians were to get the 30 per cent rebate. Australians were not advised of the fact that the previous rebate was to expire on 31 December last year and that this would reduce the amount of the premium reduction that they received. They are angry. Everyone believes that the government has not put forward the true picture to them and when they see advertisements saying, `Private health cover will now be 30 per cent cheaper for all Australians', they believe that this is a lie and very deceitful on the part of the government.

It is 30 per cent if you are on a high income; it is 30 per cent if you can afford to pay for health insurance. But it is not 30 per cent if you are a pensioner. It is not 30 per cent if you are somebody who struggles to pay health insurance, like Mr and Mrs Stevens of Buff Point, who had their health insurance policy with HCF. Some constituents are very disturbed by the fact that there has been no decrease whatsoever. I have even had people contact the office complaining that their health insurance has gone up.

I am sure members on both sides of the House have had complaints such as this: that this has been very unfairly represented. It has been put to people in a way that is very deceitful. At the most, people receive only a 23 per cent rebate increase, such as was received by Mr MacDonald of Whitebridge. There are people like Mr Callum and Mr Griffith. They are all with NIB. There have been so many complaints received that I think the government needs to look again at this health insurance rebate and get honest and tell all Australians the truth about the health insurance rebate. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Recently I corresponded with the Minister for Environment and Heritage and the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry regarding serrated tussock and the withdrawal of the herbicide Frenock from the market. The voluntary withdrawal of the herbicide Frenock has posed both environmental and agricultural problems in areas infested with serrated tussock as there is no suitable chemical alternative.

speech.para: Frenock is selective in taking out tussock at the lower recommended rates. It has been used for 25 years without any significant problems recorded. The herbicide Frenock will selectively kill serrated tussock readily at rates as low as 100 millilitres per hectare.

Registration was granted to Frenock some 25 years ago under less stringent conditions than exist today. Recently a review of recommendations reduced the rates of application and refined application methods which also affected the economics of supply of the chemical.

The greatest threat to the environment on the tablelands of New South Wales is serrated tussock, with almost one million hectares infested. There is a major expanding problem in Victoria and a small area infested in Tasmania. The Victorian Department of Agriculture estimates that the potential area of infestation is 32 million hectares in Australia based on climatic data. In non-arable areas, the weed is now uncontrollable without Frenock. The cost to agriculture is estimated at $60 million in control and lost production. There is no estimate of the environmental cost involving loss of native species or the social cost that can be attributed to many farmers who are suffering economic hardship as a result of marginal land, low wool prices and serrated tussock infestation compounding the problems of low returns.

Serrated tussock has no nutritional value. One plant can produce 80,000 to 100,000 seeds and these seed heads can blow 30 to 50 kilometres downwind. If uncontrolled, the weed will develop into a monoculture that chokes out native species, thereby becoming a serious environmental problem. It is an insidious weed which is not easily recognised as a weed, and will grow in low fertility soils and low rainfall areas. As there is no suitable alternative chemical control—at recommended rates, glyphosate will kill everything, with no residual action on seedlings—it is imperative that we get Frenock back onto the market. There are a number of options: we approach Daiken—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —Order! In accordance with standing order 275A, the time for members' statements has concluded.

debateinfo.title: AUSTRALIAN SPORTS DRUG AGENCY AMENDMENT BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 December 1998, on motion by Miss Jackie Kelly:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Labor Party is proud to have introduced, in 1990, the legislation which established the Australian Sports Drug Agency. The establishment of the agency was a world first—no other government on the globe had ever enshrined such a body in government legislation—and, since its inception, the drug agency has earned an exceptional international reputation. The opposition is enthusiastic to see that the agency maintains that very good reputation and, as such, we will be supporting the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1998 . However, we note a few general concerns.

speech.para: The legislation brings into effect two key objectives which were identified as part of the review of the principal act conducted in 1997: first, a need to increase the flexibility of the agency in response to drug testing, procedural and policy requirements, and, second, the continued protection of athlete rights to natural justice and privacy. The 1997 independent review of the principal act outlined the need for a comprehensive review of the legislation to enable the agency to adequately meet the policy needs of the international sporting federations and national sporting organisations in relation to the provision of drug testing services. We cannot, however, be sure that this legislation provides adequately for all of that.

The amendment bill is directed more towards some operational changes and the addition of new committees than the comprehensive reform which would enact the changes required for ASDA to continue to be at the forefront of antidoping agencies worldwide. The bill seeks to move operational and other provisions currently in the principal act to subordinate legislation, and establishes the Australian Sports Drug Medical Advisory Committee. It would also enable the Australian Sports Drug Agency to provide services which test for the presence of substances that may affect competitors' judgment or their safety.

The advisory committee's primary functions will be to provide expert medical advice to the sporting community and, importantly, will provide independent approval for the use of a prohibited substance where it finds the drug is necessary for a legitimate medical purpose. Members of the advisory committee will be professional appointees. But the opposition wants to put on the record its concern about the powers given to the minister, in the bill, over the appointment and dismissal of committee members. While it is necessary for there to be provisions within the legislation for members of government boards to be dismissed, it would be of grave concern if, because of this relationship, the committee's members were to become politicised.

We are not proposing amendments with respect to this concern, because a strong element of bipartisanship is necessary, indeed critical, in this very important area of public policy. However, the opposition implores the minister to exercise these powers with due diligence and only on the most sound and serious advice, to ensure that the Australian Sports Drug Medical Advisory Committee's members are immune to the politics of drugs in sport.

The opposition is also concerned about the fact that there is no provision in the amendment bill for additional funding to facilitate the administration of the advisory committee. This will place additional weight on the already stretched budget of the agency, and that must be of concern to us all.

The bill also establishes a mechanism for the exchange of information between the Australian Customs Service and the agency for the purposes of assisting with the agency's testing program and activities. The opposition therefore eagerly awaits the necessary complementary customs legislation to ensure it is both adequate and competent.

It must be noted that the government intends to increase the level of administrative and coordination support services it provides to the agency in relation to the illegal importation of banned sporting drugs. Given this, the government must also address the issue of resourcing and ensure that adequate training regarding sports drugs is provided to Customs officials.

The bill also provides a legislative framework for state and territory governments to enact complementary legislation that will enable the agency to undertake drug testing on competitors at the state level. While this is a positive step towards uniform antidoping procedures within Australia at both national and state levels and across most sports, it should be noted that this bill alone will not achieve this due to a requirement of the states to initiate that complementary legislation.

The government must therefore ensure that it proactively encourages the states to engage in a state testing regime under the agency's umbrella. If it is found to be cost prohibitive for the states and their sporting bodies to participate then the federal government should provide that financial support. While the opposition has these general concerns that I have outlined, we will be supporting the bill. We think this is a very important area of public policy.

I have to admit that when I was younger I used to drink and drive; in fact I probably drank and drove regularly—not an unexpected thing to do in those days. You did not mind approaching your friends, your mates or your football colleagues the next day to boast about how many schooners of beer you may have drunk last night and how you still drove home. It was something that would often gain almost the respect of your friends.

I often think about prohibition and how it does not work. It has never worked under any circumstances. In my view, it is not because of random breath tests that we do not have so much drink-driving these days, but because it has become uncool to drink and drive. Young people these days do not go to the pub and boast to their mates about having drunk 20 schooners of beer the night before and still having driven home. If they did so, they would get something far removed from respect from their colleagues; they would attract the ire of their colleagues.

In this society we have made it an uncool thing to drink and drive. In this society we have to make it an uncool thing to take drugs to enhance our sporting achievements. No other area of policy or area of society is more important than this, because today's young people look up to these people. If young people see these people enhancing their sporting abilities through the use of prohibited substances, we will see them doing the same.

I cannot think of any other piece of public policy more important than this in that respect, and that is why the opposition is happy to be here supporting the legislation. I have outlined a few general concerns, but there can be no greater issue out there. We see too much in our newspapers these days about street crime and the use of illegal substances—all of those things that are causing so much decay in our society. We must ensure that the people our kids look up to most, our sporting heroes, are far removed from those influences, far removed from those temptations, and there could be no issue more worthy of bipartisan support than this one. I commend the bill to the House.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to support the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1998 . In my view, drug cheating is the most serious issue facing Australian sport today and in the year leading up to the Sydney Olympics. It is referred to by high profile athletes such as Pat Rafter and Greg Norman as the ultimate sporting crime.

speech.para: Drugs have a devastating effect on sport. In the past 12 months a substantial number of prominent sportsmen and sportswomen have been disgraced in drug scandals around the world. At the beginning of last year headlines drew attention to how Australian Customs officials found human growth hormone in the bag of a Chinese swimmer travelling to Perth to compete in the world championships.

The trend continued throughout the year with the Tour de France scandal. The Festina team was kicked out of the race following a discovery by Customs officers of a team loaded with banned substances. An Irish triple Olympic swimming champion was banned for four years for tampering with a urine sample. Last month, at the Australian Open Tennis Championships in Melbourne the Czech defending champion Peter Korda was criticised by those within the sport for being allowed to play, despite testing positive to an anabolic steroid at Wimbledon last year.

As a journalist recently wrote in the Canberra Times, `The motto that it is better to be dead than second clearly still has support among some top-class competitors.' According to another report in the Canberra Times last month, Australian Customs reports show a rise in the detection of performance-enhancing drugs from 34 cases in 1991-92 to 571 in 1997-98, including 385 prohibited substances used for performance enhancement. The report states that the Australian Sports Drug Agency detected 15 positive results out of 1,351 tests carried out during the September quarter: eight for anabolic steroids in Australia and three overseas, three for stimulants and one for cannabis. For the same period in 1997, only three anabolic agents were found. During 1997-98, the agency detected a total of 33 positive findings, including 11 for anabolic agents, eight for cannabis and the rest for stimulants such as amphetamines. The agency made 4,313 tests during the year. The agency's chief executive, Natalie Howson, said last month that anabolic agents are a continuing problem in some sports.

The only way forward is for the Australian government to continue taking a proactive approach to drugs in sport to stop the drug cheats. The Howard government has already made a significant contribution to the fight against drugs, both on the sporting field and in the streets, with the introduction of the highly successful Tough on Drugs campaign in 1997. The Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1998 will ensure that the Australian Sports Drug Agency is able to undertake its responsibilities effectively and adopt world's best practice when delivering drug testing services.

I want to remind the House of the aims of this bill: to enable the Australian Sports Drug Agency to deliver an independent and high quality antidoping program for the Australian and international sporting communities; to enable the Australian Sports Drug Agency to be more flexible and adopt world's best practice when delivering drug testing services to national and international sporting organisations; to position the agency to service the needs of Australian sport well beyond the 2000 Olympics; to continue to maintain a strong focus on preservation of athlete rights and procedural fairness through the drug testing process; and to enable the creation of the Australian Sports Drug Medical Advisory Committee to provide assistance and expert medical advice to sport. As the minister for sport has informed us, the Australian sporting community has been fully consulted on these amendments, from the administrators of our peak national bodies to the elite athletes who are eligible for drug testing.

The proposed amendments will ensure that Australia's antidoping regime is more effective in achieving its goals of combating use of performance-enhancing drugs and is fairer to athletes who are subject to drug testing. But the biggest advantage for the Australian community of introducing these amendments is that it will be tougher on drug cheats.

How will the bill achieve the government's commitment to being tough on drug cheats? Firstly, the bill strengthens the ability of the Australian Sports Drug Agency to deal with positive test results registered by foreign athletes. If an international body chooses not to take any action against a sports man or woman who records a positive test result, the agency will be able to notify a relevant Australian sports body so that it may take action which it sees fit.

Secondly, the bill gives the Australian Customs Service the capability to pass on information to the Australian Sports Drug Agency about prohibited imports which are also banned for use in sport. As a result, the agency will then have the ability to use this information to better plan its testing activities to achieve the best results. I note that within the amendments provisions have been made to protect the interests and rights of competitors to ensure that natural justice principles are available and applied to the drug testing by the agency.

Thirdly, the bill allows for the formation of an Australian Sports Drug Medical Advisory Committee. The aim of this committee will be to provide scientific and medical expertise to support the Australian Sports Drug Agency's drug testing activities and the antidoping policies of national sporting organisations. The establishment of such a committee is strongly endorsed by the Australian sporting committee.

Fourthly, the bill provides a framework for state and territory governments to enact state drug testing legislation which will enable the agency to undertake drug testing on state-level competitors. The bill will promote harmonisation of antidoping rules across all sports to provide a nationally consistent approach. It is anticipated that the agency will undertake an increasing number of tests on behalf of international sporting federations in the lead-up to next year's games.

The amendments we are debating will enable the agency to apply best practice principles in complying with requests from all international sporting federations. It will also ensure that the agency has the capabilities to conduct specific drug testing services and safety checking services to such organisations under contract, on a user-pays basis.

I am sure that the majority of Australians want what I want for this country in the sporting arena: fair play, for drugs not to destroy the fundamentals of sports excellence, healthy competition, and the chance for current competitors and our youth to achieve success on a level playing field. This bill will enable the Australian Sports Drug Agency to adopt world's best practice when delivering drug testing services.

talk.start.para: —I wish to add my support to the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1998 and congratulate the Hon. Jackie Kelly, Minister for Sport and Tourism, on an excellent and timely bill. This bill ensures Australian pride in a great sporting nation, where we can be secure in the knowledge that we are competing on equal and drug free terms. It also ensures the importance of athletes as role models. It is a great tribute to Australia to assist other countries in this goal. We have a total commitment from government and sporting organisations to stamp out drug usage.

speech.para: Australian athletes do it for themselves and for Australia, with their own natural abilities. Let it be clear not only to Australian athletes but also to organisations right around the world that Australia is deadly serious in the fight against drugs in sport. Performance enhancing drugs were first recorded as far back as the ancient Greek Olympics in the 3rd century BC and in the mythology of ancient hunting rituals using herbal and other medications and substances.

Sometimes there are difficulties in identifying performance enhancing materials, and problems differentiating between the drugs helping different types of sports. Flushing and masking agents are also often used as a disguise. We need constant out-of-competition testing to achieve realistic baselines on natural hormones such as testosterone.

Drug testing was instituted for the first time at the 1968 Olympic Games in Mexico. Drug testing programs started in Australia in the early 1980s. Consistency and accuracy in testing is essential for fair legal proceedings. We need standardisation of protocols and procedures for testing and uniform penalties so that we can achieve talent not chemistry in athletes. It should also be noted that long-term damage can result from drug use in athletes. This is criminal.

The IOC world conference on doping in sport was held in Switzerland early this month to fight doping in sport and to unify the structure. ASDA made a large impact at this conference and, from this, Australia will be seen as a leader with the adoption of three proposals: independent worldwide drug testing programs, an international antidoping agency and an antidoping research fund. The proposal for a uniform antidoping policy framework needs further work. The minister, the Hon. Jackie Kelly, will convene a meeting with like-minded governments at the end of this year to address this.

The essence of the bill is to preserve the rights of athletes whilst strengthening the capacity of ASDA to deal with positive tests recorded by foreign athletes, thereby creating a more even playing field.

Increased cooperation between Australian Customs and ASDA has been cemented. Establishment of the ASDA committee consisting of specialist medical practitioners in fields such as sporting medicine, endocrinology and pharmacology allows the committee to advise in approved high quality testing laboratories, with the ability to test between doping and natural physiology. It will also ensure that the athlete is able to take necessary therapeutic substances where the rules of the sporting organisation permit, as well as offering expert medical advice to the sports doping tribunals. It will also ensure safety testing for drugs that impair judgment and the safety of competitors. It will recognise genuine inadvertent use of banned substances.

It is worth noting that the bill receives strong support from state and territory governments. The need for research has been recognised by giving the agency the ability to establish a foundation to attract non-government funding. The government has committed $3 million into research for reliable testing of substances such as growth hormone. There is also the possibility of shortening the time that a positive test can be brought to the attention of the sporting organisation. In summary, this is an excellent set of amendments to put in place before the Sydney 2000 Games.

talk.start.para: —It is my pleasure to speak on the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1998 . I congratulate the minister, her predecessor Mr Andrew Thomson and the executives of the Australian Sports Drug Agency. I think they have done an excellent job and I want to say well done to all of them.

speech.para: This is not about a bureaucratic process; it is about the athletes themselves. I have had the privilege and opportunity of going to several Olympic Games. The Atlanta Games stand out in my mind. As I was sitting amongst the parents of some of the swimmers, one particular swimmer recorded times that would have seemed impossible for her 12 months before. Everyone believed that this particular swimmer was taking some type of enhancement drug but for various reasons they were not actually able to cap it on her. I thought of the frustration of the swimmers' parents who had been up morning after morning to get their kids to the pool for training. They had done their best. These swimmers were the best in the world and the cheats came and took the gold medal away from them. As time has gone by, that particular swimmer has been shown up for what she really is.

We are not only talking about bureaucracy; we are talking about athletes. We are talking about people who are the best in the world—and this gets taken away by the cheats in sport. This particular bill is about that. It is about equity and fairness for the athletes. The bottom line is that that is what we, as Australians, support.

I have to say how disappointed I was in President Samaranch and his statements a while ago about softening the approach to drugs, that we should look at some drugs for use for therapeutic reasons and that they were not major problems. Here is another reason why President Samaranch should look clearly at his position and find a successor—although I would not suggest that he finds a successor; the Olympic movement should find a successor. This is not only because of issues such as drugs. Someone should be found who has had a track record of speaking out on the issues of corruption that have been dogging the Olympics.

That is not what we are here for today, but it is important for the leading person in sport to be constantly thinking about the athletes. One of the reasons that Sydney won was because those who were concerned about the athletes chose Sydney and there is so much commercial pressure in the games today that we need to remember what it is all about.

This bill is about the athletes and about fairness and, of course, ensuring we have an environment where we have the best practice in the world. That is why I commend the agency for being on top of their brief, for trying to be ahead of the field, not behind it, and for not even being prepared to take the standards of some of the other sporting organisations but saying, `We are going to try to be the best in the world.' Especially in the lead-up to the Olympic games, we need to make sure that our standards are excellent; that we take every measure possible to crack down on the cheats and that we are using world's best practice in terms of the ways we go about it.

I have to congratulate you on the advisory council that you have set up. The advisory committee is really the centrepiece of the legislation, and it was not there before. If I may be so politically parochial as to commend your chairman, Dr Peter Baume, let me say that he is an outstanding physician. He is an associate professor at the University of New South Wales and a person who, I know, is always concerned about the questions of fairness. He is a very good chairman and I am sure he is doing a great job.

In terms of you people from the agency who have come up with the advisory committee, this is pretty important. We have not had it before. It is going to have three major purposes. Firstly, its primary purpose will be to provide athletes with approval to use prohibited substances for therapeutic reasons when it can be proved that such usage is recognised by the rules of the athletes' sports. There are some times when this usage can be made, as Dr Washer would know. There are some special cases. Instead of referring it to people like me, who would not know the difference, they will have an expert advisory group to refer it to and say, `Does this seem reasonable to you? Is this valid?'

If we think of the Samantha Riley exercise—which I think was a great pity—athletes can actually refer to the committee and say, `Okay guys, what do you think about this proposal?' It is a great advantage to have a real body of experts that is able to take decisions over anybody else. You do not have the argy-bargy we had in the press about who is going to decide, and Kevan Gosper taking it to President Samaranch. For heaven's sake do not take it to President Samaranch. Let us have our own group to decide what fairness is about.

Secondly, there is expert medical assistance to accredited laboratories when investigation is required to determine whether a positive test result for a barred endogenous substance is due to doping or a physiological condition. It is also important that this particular group would know whether it is due to a high level of testosterone, for example, which might be seen normal for a particular individual, or whether it is due to simply wanting to mask performance. It is important that we see this advice in terms of whether it is appropriate or not.

The third aspect of it will be to provide medical advice to sports doping tribunals so that they can come in and provide a major body with the credentials and accreditation of skilled people who can say. `This is the way it is. This is our best advice to you.' That is the best feature of the bill in terms of bringing us up to best practice, and I think it is excellent. Of course, we have got the streamlining of the act, which is the bureaucratic process, and by all means put the details into subsidiary acts, handbooks, et cetera, and keep the main features of the bill. In terms of the other aspects of the world's best practice we have talked about, the support from the customs agency is significant.

We now have Mr Deputy Speaker Causley in the chair, and we welcome him. It is a great pleasure to have my former colleague in New South Wales—now my current colleague—presiding in the chair and, as someone who was the member of the cabinet that made the important decision that Sydney was going to bid for the games, I am very proud of that. I know that the Deputy Speaker is very proud of that.

One of the things that struck me about the relationship with Customs—and this is something that you have to ask yourself—was `Why on earth weren't they able to provide this information before? Why did they need to include it in the act?' I am sure there are special technical reasons. The bureaucracy again has been holding out. This will tie it down.

The final aspect of the advisory committee will be to provide a framework for the states and territory governments to coordinate their legislation. That is going to be significant as it is replayed in each of the states. It will ensure that we have a uniform system that relates to the federal act.

Overall, this is an excellent piece of legislation. The agency deserves appropriate support. It has performed well and has established itself as one of the lead agencies around the world, and now it is going one step further. Good on you all for what you have done. Keep up the good work.

talk.start.para: —I am pleased to rise in this debate on the Australian Sports Drug Agency Amendment Bill 1998 . It is an exciting initiative by the Minister for Sport and Tourism that has been prompted by the concerns that have been raised in the community, particularly over the last 12 to 18 months, about the continued use of drugs in sport. The minister, in her opening remarks in the second reading speech, summed it up pretty well when she said:

speech.para: The Australian sporting community has been fully consulted on these amendments, from the administrators of our peak national sports bodies to the elite athletes who are themselves subject to drug testing. They recognise that the agency must have the flexibility to keep abreast of change.
I think that is commendable as far as the athletes themselves are concerned. She continues:
The proposed amendments will ensure that Australia's anti-doping regime is more efficient, fairer to athletes subject to drug testing but, importantly, tougher on drug cheats.
My parliamentary colleague alluded to one of those cheats from Asia who recently visited this country. It was also interesting from my point of view to read:
In 1990, Australia became the first country in the world to establish a national sports drug testing authority under legislation.

The amendments in this bill complement that. The bill also refers to the therapeutic use of banned substances. We all know that the use of prohibited substances for therapeutic purposes could undermine the credibility of Australia's antidoping program. These amendments enable the ASDA to operate within the prevailing policy framework—it does not set the policy framework as such—which is set by the government through the Australian Sports Commission doping policy. The ASC doping policy recognises, quite rightly, that athletes should be able to use banned substances for the treatment of legitimate medical conditions. However, there is an enormous difference and gap between legitimate medical conditions and the use of drugs to enhance performance. Some international federations already approve the use of therapeutic drugs—for example, disabled sports organisations and tennis organisations.

Through the Australian Sports Drug Medical Advisory Committee, the agency will only recognise the use of prohibited substances by athletes for therapeutic purposes where their national sporting organisation or international federation has an antidoping policy which allows such use. The government is responding to the specific and individual needs of both Olympic and non-Olympic sports bodies which recognise that some athletes need banned or restricted substances for legitimate medical reasons.

The government quite rightly is not going to unnecessarily discriminate against or jeopardise the health of Australians who just happen to be athletes. The bill will also provide a framework to deal with the issue and reduce the pressure on sports bodies and athletes who now deal with this issue.

Once the federal legislation is in place, it is anticipated that Queensland, New South Wales and South Australia will quickly follow with the introduction of complementary legislation. Other states and territories are currently finalising their antidoping policies, consistent with the national drugs in sport framework that has already been adopted by all states and territories. Some jurisdictions believe the national antidoping program is meeting their needs and are not expected to introduce their own legislation in the short term.

The proposed changes represent the most current thinking on the simplest and most effective mechanism to facilitate complementary state and territory antidoping legislation. You do not have to go too far back to understand why there is concern, not only nationally but right across each state and territory in this country, about the use of drugs in sport. We do not have to go far in the state of New South Wales to know about what is going on there. As an example, there are some problems in national rugby league. There was a recent report of a positive drug test. I understand there was another one two days ago. Those reports in the media on 7 February this year claimed that a national rugby league player had received notification from ASDA of a positive test result.

As far as the general process of reporting positive test results goes, it requires that once an athlete's name is entered on the register of notifiable events the athlete, the Australian Sports Commission and the national sporting organisation are notified. Responsibility for hearing the athlete's case lies with relevant sports authorities. Prior to notification of an entry onto the register, the athlete concerned has access to due process as described by the ASDA Act. Matters arising from a positive result remain confidential between the athlete and ASDA until ASDA places the athlete's name on the register.

Is it any wonder that that sort of action is taken when you read, as I did the other day, in the 30 June 1998 edition of the Australian an article by Jeff Dunne which gave some figures on drug testing in rugby league. From the year 1991 to June 1997, ASDA carried out 3,099 random tests in rugby league. Of those 3,099 tests, 85 players or 2.7 per cent tested positive to banned substances, which included performance enhancing and recreational drugs. Of the 85 positive results, 10 players or 35 per cent were found with anabolic agents in their system. What sort of message is that action, by supposed professional athletes out there in the public arena, sending to the young children who are looking at them as idols and following their careers, whether in rugby league or any other sport?

Obviously, the issue of drugs has created some interest in the IOC. The IOC had a conference in Lausanne in early February which was called in the wake of the Tour de France and continued worldwide concern with the problem of doping in sport. In the lead-up to the conference, the IOC established four working parties and called for submissions on strategies to address the problem. The four working parties contained representatives from the IOC, the international sports federation and the national Olympic committees. Representatives from the government agencies were not involved. There is no clear definition outlining what constitutes `extenuating circumstances', which are words that are used from time to time for people to justify some of the use of drugs. The wording of the resolution leaves the international federation to determine its own definition.

Briefly, the IOC is obviously to a large degree concerned about dope in sports. What we need to do is concentrate our efforts and this is what the ASDA bill is all about. We need to concentrate on reducing the use of drugs and look at the sanctions that we need to impose on athletes when they use those drugs.

I understand that the International Olympic Committee has agreed that the two-year ban for athletes found guilty of first serious doping offences can be shortened in exceptional circumstances. The answer to that information I received is that the International Olympic Committee, as I said, hosted a world conference on doping in sport in Lausanne in early February. We were disappointed as a government to hear that the conference rejected the IOC's push for the international sporting federation to accept the uniform sanction of two years for first serious doping offences.

If we are going to have sanctions let us have proper sanctions, not Clayton sanctions which send the wrong message out to athletes. If you can successfully administer illegal substances to enhance your performance and you do so in the full knowledge that you are trying to create an induced advantage to your natural ability over another athlete, then you need to be sent a message that the sanctions are going to be so severe that you are not going to have an opportunity to do that again.

In closing, I read some articles in a number of papers before I looked at speaking on this bill and one of the things that interested me was an article in the Canberra Times of 15 January of this year which reported on an Australian Customs Service seizure of prohibited imports, namely anabolic steroids. This seizure was from an individual reported to be an Australian elite athlete. Specific details of the identity of the individual cannot, of course, be made public by the ACS. The Australian Customs Service has placed the matter into the hands of the Australian Federal Police and the AFP is responsible for issuing the summons and bringing the matter before a prosecutor. That case highlights the type of scenario where information sharing between federal government agencies may assist antidoping efforts. It is very important that agencies such as the ACS and the AFP work in close collaboration with one another so that we can get on top of this information.
