The article also made reference to the fact that the Australian Customs Service will be able to pass on information to the Australian Sports Drug Agency where there are reasonable grounds to suspect that an elite sportsperson is responsible for the importation or attempted importation of these illegal substances. They can report where they suspect the imported drugs have been brought into Australia by persons such as sports coaches, sports team doctors and officials who the Australian Customs Service might believe could supply the drug to elite sportspeople.

I think, all in all, the amendments brought in by the minister in this bill are to be commended. It is sending a message out to the community that not only do we have a concern about the illicit drugs in the community that are creating massive health problems for people, but also we are ensuring that those drugs that are performance enhancing as far as our athletes are concerned are looked upon very seriously by the government and that we are going to do something about it. I know all the bodies associated with sportspeople in this country will work together and do all they can to assist the government in this regard. I thank the House for the opportunity of saying a few words on this very important bill.

talk.start.para: —The comments and contribution from the member for Hume and those that preceded him certainly highlighted the problems of drugs in sport. They certainly also highlighted the need to be ever vigilant and again suggested very strongly the need for government to be fully committed in dealing with this. This government is strongly committed to the fight against doping in sport. The concept of fair play is embedded in the Australian culture and the government will not tolerate cheats.

speech.para: This bill proposes amendments to the ASDA Act that will ensure that Australia's antidoping regime is more efficient and fairer to athletes who are subject to drug testing and tougher on drug cheats. The ASDA Act has served us well but the sporting scene is now far more complex and sophisticated. The amendments we bring forward in this bill will enable Australia to stay ahead of the game. Changes to the ASDA Act will ensure that Australia's drug testing is, first of all, tougher because the medical and scientific experts will scrutinise test results, so cheats cannot so easily beat the system and Australian sporting organisations will now be able to take action against foreign athletes caught cheating in Australia.

The program will be fairer because athletes with a serious medical problem—not just a sniffle or a headache—will be able to gain prior approval to use appropriate medications. Medical consideration of results will occur before an athlete's name is passed on to relevant sporting organisations, and athletes' rights will be enshrined within the legislation. Also, the program will be more efficient because ASDA will be able to respond quickly to the rapidly changing antidoping environment.

In summary, this bill will keep Australia in the forefront of the international fight against drugs in sport. Indeed, this bill will provide the framework for Australia to again establish the benchmark for world's best practice in antidoping regimes. Australia will be well prepared for the challenges of the 2000 Olympics and beyond.

The amendments to the ASDA legislation are only one expression of the government's commitment to drug-free sport. The government is currently working on pulling together a whole suite of antidoping measures, with a view to developing a comprehensive and coordinated antidoping strategy.

This bill is a foundation upon which we can build a truly comprehensive and nationally coordinated effort against doping in sport. It has the support of the peak Australian sporting organisations, it has the support of elite Australian athletes and it has the support of state and territory governments. It now needs the support of this House.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debateinfo.title: AGRICULTURE, FISHERIES AND FORESTRY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 December 1998, on motion by Mr Vaile:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —The Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry Legislation Amendment Bill (No.2) 1998 amends a series of acts that relate to the rural sector. The opposition does not oppose this legislation at this point, nor do we seek to move any substantial amendments to it.

speech.para: This bill amends the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992, the Dairy Produce Act 1986, the Export Control Act 1982, the Imported Food Control Act 1992 and the Plant Breeder's Rights Act 1994.

With reference to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992, the purpose of the amendment as proposed by the government is to meet Australia's obligations under article 39(3) of the WTO agreement on trade related aspects of intellectual property rights, known as the TRIPS agreement. Applications for the evaluation of new agriculture and veterinary products are submitted to the national registration authority and they may include previously undisclosed data on active ingredients.

The TRIPS agreement requires Australia to provide protection from unfair commercial use of this data, for example in the manufacture of competing genetic products. The amendment ensures that such data will not be made available to commercial competitors for a period of five years without the approval of the originator of the data. From our point of view this is a reasonable amendment, and we will not be opposing it.

The amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 will allow the Australian Dairy Corporation to make payments from its domestic fund as compensation for levies paid, under the Domestic Market Support Scheme, by Victorian dairy farmers and manufacturers who suffered some financial loss due to the Victorian gas crisis last year. As many members would recall, the gas crisis led to many dairy farmers and manufacturers pouring milk down the drain.

Dairy farmers pay a levy on market milk, and manufacturers pay a levy on milk used in manufacturing dairy products sold on the domestic market. The funds which are generated are used to supplement the incomes of those dairy farmers supplying milk for the manufacture of dairy products which are then exported. Milk used for manufacturing delivers farmers a much lower return than milk sold to the fresh milk market. Under current legislation, the levies were still payable by dairy farmers and manufacturers despite the fact that the milk was destroyed and no income was derived. The rebate payable under this amendment is to be the equivalent of the market support payment which would have been received if the milk had been delivered and used as manufacturing milk for export.

The Victorian gas crisis not only affected dairy farmers but businesses throughout the length and breadth of Victoria. Of course, now we have significant class actions being mounted against the producers and the Australian gas industry over this debacle. We will get to the bottom of it—there is an inquiry under way in Victoria. But there is a lesson here for communities as to what really happens to the essential services, such as the provision of electricity and gas, when these services are privatised.

As many of you would know, in the Longford fire two workers lost their lives. What we have witnessed in Victoria is a gradual diminution of the servicing of the basic infrastructure that delivers these particular services to the Victorian community and to rural producers. We have seen it in electricity. Ask any electricity consumer in Geelong and they will tell you that over the last two years, since the privatisation of the electricity system and its sale to foreign interests, we have seen a lack of maintenance being done on basic infrastructure. We have blackout after blackout in the urban areas, but these blackouts also affect dairy farmers and rural producers. When you go to get the cows in in the afternoon and go to turn the milking machines on and you find that your power supply is not there, it is a cause of great concern to you and it can lead to a loss of income.

talk.start.para: —And loss of cows.

—I will not enter that debate. What we have witnessed in Victoria over the past few years is the wholesale privatisation of these public resources. What we have seen is reduced levels of service and problems with the supply of such essential services.

speech.para: The dairy industry is one that will be facing some real challenges as we move into the year 2000 and beyond. This industry is one that I have an interest in because I am the son of a Western District dairy farmer and, in my political life, I have been through some of the tensions that have been generated over the restructuring in this industry in the early 1980s. When we came to power in the early 1980s we were left an industry that had grown very comfortable behind a very heavily deregulated environment. We proceeded along the path of restructuring that industry in a way that ensured that the basic productive capacity of the industry was retained and improved while providing for dairy farmers to exit the industry.

There were many dairy farmers that I knew when I was growing up in the Western District of Victoria whose livelihoods were truncated by the reforms that were introduced at that time. But they were necessary reforms to reorient this industry to an export task. It now enjoys a level of profitability and has certainly been one of the mainstays of agricultural production in this country over the past decade. It owes its current position and, indeed, its future in fairly competitive global markets to the vision of Labor ministers at the time. I refer to John Kerin and Simon Crean, who had to grapple with the problems of refocusing and restructuring an industry to take advantage of its market potential.

I can recall in the 1983 campaign, when I campaigned in the seat of Corangamite against the then minister Tony Street, and later in 1984 against the current member for Corangamite, Stewart McArthur, attending a rally of dairy farmers down in the Heytesbury in Victoria. I tell this story because it does give an indication of the tensions that can be generated in an industry through restructuring. We met the representatives of the dairy farmers at the local municipal offices and I say, quite openly, that, if they had had a rope there, they would have hanged us. We were the devils incarnate, the socialists coming to tell them how to restructure their industry.

Leaving the politics aside—because there were members of the coalition who were in there feeding the frenzy about what the ugly socialists were going to do to their industry—we put an argument to them that their industry had a realisable potential but it had to meet an existing threat. That threat was going to come from New Zealand producers, from the New Zealand dairy industry, and the Australian industry was not prepared for the export challenges that were going to be necessary to ensure its survival in the long term.

This was not an issue that was particularly confined to the dairy industry. It was one that we had to face in the major restructurings in steel, automotive and component manufacture and in the textile, clothing and footwear industries. So it was a turbulent time for the dairy industry.

It weathered that particular storm and positioned itself as one of the more profitable, and consistently profitable, industries over the past decade. Now it faces a new challenge and a new task, given the opportunities that are emerging in export markets and the structure of the domestic industry. I can only commend the industry to intensive debate and discussion, without the politics, about the industry's future.

As I said, in 1984 I had to suffer National Party and Liberal Party members going around rural Victoria and trying to make hay while the sun shone as far as this issue was concerned. It caused particular pain and worry to producers in the industry, and it was not really conducive to an intelligent and informed debate about where the industry might go.

I know I am digressing just a little, but I call for all sections of the industry to engage in a meaningful and productive debate on the industry's future. There are some markers that have to be put out as far as future deregulation of this industry is concerned. We have to have our eye to the regional impacts of the decisions that are taken when particular plans and legislation come to an end. We have to keep in mind that the consumers of this product need to be assured that, if a deregulated environment were to be engendered as far as this industry is concerned, there would be some benefit to them and it would not all flow to the major supermarket chains nor to the processors. Those discussions are well under way in your state, Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, and you would be more acquainted, probably than any other in the House today, with the problems that a deregulated environment may cause in the states of New South Wales and Queensland.

It is very important that this debate proceed in an honest, frank and intelligent way so that governments can make rational decisions about the legislative frameworks in which industries will have to operate beyond particular days, regional communities can plan for any consequences that might flow from decisions, and the industry and the producers can prepare themselves adequately for the challenges that they are going to face over the next decade.

In reference to the amendments to the Export Control Act 1982, the regulatory controls are necessary to ensure that prescribed goods for export are fit for human consumption, match their trade description, and have been prepared in such a way as to meet the import requirements of Australia's export market. This amendment clarifies the power of the secretary to approve and administer quality and safety assurance arrangements for the production of prescribed goods for exports. It also makes some amendments to the enforcement powers for the entry and search of premises or vehicles and for the copying or seizure of evidence relating to export control matters.

I think this is a fairly important amendment because many producers in the past have not kept their eye on the requirements of the markets in which they have intended their produce to go. If we go back over the last 15 years, the great task has been to alter the export culture of primary producers to make sure that they are fully aware of the requirements of the markets in which they are intending to send produce. Too often in the past—for example, with onions and potatoes, the industries with which I am more familiar than others—growers basically grew produce for a domestic market. If they had a fairly good element of their crop, they sought to drop it onto the export market and seek a higher return. There was no real planning to grow for an export market and for the requirements of that market and to ensure, as far as food safety issues and the produce was concerned, that they met the trade requirements of the markets in which their produce was being sold. So it is an amendment that the opposition supports. We think it is an important one to proceed with.

The amendment to the Imported Food Control Act 1992 provides for the inspection and control of food imported into Australia and is used in conjunction with the Quarantine Act 1908. It allows certain kinds of foods to be defined as trade samples; it gives the secretary power to approve or revoke approval for a food processing operation; and it allows importers to claim compensation from the Commonwealth for food which, as a result of the inspection process, has been rendered unfit for the purpose for which it was imported. It is an amendment that the opposition supports.

The amendment to the Plant Breeder's Rights Act 1994 provides for the naming of new plant varieties in an easier manner by allowing duplication of plant names provided that the plant with the same name is from an entirely different plant class. This is a technical amendment that will streamline procedures under the Plant Breeder's Rights Act 1994. It is in conformity with international standards that prevail in this area so we will not be opposing that amendment; we will be supporting it. This legislation, in the main, is non-contentious and therefore we will be supporting the amendments that are being proposed.

talk.start.para: —This bill is an omnibus bill, and I guess the huge number of people clamouring to speak on it indicates how comprehensive and significant it is. Taken in its various elements, it has great impact on various industries around Australia. For somebody wishing to debate large issues and general philosophical thrusts and changes of policy, this bill would not be an attractive bill to debate. But it has in its application and administration great significance for important elements of Australian agricultural industries.

speech.para: I want to deal with some of those elements in the debate today because I want to sound something of a warning to the administrators of our agricultural industries that if they make life too difficult for our producers they are working almost as a foreign power against the export potential and cost structure of Australian industry.

It is possible through tax systems, through banking systems and through transportation systems to inadvertently impose costs on Australian exporters and Australian producers. For instance, if our taxation system is not simple and competitive in administrative terms and it takes Australian businesses and primary producers longer to fulfil their tax obligations, then we are loading unnecessary costs onto them, unnecessary time and a diversion of resources onto them, which will ultimately penalise the nation as a whole. The same may be said for government administration of all types.

I encourage our administrators, as they look at legislative changes and policy changes, to remember that the implementation process should have as its No. 1 objective the aim of being as competitive, as clean, as excellent in the administration process as any exporter is required to be. I know that is often their goal but from time to time we get competing organisations, wishing to retain their employment base and their influence, attempting to build unnecessary restrictions and structures.

Mr Deputy Speaker Causley, being a man of practical background, I know that you would agree with me that the administration and implementation of regulations and laws can be detrimental if they are interventionist or unnecessarily complex. That can impose costs and complications on our primary producers that they just cannot afford or do not need. Mr Deputy Speaker, I do not wish to drag you into this debate but with your experience in the government of New South Wales I know that you are well across all of those areas. I have heard you speak on a number of occasions on the need for Australians to administer effective, sensible laws relating to agriculture, fisheries and forestry.

This bill covers a number of provisions including the protection of intellectual property for new constituents in agricultural and veterinary chemicals, a very important area. It seeks also to overcome the unintended consequences of the Dairy Produce Act.

The bill seeks to facilitate administrative arrangements for export controls so as to enable exporters to take a greater role in product quality under the guidance of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service, AQIS. It allows for the clarification of trade samples, delegating some authorities to inspection and evaluation. The bill seeks also to facilitate the easier naming of plant varieties under the Plant Variety Rights Act.

I want to deal with a couple of elements in the legislation. Firstly, I would like to deal with the plant variety rights aspect of the Plant Variety Rights Act. Plant variety rights do not have a long history in Australia but they have a very significant history because after a lot of pressure from Australian nursery and plant breeding industries, both horticultural and agricultural, Australia introduced the Plant Variety Rights Act.

We have brilliant scientists developing new species of plants and varieties which have been great export winners for Australia. Unfortunately, in the world of competition we have had a number of foreign plant breeders come to Australia, take overseas the seeds or plant material of a variety of Australian plants, look at the genetic structure of, or by selective breeding modify, them and develop them to a point where they become a world bestseller in the nursery industry. In particular, I think of the first example that I became aware of, which was the plant breeders of Israel taking the Australian Geraldton wax to Israel and, through selection and careful breeding, turning it into quite a different plant, which is now dominating the world almost as if it was an Israeli plant. That has happened in a number of instances, but we are getting better at it. We are, in fact, having quite a significant impact on world plant breeding with the uniqueness of Australia's own indigenous species and also the work that is being done with commercial crops and cereal types.

I had the good fortune to know of one of Australia's great plant and wheat breeders, Professor Irving Watson, who developed rust-proof wheat varieties that became for many years a household name across Australia. A protege of his, a Hungarian migrant, Nick Derera, who is currently at an advanced age, has been brought back into Sydney University. He is a man so brilliant that Sydney University could not do without him. In his eighties they have brought him back to a full professorship at Sydney University to continue his plant breeding. Nick was instrumental, with Irving Watson, in establishing the Australian cotton industry and has been decorated by Her Majesty and by foreign governments.

Now Nick Derera is developing a paprika industry because he knows that we can breed and produce great capsicums here in Australia. We can replace all the imports of paprika, but we can also follow the South African trend and make this a multimillion dollar export industry. Nick has done great work at Cobbity research farm. He has pointed out to me that these plant variety changes, whilst significant in allowing Australian producers a greater flexibility in choosing names for their own products or for products they have imported and which are protected by plant variety rights, maintain the consistency of plant variety right protection. That is a commercial consideration.

These amendments are welcome but there are still further amendments needed to protect an inadvertent change in the act from the Plant Variety Rights Act to the Plant Breeder's Rights Act. Some of the work by people like Nick Derera could be knocked off by anybody. An amendment is urgent to protect people like Nick Derera, and I know the minister has that in hand; it is in the pipeline. Nick Derera can safely say, `If anybody tries to play with my plant material that I am using to establish this new industry, the full force of the act will come down on them because it will be protected.'

I want to praise our plant breeders, compliment the government for these changes, and encourage the government to go further and indicate that the research and development programs that we have in agriculture should encourage our plant breeders who are dealing with both indigenous species and commercial crops and varieties.

The second issue I want to raise is that of the changes to exports and the powers of the Australian Quarantine and Inspection Service. I have had an unfortunate experience over the years with AQIS. I do not know whether every member has had the same experience, but at one stage they made claims that they had researched pig quarantine measures and the safety of certain diseases around the world. They wrote to members saying they had done that. I checked with those foreign governments and AQIS had not contacted a single university—yet they said they had been in touch.

I made a speech in the House a couple of years ago, but AQIS are too busy to even acknowledge those sorts of concerns. Maybe one day they will. But until they can explain themselves, honestly, fairly and up front in everything they do, I am going to have a doubt about that organisation. I have got plant producers and plant breeders in my electorate. Mitchell is a huge, multimillion dollar production area. We have got most of Australia's mushroom growers and we have got heaps of strawberry and cut-flower growers. These people rely on complete protection for the clean, green image. They are so close not only to the airports and to people that want to sneak stuff in and in some way smuggle plant varieties in—which occurs; I acknowledge that and that is not possible to control—but also to the threats of imported plants and plant types from everywhere around the world.

Valentine's Day has just passed; there were truckloads of flowers from all over the world in the Sydney city markets on Valentine's Day. Bugs were found in those plants. I am told by one of the local growers that on one of the imported plants there was a hard-shelled beetle of some sort. The plants were supposed to be fumigated. AQIS said the bug would die in 24 hours; the bug is still living happily down in Sydney. Valentine's Day was a few days ago but the bug is still alive. Who knows what the bug is or what it is carrying?

I acknowledge that we have got to make a decision about what is sensible protection. But we have also got to think that it is a tremendous advantage for the flower-growing industry of Zimbabwe or India to lob onto Australia plant pests or diseases we have not currently got. If they can load us up with pests or diseases that we currently do not have and that they do have, that levels the cost equation between the countries and may in fact knock out some Australian industries.

Western flower thrip is in Australia, and white rust. AQIS will claim, `Don't look at us. We could not possibly have let it in.' All the evidence points to the fact that it came in in commercial imports but, of course, you cannot identify which plant. I think we need to have a system where we can have our authorities say, `We know that it did not come in through our system. We are certain.' All they can say at the moment is that it probably did not and that is their side of the argument. The industries are saying, `It probably did,' because they can trace back to where they think the first contact was made.

Some of the provisions in this bill are allowing a tighter control of our exports and I believe in quality control in our exports. That is very significant. But I would like to put the counterbalance to tighter control of exports by saying that, if we are going to come down hard on Australian growers to maintain the standards of our exports, we must also make sure that our importers are not bringing in plant material which carries the risk of disease and pests that we have not seen in Australia. Western flower thrip is a high-cost pest that really should not have got into Australia. We have got it now and there will be, I am told by a reliable authority, a major outbreak of plant or animal threats of a significant type at least four times a year. I think we need to be jolly careful about this; we have got a great export advantage and we need to maintain it.

It is okay saying that all the scientists say this or something else. We are thinking about bringing in fruit from China, and the protection against fruit fly, I understand, is the acceptance of the Chinese practice of one fruit fly trap in every 100 trees. That is not protection for Australian industry and I would like to draw the minister's and the House's attention to the fact that it is no good jumping on Australian exporters to maintain quality—I agree with that—if we do not on the other hand say that we are also endorsing their efforts by preventing somebody inadvertently or by design dumping in Australia diseases or pests that should not be here.

Finally, I wish to refer briefly to another measure in the changes to the act: the registration processes for agricultural and veterinary chemicals. Chemical engineering is a great Australian industry and one that is not very frequently recognised by government. We have a multitude of very enthusiastic administrators there that want to nominate, describe and register every molecule and every chemical known to man, including things like common salt.

The administration for our Australian agricultural and veterinary chemical industries has gone up dramatically. My plea to the government is to sort this mess out because we have got at least two organisations, possibly three, competing for fees, registration and recognition for agricultural and veterinary chemical industries.

There are good reasons why there should be two organisations. It has been the government's commitment that they should be reduced to one; the government has not reduced them to one but I know work is being done and has been done over a period to reduce it to one organisation. The duplicated cost to industry is needless and should be removed. The more quickly that can be done, the better. Those people who are holding onto power bases or claiming particular protection for particular groups of people, saying that we must have a really safe system, are more interested, I think, in maintaining their bureaucracies than they are in doing something for the large number of Australians who would benefit not only from easily and positively identified Australian veterinary and agricultural chemicals but also from those products being available at a significantly lower price.

This matter goes also to the coverage of new products, both those which can be developed by Australian chemical engineers and those which are imported to Australia. We should have access to the latest and the best, provided it is properly tested, and we should be encouraging Australian producers not only to manufacture and to export but also to innovate and develop new products.

talker.name: Tuckey, Wilson, MP
Mr TUCKEY
talker.role: Forestry and Conservation; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister

talk.start.para: —I have been asked to attend on behalf of the Minister for Agriculture, Forestry and Fisheries, who is otherwise engaged, to respond to the many speakers on the amendments contained in the Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1998 , which cover a number of issues, and to thank them for their participation. I can assure those speakers that their comments will be considered by the minister, as they would normally be, and the minister has asked me to make the following remarks.

speech.para: The proposed amendments to the Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals (Administration) Act 1992 provide five years protection for undisclosed test and/or other data submitted to the National Registration Authority for Agricultural and Veterinary Chemicals, NRA, for the valuation of a new active constituent for an agricultural or veterinary chemical product.

The five-year data protection period for agricultural and veterinary new chemical entities will have a negligible effect on the NRA, which will be responsible for administering the provisions of the proposed amendments. In the vast majority of cases, the five-year data protection period will lapse before the expiry of the patent term, thereby having no effect on the marketing of generic products. It will, however, remove any doubt about whether Australia is fulfilling its obligations under article 39(3) of the World Trade Organisation agreement on trade related aspects of intellectual property rights, generally referred to as the TRIPS agreement.

The proposed amendments to the Dairy Produce Act 1986 are designed to ensure that the difficulties experienced by sectors of the dairy industry during the Victorian gas crisis are not compounded by the operation of the Commonwealth's Domestic Market Support Scheme. The proposed amendments have the full support of the Australian dairy industry.

The proposed amendments to the Export Control Act 1982 reflect the Commonwealth's commitment to a system of approved quality assurance arrangements that properly ensure the higher standards of product safety, the appropriate level of company accountability and a cost-effective food industry.

The proposed amendments to the Imported Food Control Act 1992 anticipate a more effective and efficient service to industry by clarifying some aspects of the act which have previously been confusing or caused an inconsistent application of the act.

The amendments to the Plant Breeder's Rights Act 1994 will simplify the naming of new plant varieties. It allows for two or more varieties to have the same name, provided that they are completely different and unlikely to be confused in the marketplace—for instance, turnips and tulips. Duplication of names will not be allowed within a group of closely related genera called plant classes. A list of plant classes consistent with international standards will be maintained by the registrar of the plant breeder's rights scheme and will be accessible free of charge. Industry, particularly the horticultural industry, supports this improvement and encourages its earliest introduction.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that this bill be reported to the House without amendment.

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 December, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —This bill is welcomed by the opposition as a step forward in the reduction of greenhouse gas emissions. The bill widens the definition of a vehicle standard for new motor vehicles to include standards for energy saving. At the moment, the Motor Vehicle Standards Act defines a vehicle standard as having three characteristics: being designed to make road vehicles safe to use, or to control the emission of gas, particles or noise from road vehicles, or to secure road vehicles against theft.

speech.para: This bill adds a new design parameter to that definition by adding the words `to promote the saving of energy', and that will enable the development of additional standards designed to do just that. Once these new standards are developed, they will be included in regulations made under the Motor Vehicles Standards Act 1989 and they will become mandatory in Australian design rules applicable, Australia wide, to new vehicles.

The government initially intends to use this new standard to develop an Australian design rule for model specific, fuel efficiency labelling, although it is important to note that these amendments do not preclude other standards from being developed. Fuel consumption labelling forms part of the government's environmental strategy for the automotive industry, included in its 1997 climate change package. The new Australian design rule is being developed by the Australian Greenhouse Office in consultation with the Federal Office of Road Safety. Once that rule is developed and introduced, all new cars will carry fuel efficiency labelling setting out the fuel consumption of the particular vehicle. This means that new car buyers will have an easy comparison of fuel consumption between vehicles, like we have with fridges, with the stickers with stars on them. I think it helps.

I also think it would be good—and I would ask the minister to take this on board for consideration—to take the opportunity offered by the new design rule to look at extending this labelling to the advertising of new vehicles. I understand that the United States has had this requirement for well over a decade now. What happens there is that in any advertisement, whether it is print or television, there is also a label, which has to be carried down the bottom of the advertisement, indicating the car's fuel consumption. It is just another, more public way of educating people to take that into consideration when making purchases. I do not think it is a particularly onerous requirement, and I think it is a helpful one if we are serious about educating people to think about how they individually can contribute to the reduction of greenhouse gases.

It is worth remarking on the fact that the 1996 National Greenhouse Gas Inventory tells us transport is responsible for 17 per cent of greenhouse gas emissions, with road transport responsible for 87 per cent of those emissions. Cars are responsible for more than half of transport's greenhouse gas emissions and for 10 per cent of Australia's total emissions. Consequently, they are responsible for a contribution to air pollution in our cities.

This bill is a positive step—we acknowledge that—towards reducing those emissions, although we do have to consider the way in which this could possibly be undermined by the government's proposals to reduce diesel fuel excise and what that will mean for heavy road transport's contribution to the total emissions. I do not intend to go into that today. I simply put on the record the opposition's support for this bill and our support for fuel consumption labelling.

talk.start.para: —I call the honourable member for Dunkley—in a very bright tie.
—Mr Deputy Speaker, are you unhappy with my tie? I will pass on your thoughts to my wife. Quite frankly, she is a Greek goddess, and I am not brave enough not to wear it, Mr Deputy Speaker.

speech.para: I compliment the previous speaker on her contribution. I also compliment the last speaker on the previous bill, the honourable member for Mitchell; we will all practise fruit fly trap for the rest of the day.

I am pleased to be able to talk in support of the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 1998 . It brings together two areas of government policy that very much interest me. One is improving the performance of government, which this bill seeks to do by tidying up some of the administrative arrangements that support the implementation of these types of measures and by enabling the delegates of the minister to act on his behalf.

The second area that interests me is its contribution to Australia's greenhouse gas emissions effort. I will start with the latter point because I think it is worth reflecting on the importance of this measure in the context of the Prime Minister's 20 November 1997 statement on greenhouse issues, Safeguarding the future: Australia's response to climate change. The issues that were outlined in that statement by the Prime Minister were very comprehensive and were designed to deliver on Australia's commitments that have been entered into through the Kyoto process. Naturally, they are not binding at this stage because many of the member states have not gone through the formal ratification process, but it is a guide to the responsible approach the government will take into the future and in meeting our commitments in the future accounting periods under the Kyoto protocol.

What I like about this particular measure is that it is something we can all get behind. The member for Dickson spoke about individuals wanting to do something in this area and I concur with those remarks. We have seen in areas like recycling and in other conservation and environment related areas of concern that the ordinary citizen wants to do their bit. They want to be able to make a small contribution towards a national or international effort to address some of these environmental concerns. With recycling, we have probably been killed with people's enthusiasm to get involved, as the downstream processing of some of the products that are available for recycling has not quite kept pace with the supplies of recyclable products that Australian consumers are putting back into the waste management system. In this example, though, it is a chance for individual consumers to make some choices about their behaviour and how it will impact on emissions from Australia. This measure tools up consumers with information that will enable them to make some choices about which vehicles to buy into the future under a reliable set of reporting arrangements embraced as a standard.

The bill expands the range of standards that can be implemented under the Motor Vehicle Standards Act to include energy conservation and fuel efficiency. That is particularly significant in light of the contribution that emissions from motor vehicles, or, more generally, the transport sector, make towards the total greenhouse gas emissions in Australia.

There are a number of very in-depth and well-considered reports around. One of them I have here with me, which is the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics working paper No. 37, which talks about tradable permits in transport. While we are not here to talk about tradable permits, the document canvasses issues about the transport sector and how it will play its role in the reduction of the emissions from the broader Australian economy. It points to some options that, frankly, are flagged as not being terribly manageable or not being sound and efficient administratively in terms of what the transport sector can do to reduce our emissions.

What is attractive about this proposal before us today is that it fits very neatly with and responds quite directly to some of the concerns that have been raised in this paper. I have talked about tradable permits on other occasions and I will not go into that today. But if you reduce that sort of thinking down to individual motorists, it becomes a bureaucratic and administrative nightmare. It is difficult to imagine how, at an individual level, a tradable permits system would bring about changes in people's behaviour, because many of the decisions that are made about people's behaviour in terms of their motoring habits and the vehicles they buy would be removed in some way from the particular permits that would operate at an individual level if a full tradable system were implemented.

That has been recognised by the government in that there are other more direct policy measures required to make sure that all sectors of the economy are doing their share towards reducing the growth in our emissions of greenhouse gases. This particular measure is one of those. I like it because it is, I think, something we in this place can agree on—and that is nice—but it is also something that those outside this place can agree on.

I know the motor industry itself is taking its responsibilities very seriously. I would like to put on the record my respect and support for the work that people like Mr Russell Scoular, a friend of mine who works at Ford who is heavily involved in this area, and others involved in the motor vehicle industry are doing to make sure that the difficult problems around other measures, as outlined in the Bureau of Transport and Communications Economics working paper No. 37, are not an impediment to the motor industry doing something at all.

This particular bill will see a standard introduced where consumers will have reliable and consistently compiled fuel consumption information at their fingertips. It actually goes further than some of the similar measures which are around overseas. The explanatory memorandum points to the United States, Japan and, I think, some European countries that have taken steps in this direction. In the US, the mandatory measures tend to relate to a consumption rate across the whole suite of vehicles a manufacturer is putting into the marketplace. While they do support that with individual fuel consumption information, as the member for Dickson pointed out, and are quite adamant in having that information communicated to consumers, the mandatory obligations relate to a whole suite of vehicles.

We have gone a bit further here. We are talking about mandatory obligations on fuel consumption reporting at an individual vehicle level. Just to illustrate what that means: if I was in the market for a small car and, being a bit of a Holden man, was attracted to some of the Barina product line or to some of the Astra product line but knew there were some much larger engine capacity, higher fuel consumption vehicles in the top end of the Holden range, I might not get the information I wanted about the particular vehicle I was interested in if we applied parts of some of this whole-of-fleet mandatory regime.

Under this proposal, though, I will get that information about the particular vehicle I am interested in purchasing and I can compare that with other vehicles on the shop floor. It tools up consumers with information to do something themselves at an individual level, and that is what is really first class about this proposal.

We are still faced with other issues in the motor vehicle industry that need to be addressed in the context of our greenhouse gas responsibilities. There are some questions concerning the age of Australia's vehicle fleet, and I have talked previously about that subject under a private member's motion dealing specifically with it. But just to recap on some of those themes, the age of the Australian vehicle fleet causes some inherent problems, not only because many drivers use vehicles that do not have the latest technology, safety measures and fuel efficiency devices that are available but also because they run on unleaded fuel. Unleaded fuel itself has other problems outside greenhouse gas emissions—obviously lead emission being the key one—and at this stage we are still moving towards the date in 2010 when we will look to have leaded fuel taken off the market.

There is an argument that we might look at bringing that date forward, but we have got to be mindful of the age of the vehicle fleet and what such a measure would do. I think that, with some of the petrol companies already producing half-lead fuels and derivative fuels that can run in leaded engines, we do have some encouragement to look at bringing that date forward. But we need to bear in the back of our minds that more than 30 per cent of all the fuel sold today is leaded fuel.

We have also before us some work to do at a broader level about our emissions trading responsibilities under our greenhouse gas commitments. What I like about this vehicle standards amendment is that cars being imported into this country, as I understand it, will have to meet the same requirements as domestically produced cars in terms of their vehicle fuel consumption performance.

It raises other questions about how, in this greenhouse gas emitting world and under some of the framework set up with the Kyoto protocol, we are going to harmonise the behaviour of countries that are in the loop and have made commitments to reducing their emissions and those countries that are outside the loop and under the banner of being a developing country. At least here, if we have motor vehicles that are manufactured in those developing countries where, at the point of manufacture, emissions are not being fully taken into account, under Kyoto, the product of that effort, when it comes into a more developed market such as ours, needs to apprise itself of those global responsibilities.

It also leaves some broader questions about trade. Here we are recognising that products offshore that have an impact on greenhouse emissions need to come within a more responsible emissions net. At the same time there are other manufactured products, coming out of developing countries in particular—where emissions are not a high priority—competing with goods manufactured domestically where we have to keep an eye on the emissions produced. There seems to be a tad of inconsistency there. I have talked previously about whether we might need to look at climate control compliance measures on imported goods coming out of undeveloped countries into our mature market so that our domestic manufacturers are at least competing on a level footing. That is about fairer trade and fairer competition, and that is a subject I would very much like to talk more about at another time.

I might leave my contribution at that today. I am grateful that the deputy speaker has changed: he might find my tie more acceptable than did the previous incumbent of the chair. I commend the bill to the House and think it is a small but important step towards a sensible way for our nation to address its greenhouse gas emission responsibilities. That is important; it is important for my little son, Alexander, because he will be here dealing with the world as it is long after I have gone somewhere else and do not need to worry about the ties I am wearing.

talk.start.para: —In saying a few words I am not going to repeat what the Motor Vehicle Standards Amendment Bill 1998 is all about; all the other speakers have done that. The changes to the Australian design rules being facilitated by this bill will remind us that we are able to change Australian design rules. There is an Australian design rule being introduced now which very badly needs to be changed. The aerodynamic, sweptback shape of the modern car results in the driver being exposed to sunlight and solar radiation which cause skin cancers. Two Mount Isa taxi drivers came to me. One has a very serious skin cancer problem and the other looks as though he may have the same problem. While some of these people work in shorts, some do not; they drive with long trousers on—all of them drive with long trousers on now. But even trousers do not give you all that much protection and, unless you wear gloves, your hands are constantly exposed to the sunlight coming into your car.

speech.para: In addition to that, what you create with the modern car design is a glass bubble. For those of you who are not familiar with what happens when you have a glass bubble, radiation can travel through the glass, but it changes its wavelength after it has travelled through the glass and cannot get back out again, and that is what is called the greenhouse effect. So in every one of our cars now we have a little greenhouse machine keeping the heat in.

The vast majority of Australians use airconditioners in their cars all the time. The fuel consumption that is arising as a result of the glass bubble effect, of course, makes what we are doing here today very irrelevant unless we address the problem of modern car design, the glass bubble design. The average airconditioner pulls, if my memory serves me correctly, five horsepower, which is an awful lot of power. In fact, if you are driving along you will notice the loss of acceleration and speed the minute you turn the airconditioning on, because it does take an awful lot of power to run the small compressor which works your airconditioner.

Our airconditioners in northern Australia are simply not adequate to cool cars. We can have an airconditioner on maximum speed, maximum freezing, and still it will not cool the car because the car is designed, albeit inadvertently, as a glass bubble. This design may be suitable for Europe, but it is very interesting that it is not a design suitable for the United States where the vast majority of the population now are in Texas and California. In fact, 30 million people live in southern California and, I think, pretty close to 30 million people live in Texas and the other southern states of the United States. Of course, Europe is now dominating the world stage with 550 million consumers. They are quite happy with the glass bubble effect because it is suitable for their climate.

It is most unsuitable for our climate. Having had this very real problem presented to me, I know that people will die. In fact, there was a report recently in the Queensland media—and I must emphasise that I have not verified whether it was accurate—which said that skin cancer is the second biggest killer in Queensland, after heart disease. I do not think that anyone would argue that it is not a major cause of death in Australia. When I see a lot of our older citizens—and I must say this—without ears and noses and parts of their cheeks as a result of this, I consider that it is a problem that governments should be addressing in Australia.

I started my little campaign by ringing Choice magazine—the Australian Consumers Association—and asking to speak to the editor. I cannot help but say that over a period of the next eight months I made somewhere between 15 and 25 telephone calls and I have still not been able to speak to the editor of Choice magazine. She must be a very important person because she does not speak to people. I have spoken to other people there to say that I wish to proceed with this. The logical place to start would be with the Australian Consumers Association and Choice magazine but they are not even interested enough to return a telephone call. If people are dying of cancer out there, this does not seem to be of any interest whatsoever to the Australian Consumers Association and Choice magazine. I would ask any of the government decision makers who may be here today that, if there is any government money going into those areas, they seriously consider whether this is a responsible organisation or not.

The reason I am acting with considerable anger towards this organisation is that we have a very serious problem indeed. Ralph Nader did a wonderful job in the United States saving so many lives by his aggression on the issue of dangerous motor cars that was brought to his attention. We have an organisation in Australia which, when a situation which is extremely dangerous to the health of Australians is brought to them, cannot even be bothered to return a telephone call over a period of eight months—a matter of, as I say, between 15 and 25 phone calls.

Perhaps the Australian design rules can be changed; I do not know whether substances can be put into the glass to stop the UV light from coming through. Clothing gives very modified protection so do not think that clothing or gloves can overcome this very serious and dangerous problem. There is also the issue of increased fuel consumption because of the greenhouse effect in the motor car. So we are defeating all of our purposes here today unless we address the problem of this glass.

I do not know if the minister at the table, the honourable member for Wide Bay, is responsible for this area, but I would like to see the minister responsible for this matter run an annual cancer award for the car with the least protective roof. There will be a lot of very strong contenders for that prize. That is how I believe this thing should be because I have very strong feelings about this, having seen so many of our oldest and greatest citizens from North Queensland ravaged by skin cancer in the most terrible manner.

There is another issue which needs to be addressed here with respect to fuel consumption. Transfield came to the Queensland government and approached four separate ministries in Queensland—the premier's department, the mines and energy department, the northern development department and the primary industries department—with a proposal to put a 10 per cent ethanol content into motor cars.

Ethanol is much more expensive than petrol. They were not proposing that they replace petrol with ethanol, as is done in Brazil—98 per cent of fuel in Brazil came from sugarcane, but that is now down to about 60 per cent—where 60 per cent of fuel in cars in Brazil is ethanol from sugarcane. They are selling that at world prices so there is no subsidisation going into the fuel tanks.

When I was working on this matter in 1988, the average in the United States was between two per cent and four per cent, depending upon which authority I used. The United States already has an ethanol content in its fuel tanks and the percentage varies from state to state. In Canada it is a bit higher, and there are a number of other countries throughout the world that have relatively high ethanol content in their fuel.

Transfield explained to me that they did not want to replace petrol with ethanol—a notion which I knew was absolutely stupid—they wanted to replace with ethanol the lead that had been taken out. If you put in a 10 per cent ethanol blend you did not need to put in the expensive additives that now have to be added to raise the octane level because lead has been taken out. It was really a replacement for these expensive additives.

In my department we had Wright and Killen from Texas, and Fluor Daniel from Texas, do the figures. The premier's department and the mines and energy department used other engineers, and the primary industries department did not submit a paper to cabinet. All three of those ministries said that it would be about the same cost, or cheaper, for super grade petrol. And they said it probably would be the same cost, or maybe a bit more expensive, for lower octane rated petrol.

We felt that price-wise it would have been neutral. I would not say that it would have reduced the price, but on the figures that we had available to us from the best engineers in the world, we felt the price would have been about the same as it was at the time for petrol, and that that fuel would have given a cleaner burn, a better octane rating and better performance in the cars.

It would also have dramatically lowered the greenhouse effect coming from motor cars because to get this petrol we would have had to grow sugarcane and, of course, an average sugar mill will take two million tonnes of carbon dioxide out of the air. There would be a massive change in the net greenhouse effect if we went to an ethanol content, and the carbon credits that would flow in this area would be massive. So there is another ball game out there that should be being addressed.

This was not the reason why we were proceeding, but there was a by-product effect which was of enormous benefit to the Australian economy. World sugarcane prices have dropped dramatically. We do not have the protection of a home market any more, like all the other countries, and we are up against slave labour produced product out of South America in countries like Brazil. We are up against massive subsidies in Thailand. Believe it or not, there is nearly a 100 per cent subsidy in Thailand. And according to a report to the President of the United States in 1990, the subsidy tariff levels on the biggest sugar exporter at the time—and it is still the second biggest sugar exporter in the world, the European Community—was 193 per cent.

We could get long-term contractual arrangements at $360 a tonne—maybe even $380 a tonne—with this arrangement which would underpin the price of almost a quarter to a fifth of our Australian sugar production as well. So there was an enormous side benefit for one of Australia's major export earning industries and one of Australia's major industries, the sugar industry.

Whilst I think this is a very good move, the problem of the aerodynamic shape and this massive glass bubble effect that we have in our motor cars must be attacked now because it is causing cancer. It is also causing a massive increase in the consumption of petrol to keep those airconditioners burning at a level that they should never be burning at. There is another safety issue, of course. If you have glass covering your motor car instead of steel, it is far more dangerous; far less protection is afforded the passengers if you have steel over your head instead of glass over your head.

We are exposed to the dangers of car accidents; we are exposed to the dangers of skin cancer; and also our motor cars are becoming heat traps that are causing a very dramatic increase in the consumption of petrol. A little by-product of a manoeuvre in that direction would be of massive help to one of Australia's great industries—the sugar industry.

talk.start.para: —At the outset, I thank the members for Dickson, Dunkley and Kennedy for their contributions to this debate. In her fleeting contribution, the member for Dickson acknowledged the opposition's support for this legislation and we are grateful for that support. I merely comment on her reference to opposition concerns about government proposals to reduce fuel taxation in regional areas. I am not sure whether that is the ex-Democrat speaking or the new Labor spokesperson for regional affairs, but let me assure you that the government takes very seriously the cost of fuel in regional areas. These taxation measures are a significant proposal to help equalise the costs of living around Australia and to ensure that regional Australia is able to effectively share in the economic growth of our country. All people in rural and regional Australia will be gravely concerned to hear the comments of the honourable member for Dickson about proposed changes to fuel taxation.

speech.para: I compliment the member for Dunkley on his contribution and his recognition of the importance of consumers being aware of the energy usage of vehicles and of the contribution this bill will make towards having a more informed marketplace.

I think we were all interested in the comments of the member for Kennedy. Let me say, as a fellow Queenslander, that I share his concerns about the impact of the increasing level of glass, particularly on the tops of recently designed vehicles. A compromise is obviously being made between the aerodynamic styling, the attractive looks, and the effect that that has on the occupants of the vehicle. I am one who always tries to order a sun visor for my vehicle and I am finding it increasingly difficult to do so. I am told that some of the new models are coming out—with sun visors only designed at a later stage. Certainly, many of the manufacturers discourage the fitting of sun visors, because they rightly point out that it affects the fuel economy of the vehicle. There is no doubt that that is the case. It also affects the lines that the designers have chosen for the vehicles.

Many of the new cars have very little metal on top at all and the driver's seating position is exposed to the sunlight through the windscreen for the majority of the day. I think that is a matter of concern. I will certainly raise that matter with my colleague the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Mr Anderson, and ask him to take the issue on board. I think it is a relevant issue and we do have to make judgments as a community as to whether some of those issues are so important from a health perspective that they have to be given priority.

I would like to make one other point to perhaps emphasise and support what the member for Kennedy said: it is not only the risk of skin cancer that is associated with exposure through the high glass contents of vehicles, but it also raises the temperature in the vehicle. They become much hotter and that has implications for airconditioning and also the safety of the occupants. There have been many tragic cases of that having an effect, particularly on young children who are left in vehicles. Some of those things I appreciate are difficult issues. The world believes very strongly, for very valid reasons, that we need to improve fuel economy wherever we possibly can but there are certainly other factors that need to be taken into account.

In the climate change statement of 20 November 1997, the Prime Minister announced that model specific fuel efficiency labelling was to be implemented as a part of the automotive industry environment strategy. The bill debated today will amend the Motor Vehicle Standards Act of 1989—the vehicle for Australian design rules—to allow that commitment to be met. Consumers and the environment will benefit from the introduction of the new ADR to make fuel efficiency labelling of motor vehicles mandatory—a concept similar to the energy efficiency labels on household electrical appliances that we have all come to expect in this day and age.

It is anticipated that the draft ADR and the regulation impact statement for this ADR will be released for public comment shortly, giving industry the opportunity to contribute to the development of this important measure. The proposed amended definition of `vehicle standard' is also broad enough to enable other agreed greenhouse/fuel conservation objectives to be implemented in the future, a point that was made by the honourable member for Dickson.

A number of other measures are contained in this bill. Notably, the ability to appoint an associate administrator which will allow the Federal Office of Road Safety to provide a better service to clients by ensuring that the functions of the administrator, particularly the routine ones, can be performed by more than one person. The remaining amendments are essentially mechanical in nature, aimed at improving the administration of the act. They include restoring the connection between this act and the Customs Act 1901 and removing a duplication of penalties.
On behalf of Minister Anderson, I thank those who have contributed to the debate and commend the bill to the parliament.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.

talk.start.para: —If no member wishes to consider the bill in detail, I will put the report question forthwith. The question is that the bill be reported to the House without amendment.

debateinfo.title: INDUSTRY RESEARCH AND DEVELOPMENT AMENDMENT BILL 1998

subdebate.1.para: Debate resumed from 3 December, on motion by Mr Anderson:
That the bill be now read a second time.

talk.start.para: —What we have before us is a minor bill, but it is a minor bill about a major matter. I know there is a lot of interest on all sides of the parliament about a range of issues related to research and development. I do not think any of that interest will lead to contention about this particular bill. I do wish, of course, to make some specific remarks about the terms of this bill, its impact and our view about it, but I principally want to talk about the broader question of research and development and its place in the economic and industrial future of this country—in a sense, talking about what is not in the bill but should be, instead of what is in the bill.

speech.para: The Industry Research and Development Amendment Bill 1998 amends the Industry Research and Development Act 1986, known colloquially as the IR&D Act, and streamlines the administration of the research and development tax concession scheme. It does it in a number of minor but I think useful ways. It extends the time for registration and allows the board a bit more discretion in the manner in which it deals with applications. This is always something the House should examine when legislation is changed to make it less proscriptive and more discretionary. It gives flexibility but it also gives, in a sense, less direct scrutiny. But this sort of discretion exercised by a public body is open to the normal review procedures of our administrative law regime, so I think we have no problem with that.

The bill has another aspect, one which parliamentarians should always examine but with which in this case I have no concern, in that it has a retrospective element. It allows the board to consider or reconsider six specific applications where the existing lack of discretion to accept late applications has prevented the board from validly considering them. In the case of these six, as I am advised and as appears to be unquestionably the case, the delay was not the fault of the applicants but in the administration of their application. The retrospective element seems to be entirely beneficial, so we have no difficulty with it, although it is never a matter that we allow to go through without comment.
The bill also implements some minor proposals arising from the Audit Office review concerning appointments to the board and other such matters.

We intend to support this bill and the amendments which it makes to the act. They assist in the administration of a scheme. But what I hope and expect will be unanimity in the House should not in any way deflect attention from the profound concerns that we on this side have at the decline in business investment in research and development which has followed from the government's flawed strategy of cutting assistance for research and development. This is what I call the hole at the heart of our economy.

There continues to be predominantly welcome news about the strength of the economy. There are some worrying signs, which I spoke about last night in the debate on the appropriation bills. I will not repeat what I said then, but there are clouds on the horizon and today we have had what appears to be worrying information about an increase in long-term employment. Nevertheless, everybody in Australia welcomes the fact that the growth figures had been better than expected, and we hope it continues.

But my concern—as an Australian, as a member of parliament and, particularly, as shadow minister for industry—is that at the very heart of our economic development there is a fundamental flaw, a structural problem in our economy which is leading us to not be positioned as effectively as we might to maximise the benefits and opportunities of globalisation, and to not be as effective a participant as we might in the economy of the 21st century.

I am concerned about the new industries, the new jobs. Those phrases are sometimes misunderstood to mean that one is not interested in the existing industries—the flourishing core of our mining, agricultural and manufacturing industries at the moment, as well as what it is more fashionable to discuss these days, the services sector. But when we talk about the industries of the future and about the importance of science and technology, and research and development, we do not mean only the wonderful and exciting new industries that research and development can generate but the way in which they can transform our existing industries and have traditionally done so.

There is no doubt that our agricultural industries have been wonderfully enhanced, over the years, by the powerful impact of the research and development that has been done by the industry specific R&D boards and by the CSIRO. That sort of research and our strength in medical research combine to put us in a position where we have a wonderful opportunity to be very successful in Australia in the emerging biotechnology industry.

There is a lot of fascination with information technology in the public debate and in the government, where a minister is specifically responsible for information technology but the rest of technology is not so specifically addressed. It is lumped in with the industry portfolio overall—which is where it should be, but I am concerned about its lack of priority there.

There are worrying reports from our researchers, highlighted this week in an article in the Age, that we might miss the opportunity that our research strength gives us in what is going to be the industry of the 21st century. There is no doubt the last decade of this 20th century has been the decade of information technology, the silicon decade, a decade dominated by physics. I suspect in the next decade or so we are going to move to the dominance of the biological sciences, of genetic engineering, of the products and the problems that that creates—the challenges and the opportunities. Australia is very well placed in that area—per head of population there are few, if any, countries that can claim more success in publication, in citation, in innovative thinking, in original thinking and in effective research and development in this area of potentially great economic importance in the 21st century.

That is just an example. As IT has become a centre of debate, so now we are moving to biotechnology, but there are other important new areas of research and development, both in their application to existing industries and to things we have not imagined. In areas like polymers and those sorts of potential new industries and new products, Australia can be at the cutting edge. But we are going in the wrong direction: slashing the research and development tax concession, cutting funding to universities, and undermining our intellectual property regime in a manner that affects our most successful policy initiative with regard to innovation in this area—the Cooperative Research Centre Scheme—which has had bipartisan support and has flourished under governments of both persuasions. Those things are a source of real and profound concern to me.

The problem we have before us in dealing with this bill is not what is in it, which I think we all support, but what is not in it—what it does not say, what it does not address, what it does not examine about the industries of the future and the jobs of the future. Sometimes, in a welcome way, you find the occasional minister saying something about the potential of new industries. With Senator Alston, it is only about IT, but that is his brief; I do not criticise him for that. My criticism for him is that he speculates about whatever the current trendy phrase is—something about tax here, something about clusters there. You try to look behind the comments and say, `Where's the policy?' This is not an independent commentator writing interesting articles, this is the minister, the member of the executive government with responsibility for this area. Where is the executive action? Clusters are an important concept, with potential to assist the growth of new industries or new companies, to build on existing industries. But just saying it is a good thing does not help. You actually have to do something. And at the moment nothing is happening.

Look at the balance of Australia's external trade, particularly our exports. A little of the shape of our imports as well is affected by this, and of our import competitiveness, but let us just have a look at our exports. We have had a long and continuing history of great strength in exports from mining and agriculture. It has been the basis of our wealth for the whole of the European development of this country, and you cannot imagine an Australia where that will not be the case, where they will not be fundamental to our future. They will be different. The mining industry is more obviously different to the eye than agriculture because we have had the transformation from the underground mine to the open cut, with the new technology and the changes that it has made.

The product, the technology, the science that have gone into agriculture are not so obvious to the layman driving by but it has meant that wheat, wool and the new industries like cotton—and the new products within wheat and wool—have kept Australia at the cutting edge in that area. They have kept us productive, successful, effective and efficient. We need to continue to do two things: to encourage and support the R&D that keeps those industries going and to build on the strengths that those industries give us.

I mention the period up to 1996, and I do not use that figure simply because it is the period of the change of government, which is rhetorically convenient for me, but because the most recent data tends to analyse these industrial structural changes up to 1996; that is when the analysis was able to be done. Documents which have been published by the current government—this research took place over a 20-year period to 1996 and essentially looked at the structural changes that took place in the period of the previous Labor government—show a great increase in our manufactured exports and in our services exports. One of the significant areas of growth in our manufactured exports is in the further processing of our minerals and our agricultural products.

This has had a bit of a cult status. It seems intuitive that, because we grow, produce or dig out these primary resources, we should always be the best place to further process them. That is not going to be the case; it cannot always be the case. The laws of economics do not work like that or else we would not have any of the industries we have that sometimes depend upon further processing other people's products—some of the high tech things that we do. But there are significant opportunities: for example, the emergence of the opportunity for the further processing of magnesium. It is being driven by research and development, by cooperative research centres, by the injection of new technology. Research did not put the magnesium there; research, in the main, did not find it. Research has the potential to develop that natural resource into an effective commercially successful new product and maybe even new industry. We might see a bit of state competition as to where this might best be developed. I am all for a bit of competition, but there is nothing less productive than having states caught up in a bidding war about who should have a particular industry within Australia.

In the time remaining to me, let me turn my attention to some aspects of what a government should be doing, rather than deploring what is not happening. What used to be called the Metal Trades Industry Association—the forebear of the current Australian industry group—in a research paper, Make or break, stated:
OECD analysis suggests that manufacturing companies in high wage markets can best survive by focusing on work that has a high technology or science content.

That is a very apposite comment because today with the release—even if it is the very reluctant release—by the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business of his secret agenda to the Prime Minister about employment matters, we see the contrast, starkly written, between a high wage strategy and a low wage strategy. Everything in that document is about lowering wages. I see here some representatives of rural and regional Australia. I hope they have read the document and have seen that it is talking about lower wages in regional Australia—that the people they represent should get paid less than the people I represent—and, as a corollary, what that means for other income support payments in rural and regional Australia.

We want to talk about a high wage strategy for Australia and that will not automatically happen. It will happen if we are intelligent, if we look at issues of innovation, research and development and the associated investment in the products of innovation in research and development through venture capital.

Governments can play an important part, an active role, by committing funds to the universities and the cooperative research centres that conduct much of this research and development and providing incentives to the venture capital industry. On the face of it, one of the government's initiatives about venture capital seems to be working well. I am always happy to acknowledge the bits that work—it never takes very long.

What I see about the innovation investment funds—it is very early days—is that, conceptually, it seems to be quite a well designed scheme and it has the potential to be of value to one aspect of our venture capital industry. I hope it is successful. We said at the last election that we would continue it and there is nothing I have seen since that time to discourage me in that area.
