But the overall thrust of government effort in terms of innovation and research and development is going in the wrong direction, reducing incentives for the private sector leading to the decline in business investment in research and development. For the first time since we have been measuring this matter, the trend is down. There could not be a worse time for a reduction in business investment and research and development in terms of what is needed to position Australia to be successful next century.

The second area where governments of all developed countries, but particularly the Australian government, need to invest is in education and training both in aggregate terms and in terms of where and how that is done. Others are more expert in that, and more responsible for that than I am, and I am very happy for the member for Dobell and others to lead the debate on that. I want to focus on just one aspect.

We have a disappointing and absurd situation in that, as a country that needs science and engineering to turn our potential into jobs and industries for the future, we say that the Higher Education Contribution Scheme should be imposed more heavily on students of science and engineering than on others. That probably would have suited me when I was at university because I was not any good at those things, and those of us who did arts and economics degrees would not have been hit. But in the national interest, how can you say that it makes sense to put a deterrent on young people going to university? The only place where the government think the price signal does not work in a market economy is in the incentives for young people to go to university. They put disincentives in their way in studying science and engineering.

Of course there is a big government role in infrastructure. There is a lot to be said there, most of which has been articulated often, about roads, rail, telecommunications, et cetera. But we need to look at our scientific and legal infrastructure, the framework of intellectual property rights. I am extremely concerned about the recent move by the National Competition Council which has been opposed by both the CSIRO and IP Australia and which has the potential to water down our intellectual property rights and impede the commercialisation of innovation.

The Howard government have been silent about this. They make generalised glib statements. We need them to make it very clear that they reject the National Competition Council's proposals as they relate to intellectual property.

I am concerned about other areas of lack of government action, which I will mention briefly because most of them do not come to the subject matter of my comments today, such as export assistance and enterprise improvement. These are areas where a role for government has been accepted even by many conservatives on the basis of perceived market failure. We have reduction in funding for export assistance and abandonment of the field of enterprise improvements.

There are three other issues, none of which I will deal with in detail today, that closely relate to what we are dealing with here and which need examination and action by a government if we are to deal with this hole at the heart of our economy. They relate to issues of tax, and not this red herring about a goods and services tax.

The one useful thing that is emerging is a consensus that you might be encouraged by the distributional effects of a goods and services tax. That is a proper matter for public debate and we are having it elsewhere, at great and exhausting length. But the argument that it has any significant efficiency and macro economic effects has now gone. Even its advocates now acknowledge that is not the case. It is not going to create jobs and it is not going to have a significant efficiency effect. There might be another case for it, but that is nothing to do with this argument.

However, there are some tax issues around that are important for investment in innovation, and the capital gains tax issue does need to be addressed. We do not want this to become a cloak for capital gains tax reductions which simply transfer the tax burden from people who make their money from capital gain to people who make their money from the sweat of their brow or the exercise of their intellect. That is an issue that needs to be addressed along with design issues and venture capital issues.

Obviously, we do not oppose these amendments because they streamline the administration of the R&D tax scheme and they create the potential for the Research and Development Board and those others associated with the administration of the scheme to operate more efficiently and effectively. They also streamline system design matters to do with the tax act and the IR&D Act so that they do not get in the way of the objectives.

We sometimes find in our parliamentary and executive government, in our administration, that the administration of the law gets in the way of the intention of the law. That is essentially our fault. We are the legislators, and if the law creates that impression, creates that outcome, it is a matter that is our responsibility.

These changes flow from the continuing review, revision and modification of the strategy by successive governments about the administration of the IR&D Act. They will not be the last, and nor should they be the last because we continue to bump against administrative impediments to our public policy objectives. We need to expedite the passage of legislation that gets us back to our core purpose, whether it is in industry research and development or in the plethora of other matters that go through this parliament unnoticed and unheralded while public attention is on matters of controversy and contention.

I notice the member for Groom is in the chamber. He is a new member but I am sure that already he will have had constituents coming up to him saying, `Why do you people spend all your time arguing with each other? Why can't you just get together on a few things that are in the national interest and agree?' And when you say, `But 90 per cent of the bills that go through the parliament are like that,' nobody believes you. I like to think that, in my electorate, people think that I am very open and truthful with them. However, when I say that to them you can see their eyes glaze over because they never read about those things.

You used to read about those things. Only a decade or so ago, media coverage of the Australian parliament did record debates like this. It was not on the front page, and I have to say, with all due modesty, I do not think it would be on the front page, even with this contribution. But there was some acknowledgment that people were up there talking about ordinary matters of profound public interest, sharing common views, disagreeing as we have today about other matters but agreeing about some and saying, `This bit is going well and that bit is okay, but I do not like this.'

That is what the Australian people expect us to do, and it is what our obligation is, but it is very hard to communicate, even to people who have a particular interest in this matter of research and development. This is an area which has a big constituency of Australians concerned about it either because they are involved in doing it—which is a growing band, I am happy to say—or else they are the beneficiaries. These beneficiaries include primary industries that benefit from the CSIRO, and industries that are seeking to take advantage of the R&D initiatives that we take. Yet when we make those consensus initiatives we find that it is very hard to get attention focused on them.

We welcome the amendments and we support them—they do not in any way address our more profound concerns in the area of R&D—not just because they are important but because they are essential to addressing—(Time expired)

talk.start.para: —It being 12.30 p.m., I propose the question that the Main Committee do now adjourn.

subdebateinfo.title: Queensland Liberal Party: One Nation Preferences

talk.start.para: —The Sydney Morning Herald of Saturday, 14 November 1998 gave an interesting insight into the workings of the Liberal Party today, especially the growing influence and power of a small group of extreme right wing power brokers, centred around the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Nick Minchin. I want to focus on the role of Senator Minchin and his chief Queensland acolyte, Mr Santo Santoro, the Queensland state member for Clayfield, and the Liberal Party's unprincipled and disastrous decision to give its preferences to the One Nation Party at the Queensland state election on 13 June of last year.

speech.para: The former member for the seat of Oxley must have thought all her Christmases had come at once when the Queensland Liberal Party decided over the May Labour Day weekend to put the Labor Party last in all but one electorate in the state election. Overnight, almost single-handedly, the Queensland Liberal Party made One Nation a real force in Queensland politics. The Liberal Party's decision, following a similar but less surprising decision by the Queensland National Party, gave One Nation a real chance of winning seats in the Queensland parliament and possibly even holding the balance of power in our state.

They almost got their wish, with the One Nation Party winning 11 seats through Liberal and National Party preferences. For some time the Liberal Party state president Mr Bob Carroll, a Queen Street grazier, claimed credit for the preference decision. The fact that he still says it was the right decision shows just how out of touch he is with the people of Queensland.

But the profile of Senator Minchin in the Sydney Morning Herald of 14 November distributes the credit much more widely. The article makes it clear what most political observers already knew—that every decision made by the Carroll regime in Queensland emanates from Mr Santoro. Senator Minchin has been somewhat bashful about his role in the Queensland preference decision. Given the disastrous result it achieved, that is not surprising.

For months stories have been circulating in Queensland politics that Mr Santoro was the architect of the preference decision and that he was backed up in his decision by his extensive range of contacts in the federal Liberal Party. Mr Santoro tells everyone game enough to listen that he has a pipeline to the Prime Minister, the Treasurer, the minister for labour relations and employment and, of course, the grey eminence of the Liberal Party's right wing, Mr Michael Kroger. Does anyone seriously believe that such a well-connected political hatchet man would not have consulted his southern network before such a momentous decision was made? Bashful though he is, Senator Minchin did concede the following in the Sydney Morning Herald article:
Well, I discuss a lot of things with Santo from time to time. That was a very big issue for the Liberal Party so he would have mentioned it in passing whatever they were doing and why.
Do any of Senator Minchin's party victims and rivals believe him? Does the member for Sturt, who seems to be under attack from Senator Minchin's forces in South Australia once again, believe that?

Also of interest is the fact that the Queensland Liberal Party expelled former state candidate for Ipswich, Steve Wilson. Mr Wilson was expelled because he would not deliver preferences to the One Nation Party. The expulsion shows the lack of support in the Queensland Liberal branch for the Santoro-Minchin preference deal as only 16 of the 44-member Liberal executive voted and with a split decision. It seems not everyone in the Queensland Liberal Party is without principle.

What Senator Minchin must do is come clean on his role in the preference decision. Did he travel to Brisbane on the weekend the decision was made to meet with Mr Santoro and the state Liberal Party president, Mr Bob Carroll? And did he consult with the Prime Minister on this matter?

You cannot blame Senator Minchin for trying to distance himself from such a decision. It was, after all, one of the biggest own goals in political history. The decision helped cost the Liberal Party six of the 15 seats it held and saw it lose official party status once again. It also made the Liberal Party in Queensland a political pariah, even in its own heartland, with sitting members in the blue ribbon seats such as Mr Santoro's suffering swings of 10 per cent or more. The decision also impacted in the federal election, even though with the benefit of hindsight and for political convenience, not principle, the Liberal Party reluctantly put One Nation last in the federal election. It still lost four seats in Queensland and went within a few hundred votes of losing three or four more.

Incredibly, Mr Santoro and his puppet, Mr Carroll, are claiming that the federal election result in Queensland was a good one for the Liberal Party. They even defend the preference decision, blaming the media and dissidents within the Liberal Party for the loss of six seats and for the loss of party status. But the real issue remains: what was the role of Senator Minchin and his Queensland factional colleagues in the decision to give One Nation Liberal Party preferences—arguably, the most inept decision by any political party in the last decade or so.

The people of Queensland are entitled to know who made this disgraceful decision and what role they played. I am sure that the members of the Liberal Party in Queensland, who have seen their party returned to rump status, would also like to know. I am sure most of the people of Queensland would be very interested to know who was involved in the preference decision, why the Liberal Party made those decisions and then what really changed their minds not to make the same decision at the federal election. It certainly was not based on principle. It was certainly based on what they saw as a way to get more votes. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —While I cannot comment on the article that the member for Oxley was referring to, I would just like to remind the member that, in South Australia, where Senator Nick Minchin is a senator, we did very well at the last federal election, and I am sure that we will continue to do so.

speech.para: As I stated several nights ago in the adjournment debate, I recently had occasion to speak out publicly against the prospect of a film being released in Australia, although not yet classified by the Office of Film and Literature Classification—a film entitled, Lolita, based on the novel by Vladimir Nabokov. Unfortunately, there was not enough time to finish, so I will continue here.

This in turn created something of a frenzy on the part of some people in the media. In particular, Mr Phillip Adams, in his Weekend Australian article, without actually naming me, poured vitriol on my efforts to take some steps to protect our children and even accused me of being xenophobic. Again, as I stated in the House earlier, I have written a response to Mr Adams in the form of a letter to the editor to the Australian, dated 16 February 1999, which, sadly, has not yet been published. That may still be. We live in hope. The letter is as follows:
Dear Sir

I choose to refute comments made by Phillip Adams in his article, `In pursuit of Power Abusers'( Weekend Australian , 13-14 February 1999) with reference to an unnamed Liberal MP wanting to have the film, Lolita , sight unseen, banned.

Well, yes, I'm not afraid to admit publicly, having recently finished reading the book, Lolita , by Vladimir Nabokov, on which the film is based, I do have grave concerns about the film which, to date, has not yet been classified by the Office of Film and Literature Classification.

Upon deconstruction of the text, the main themes are: (i) that of a middle-aged man (stepfather) who desires to abduct, rape and keep prisoner a 12-year-old girl, specifically after priming her for that purpose, which he does for two years until her escape, sadly, into the arms of another paedophile and child pornography film-maker; (ii) his justification for continual sexual abuse of his step-daughter; and (iii) his desire to procure more victims via Lolita having more daughters by him.

The justification of his abuse by statements to the effect that his loves her and wants to care for her sounds a bit like Phillip Bell's `hebephile' defence to me. When any adult loves and cares for a child, that's exactly what they do—not sexually exploit them for their own deviant sexual gratification. Mr Adams states the film is a depiction of `child sexuality'. Isn't that the problem? This notion is used by paedophiles to justify their deviant behaviour. The term `child sexuality' in the context of Adams' comments on the film is, in my view, incongruous.

I have no objection to examining the serious issues relating to the abuse and exploitation of children for educative and preventative purposes. However, a film depicting the aforementioned in the genre of `film entertainment' is beyond the pale.

The most up-to-date research suggests there are two things that paedophiles crave most. The first is more children to sexually abuse. The second is mainstream acceptance and sympathy for their activities in any form (Institute of Criminology Conference, 14-15 April 1997, Paedophilia Policy and Prevention). I, for one, do not wish to put a smile on a paedophile's face.

Mr Adams refers to covers of magazines with fourteen year old girls. Yes, sex sells, as does violence, particularly in videos, computer games and films, so how low, if we continue to push boundaries and lower the thresholds of tolerance, can we as a society go? Mr Adams may be consoled by the fact that these are issues I have consistently raised with the Attorney-General's office, as well as the Office of Film and Literature Classification.

I'm a little bit perplexed as to why Mr Adams attributes to the unnamed Liberal MP the comment, "Not only is it filth, (the book, `Lolita') but it is foreign filth." I am not xenophobic, Mr Adams, and I resent the inference in the article. I am also perplexed by Peter Goers' hysterical reaction on local radio recently in relation to my stance on this issue.
Yours sincerely
(Mrs) Trish Draper MP (nee Zimmermann)

talk.start.para: —Like many members, I am aware that Telstra has appointed a new chief executive officer to take over the organisation on 1 March. I am sure that all members wish him well in this very challenging position. I note that the new chief executive officer has flagged a further crackdown on operating expenses. Perhaps a good start would be some of the correspondence the organisation has been sending out.

speech.para: Just before Christmas, a constituent telephoned me to ask why Telstra would be sending her letters in Japanese. I had to confess that I did not know. I said that it must have been an oversight. She then said, if it was an oversight, why did her daughter, who lived at the same address, get a similar letter? She said that apart from the date, 22 December 1998, her address and the name at the bottom—Ken Sackville, Regional General Manager—the letter was all in Japanese.

Here is the letter. This letter is all in Japanese. It has got `Telstra' at the top, the constituent's address and 22 December, then it has greetings in Japanese—I suppose that must be `Dear' in Japanese—before `Ms Tilley', then it goes on for six paragraphs all in Japanese and it is signed by Ken Sackville, Regional General Manager.

The people who received the letters have given me permission to use their names. One was sent to Lorraine Tilley and the other was sent to Renay Tilley. They run a hairdressing salon in Wollongong and Telstra sent them each a letter. The women have assured me that they are not Japanese speakers and they are puzzled at receiving such letters.

First of all, I tried to telephone Mr Sackville and I could not get through. So I then rang Telstra Customer Relations and asked them why they were sending out letters in Japanese to English speaking people and if they could give me an explanation. Talk about the run-around! Obviously people did not know; they did not know these letters were going out. I was put onto various people and finally I spoke to someone who assured me that Telstra would contact the Tilleys and give them a full explanation. Then I said, `What about me?' They said, `Yes, you will be contacted, Mr Hollis, and you will get a full explanation.'

talk.start.para: —In Japanese or English?

—I did ask for it to be in English not in Japanese. I have been ringing Telstra each week and they will not get back to me. One of the points the Tilleys brought up to me was about waste of public money. They asked me how many of these letters I thought were being sent out. I said I had absolutely no idea, but I would ask Telstra how many people throughout Australia were receiving these letters. I do not know if any of my colleagues' constituents are receiving these letters.

speech.para: I receive many complaints about Telstra in the office. They are usually to do with telephone accounts and they can usually be fairly easily sorted out. It is usually that some of the other members of the family have been using the phone for various telephone calls they should not have been making and hence the big bill. But this one I am quite puzzled about.

I wonder whether the letters are actually meant for people in Japan, whether Telstra is selling its services in Japan and writing to people in Japan. As I say, I am still waiting for a reply. And, as my colleague suggests, I urge Telstra, when they do reply to me, to please reply to me in English. I do go to Japan quite a lot but I am not a Japanese speaker and the Tilleys are most certainly not Japanese speakers.

I am also concerned that Telstra has not bothered to get back to me. This is fairly typical of many business organisations in Australia, that when you raise complaints with them they do not have the courtesy to get back to you. It may have been a genuine mistake, or they may have thought the Tilleys were Japanese speakers, or the Tilleys may have won a prize, a trip to Japan, and Telstra is writing in Japanese to tell them that they have won a trip to Japan or something like that. I want to know the answer and the Tilleys most certainly want to know the answer to why they are receiving this letter. It is in very nice Japanese; nevertheless, they cannot understand it. We all want to know the contents of this letter that Telstra has sent out in Japanese.

talk.start.para: —Sayonara, member for Throsby!

subdebateinfo.title: Native Title: Release of Fish in Waterways

talk.start.para: —I am here today to make a plea for commonsense, more balance and less pointless bureaucracy with reference to the Native Title Act. The fact is that the inflexible nature of the Native Title Act is fuelling bureaucracy and hurting a lot of people.

speech.para: I cite in evidence of this the example of Dennis Dilger, from Childers, in my electorate. He runs a very well-focused and very successful fish hatchery, and he exports to Japan. He breeds all sorts of native fish, like Australian bass, sooty grunter, silver and golden perch, whiting, flathead, coral trout and even barramundi. Many of these are used for the stocking of dams, rivers, lakes, estuaries and other waterways.

He does this under contract and strict supervision from DPI. You cannot move these fish from certain river systems to other river systems; there is quite a protocol there. He usually does it under contract to councils, fish stocking groups, government departments and community organisations who generally know what they are doing. In fact, he has pioneered many breeding techniques and his fingerlings have been exported overseas, as I mentioned earlier.

But fish breeding is a very sensitive business. The window of opportunity for the transfer of fingerlings from holding tanks to open water is quite narrow. It can be as narrow as three days and the outer limit is generally not beyond a fortnight. It is absolutely vital, then, that he meets the window of opportunity for a particular fish or his investment just goes down the drain and the fish do not survive.

Recent changes to the Native Title Act demand that 30 days notice be given for the release of fish into waterways in areas where there is a claim. Just think about that: 30 days notice has to be put in writing before you can put the fingerlings into the water. Because various land councils close down over the Christmas holidays, the state government deemed that this should be put out another 21 days, then you had to allow another seven days for the actual issue of the permit, so you had an eight-week time lapse. During that time, the fish got too big, the cost became prohibitive and they could not be placed in their new environment. This delay, about which there was no prior warning, cost an excellent business operator an estimated $30,000 over the last few months, all because of thoughtless bureaucratic bungling.

I can understand people claiming native title who have sacred sites, who have land that has been in their tribe for generations, being sensitive about new roads being punched through their areas or land clearing that is unnecessary. It is appropriate that they should be consulted about such matters. But, for the life of me, I cannot understand why a service that is regenerating the environment, putting things back into the system that had been taken out in previous generations and, in some cases, putting new life into man-made storages, has to face hurdles such as this. Let us give the fish breeders, people like Dennis Dilger, a fair go. Is it any wonder there is anger and resentment in regional Australia when hardworking small businessmen and the community at large confront mindless bureaucracy like this?

talk.start.para: —Today we have seen the revelation of the plan that the Minister for Employment, Workplace Relations and Small Business envisages for Australia into the future. In extraordinary circumstances, we have had what can only be described as a truckload of documents dropped officially by the minister on proposals that have been considered by the cabinet and by the Prime Minister. What is extraordinary about this is that it says a lot about the dynamics of decision making. Whilst I do not want to dwell on the obvious tensions between the pretenders to the throne, the two Peters, what this document reveals is a vision for Australia that is quite scary.

speech.para: In the Age on Saturday there was a document based on the concept of mutual obligation and exploration of what was happening in New Zealand and the United States and even what was being considered by the Blair Labour government in the United Kingdom. In my speech on the appropriations legislation, I referred to that article. I said that I hoped that if Australia—and in particular the Howard government—was going to continue with the notion of mutual obligation, that it should be mutual. The documents that Minister Reith has now revealed indicate this expansion in his eyes of mutual obligation. But what is not revealed in the documents is that it is a true concept of reciprocal obligation—that is, the government will do something for people and that, in return, people receiving a benefit and other things from government policies will do something for that. For instance, if we look at the Work for the Dole scheme, all that is being done is that people, in return for their benefit, are receiving between 24 and 30 hours work.

The work experience in itself has importance. The Labor Party suggests that we can build on that work experience if proper training is injected into these schemes. When the junior minister in this portfolio, the Minister for Employment Services, answers questions, he can relate how cheap the Work for the Dole scheme is. Unfortunately, it is cheap—in the full sense of the word—in that, bar the work experience that these people have, it does not give them any wider experience.

It is of interest that the Minister for Employment Services, in a couple of answers this week, referred to the community service scheme back in 1987 that the then Liberal opposition went to the election with, which he believed was based on the work of Professor Mead in the United States. In his answer on 16 February, he said:
. . . at much the same time as Professor Lawrence Mead, in America, was developing notions of responsibilities to match welfare rights.

Professor Mead has been involved in promoting notions such as the families, the children of people on benefits, having no rights themselves to benefits. If that is the notion that the Minister for Employment Services says that we should follow from people like Professor Mead, I really wonder what the vision is for Australia. At least the document that Minister Reith has produced has explored fully some of the problems. I dismiss many of the answers, bar the ones that he has picked up that Labor went into the last election with, such as the tax credit scheme and others. This document highlights the need for special attention for the long-term unemployed. What is the answer? Suddenly the long-term unemployed are not going to be paid a full wage. This is the great boost for the long-term unemployed and their families—to put them behind the economic eight ball. This is a real problem.

When we look at some of these proposals, we see that there is a proposal to assist small business: to explore the possibilities that small businesses need to meet a more minimum set of requirements for working conditions of their employees. If this is Minister Reith's vision for the future, it is something that we will have to be debated over time. I believe that we are at a crucial time in Australia's history. Solutions can be achieved if we have a proper debate and cooperation from all those that have an interest in finding those solutions. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —I want to report to the Main Committee this afternoon that I am detecting a tide of anger in my electorate in Townsville and Thuringowa on the Labor Party's position on matters such as unfair dismissal and junior wage rates. This morning, for example, I received two faxes in Canberra. One is from Kent Sutton at Darrell Lea on Flinders Mall. He said:

speech.para: Dear Peter, Thank you for your recent update. My comments are:
1. you must retain junior wage rates otherwise no one will ever employ a junior again—

Secondly, he said that he would like to see the government extend the Work for the Dole scheme to everybody, that it would give the Australian taxpayers a little value for their dollar. I am well aware that this particular scheme is very popular in the community. I thank Kent for sending me that note this morning. The other fax is from Dave and Adele from Dave's Pet Barn in Kirwan, and I thank both of them. They say:
Re the Unfair Dismissal Laws.

Would you please convey to Mr Beazley and his Senate members and to Meg Lees and her Democrat Party that the statistics for unfair dismissal claims that they are hiding behind does not reflect the true state of the epidemic of suing small business by people who are making a career out of unfair dismissal.
No small businessman in his right mind would contest a case as the litigation costs double the payout figure. There is no hope of recovery from the people bringing the claim, as they cannot pay—
That is an issue in itself in a wide range of litigation. They continue:

It is clearly a law to help the down and out have rorts. Break the back of small business, which for some obscure reason is the aim of the two opposing parties, or are they really one party under two names—
that is an interesting question—

Their obstructive behaviour is sentencing young Australians to either no job or at best casual employment is very concerning. Why don't they come clean and stop hiding behind statistics and tell all Australians what their agenda is.
They are just two unsolicited faxes that I have received here in Canberra this morning.

As I move widely in the Townsville community I detect very great concern with the position of the Australian Labor Party and the Democrats. The Australian Labor Party is seen as a party that simply opposes for the sake of opposing, has no plans for the future and no vision. Certainly, this government has a plan. It has a vision. It wants to bring unemployment down. It wants to have sensible laws. In a sense, it certainly understands the problems that businesses have. I, as a small businessman, know full well the ramifications of the unfair dismissal laws and why that precluded me from employing extra people. I was concerned about the legal ramifications of that.

The Labor Party, the Democrats and the Senate have got to get out of the way of the government. We have a plan for the next century. We have a new tax system for Australia for the next century. Yet these people just sit there and say they are going to obstruct, they are going to make life difficult, but they have got no alternative.

It is certainly incumbent on the Labor Party, the Democrats and the Senate to give the government a fair go—we have a mandate to do what we have been elected to do—and to let us move on. I make the point that three years ago we had to make some very difficult decisions in bringing the budget back into surplus. Three years later we are reaping the benefits of those very hard decisions. Now we want to move on to a new tax system, a new employment system. Let us have the hard problems and the benefits again in three years time. We have a track record as a government able to deliver, that looks after the people who live in our great country.

More and more people are going to produce this kind of material which has been sent to me today as their plea to the Australian Labor Party and to the Democrats to get out of the way, to stop obstructing, to let the government get on with its agenda and to build a much better Australian nation.

talk.start.para: —In the 30 seconds that I have, I say to the honourable member for Herbert without too much rancour that the coalition went to the election with a plan. Even though they have formed government—and I acknowledge that they did win the election—that plan was rejected by over 50 per cent of the voters.

speech.para: The concern is that not only has the plan been rejected by the majority of voters but we now have a new plan that Mr Reith is peddling around the place which the Australian public will be even further confused about. If we throw in any other plans that Treasurer Costello puts in place, or that Prime Minister Howard can inject into a preamble suggested for the Constitution, there will be even further confusion amongst the Australian electorate.

debate.para: The following answers to questions were circulated:

talk.start.para: asked the Minister for Trade, upon notice, on 24 November 1998:

question.para: (1) Further to the answer to question No. 3086 (Hansard , 15 July 1998, page 6271), will the Minister inquire into the success of the 1998 World Expo in Lisbon, Portugal, in particular the trading and tourism opportunities available to participating nations; if not, why not.
(2) Would an inquiry similar to that referred to in part (1) assist the planning of Australia's exhibit for Expo 2000 in Hanover.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) Australia did not participate in the 1998 World Expo in Lisbon and the Government has no independent means of assessing the success of this event. The Portuguese Commissioner-General presented a final report on the Expo to the International Bureau of Expositions (BIE) General Assembly meeting on 27 November 1998. I understand that the report focuses on the urban development impact of the Expo and does not contain substantive discussion of its trade or tourism impact for Portugal or for the participating countries.

subdebateinfo.title: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission: Monitoring Price Changes
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 224)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 30 November 1998:

question.para: Will the Government release the advice it has given to or received from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission about how it intends to monitor the price changes that will occur because of the implementation of the GST.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: The Government has not given to or received from the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) advice about how it intends to monitor the price changes that will occur because of the implementation of the GST.

The Government has introduced a number of tax reform bills including A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998. This Bill will amend the Trade Practices Act 1974 by inserting a new Part to provide the ACCC with power to monitor prices, in order to prevent the possibility of consumer exploitation and excessive profit taking in the transition to the new tax system. The Bill will prohibit price exploitation, which will occur where a corporation supplies a good or service at a price that is unreasonably high, taking into account the various tax changes, provided the unreasonably high price is not attributable to the supplier's costs, supply and demand conditions or any other relevant matter. The price oversight regime will begin 12 months prior to the implementation of the GST and will continue for a further two years after the date of introduction. The ACCC will publish guidelines about when a price may be regarded as being in contravention of the prohibition on price exploitation. The ACCC will report quarterly to the Minister on its operation under the new Part of the Trade Practices Act and these reports will be made public.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: Australian Competition and Consumer Commission
subdebateinfo.subtitle: (Question No. 247)

talk.start.para: asked the Treasurer, upon notice, on 2 December 1998:

question.para: (1) Did the Commonwealth announce after the special premiers' conference in November 1998 that it would give the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission statutory authority to formally monitor prices and take legal action against businesses taking pricing decisions in a manner inconsistent with tax reform.
(2) Is the Government taking steps to curb GST-based profiteering.
(3) Has the Government introduced formal monitoring of bank fees and charges; if not how will the Government prevent profiteering by banks.

talk.start.para: —The answer to the honourable member's question is as follows:

answer.para: (1) and (2) The Government announced in A New Tax System (page 85) that it would legislate to give the Australian Competition and Consumer Commission (ACCC) special transitional powers to formally monitor prices. The ACCC will be required to monitor retail prices in order to identify instances where consumers have not fully benefited from reductions in the tax rate, or have been exposed to greater than necessary price rises.

The Agreement on Principles for the Reform of Commonwealth-State Financial Relations, which was endorsed by the Premiers and Chief Ministers in November 1998, states that the Trade Practices Act 1974 will be amended to insert a new Part giving the ACCC statutory authority to formally monitor prices and take legal action against business practices that take pricing decisions in a manner inconsistent with tax reform. In order to ensure that the measures apply to the whole economy, the States and Territories agree to apply the Commonwealth legislation, and extend it to cover those areas outside the Commonwealth's constitutional power.

In general, it can be expected that the competitive pressures that already exist within the economy will ensure that a fall in the tax rate on a product will flow through to consumers in the form of lower retail prices. However, the Government recognises that with the transition to a new tax system, there will be legitimate community concern regarding the possibility of consumer exploitation and excessive profit taking.

Accordingly, the Government introduced into Parliament, on 10 December 1998, A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998 that amends the Trade Practices Act 1974 to provide the ACCC with powers to monitor prices, in order to prevent the possibility of consumer exploitation and excessive profit taking in the transition to the new tax system. The Bill requires the ACCC to publish guidelines about when a price may be regarded as being in contravention of the prohibition on price exploitation. The ACCC will report quarterly to the Minister on its operations under the new Part and these reports will be made public.
The price oversight regime will begin 12 months prior to the implementation of the GST and will continue for a further two years after the date of introduction.

(3) The Government will maintain its policy of informal monitoring of bank fees and charges. The major banks voluntarily inform the ACCC of their movements in fees and charges. These arrangements would not preclude the ACCC from formally monitoring bank fees and charges, along with other prices in the economy, as provided for in the A New Tax System (Trade Practices Amendment) Bill 1998.

talk.start.para: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, upon notice, on 10 December 1998:

question.para: (1) What was the budget allocation for the ABC TV (a) news and current affairs and (b) documentaries and features departments in 1997.
(2) How many documentaries were commissioned solely within the ABC in 1997 and what was the subject in each case.
(3) How many documentaries were purchased by the ABC and partly funded by the Film Finance Corporation, Australian Film Commission, Film Victoria or another funding body in 1997.
(4) How many documentaries were purchased by the ABC in the secondary market from overseas offerings in 1997.
(5) What is the usual cost of the documentaries referred to in part (4).
(6) Which of the documentaries referred to in the preceding parts were the five most expensive to produce or purchase and what did each cost the ABC.
(7) Is the information requested in the preceding parts collated in some publication or format in the ABC; if so, (a) in what publication or format and (b) is it available to the public.

talker.name: McGauran, Peter, MP
Mr McGauran
talker.role: Arts and the Centenary of Federation

talk.start.para: —The Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts has provided the following answer to the honourable member's question:

answer.para: (1) In line with Government accounting policies the ABC maintains budget information on a financial rather than calendar year basis. For the 1997/98 financial year the budget allocation for:
(a) ABC News and Current Affairs (Television) was $70.7 million.
(b) ABC Documentaries (including Natural History Unit) was $9.4 million; and ABC Features/Science and Talks was $10.1 million.
(2) ABC Television Documentaries commissioned twelve projects in house.
The projects generated forty-nine episodes of documentary material produced or currently in production solely by the ABC. These were:
. "Reporters at Large". Short stories made by reporters selected and trained by the ABC as potential Race Around The World reporters, but not selected as part of the final eight.
. "The Invincibles". The story of the 1948 touring Australian Ashes team.
. "Eye of the Storm". A four part natural history series about climate.
. "Top Floor". A three part series which traced the business highs and lows of well known Australian entrepreneurs in the 80's and 90's.
. "Frocks, Woks, and Gossip". A documentary following the introduction of The Australian Woman's Weekly in Singapore.
. "Aim 4 More". The story of a Brisbane contemporary band who set out to find out more about their family history, (produced by the Indigenous Production Unit).
. "King's School". A five part series on life in a boarding school.
. "Burden of Proof". Examined the human cost of attempting to find the truth behind child sex crimes.
. "Tent Boxing". Examined the history of an Aboriginal boxing troupe which toured rural Australia in the 1950's.
. "Without a Song". (Produced by the Indigenous Production Unit).
. "Dancing in the Dark". A program to mark the 20th anniversary of the Sydney Gay and Lesbian Mardi Gras.
. "Race Around The World". 21 episodes made up of short documentaries from young film makers as they travel the world.

Documentary episodes were also produced in house for inclusion in series produced by the Science Unit for programs such as Quantum, the Arts Unit for Sunday Afternoon and evening timeslots and the Religious Unit for programs such as Compass. News and Current Affairs produced documentary episodes for programs such as Australian Story.
(3) In 1997 thirty one single episode documentaries and five documentary series were commissioned in this way.
The projects generated fifty five episodes of documentary material commissioned by the ABC and funded in part by other funding bodies in the year.

(4) Sixteen individual programs and seventeen documentary series (excluding Natural History) were purchased from overseas for inclusion in documentary timeslots such as The Big Picture and Inside Story in 1997.
(5) and (6) Arrangements made with producers outside the ABC are considered commercial in confidence.
(7) Apart from published program guides this information is not available in a collated/published form.
